It is about deciding on a policy where assets, now exclusively in the public sector, can be best used in terms of their value to the community generally and in terms of their efficiency. It is on that basis that the Government has undertaken to consider each of the various public authorities, and their business, which have been under public notice in the last six to 12 months or so.

ANSWER.PARA: My Party has a process and it has a policy. I have said before in this House and I will say it again: the Australian Labor Party is the only real political party in Australia. It functions like a political party. What we have on the other side of the House is outfits bound together by convenience rather than conviction, outfits which do not function as a living, breathing organ of the community.

The Labor Party is a mass party; it has feelings; it has views; and it has very deeply-rooted sentiments about certain areas of policy. The Opposition never had such depth and sentiments. The Liberal Party will always be just an outfit. Because it does not have those processes, it does not have conferences which mean anything. That is why the Labor Party is always so newsworthy organisationally, and it remains newsworthy in or out of office because it is the one great mass party of Australia and it is the one party which has been the only vehicle of social and economic reform.

What honourable members opposite regard as a bit of value for themselves as spectators on the sidelines of the policy ferment that goes on from time to time in my Party, in the end, of course, leads to policy action, the implementation of which generally beats the Opposition members. We will go on beating them because we are the only party which can actually deal with problems. Honourable members opposite say they can deal with them but they never get around to it. They were always going to reduce tariffs but they never did it. They were always going to privatise things but they never got around to it. They were going to float the Australian dollar but they could not do that. They were going to turn Australia into a market economy but they never got around to it.

The fact is that what that crowd says and what it has ever done are two distinctly different things. As usual, it will be this Party which breaks all the new ground in Australian social and economic life. So they want to watch our conference because what will come out of it will be more progress for Australia. They can just sit on the sidelines again and watch the real Government of Australia get on with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Employment, Education and Training advise the House of any measures to enhance the degree of uniformity in year 12 assessment procedures in Australian schools?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can inform the honourable member for Adelaide, and through him the House, that a report on year 12 assessment was recently completed by the Australasian Conference of Assessment and Certification Authorities at the request of the Australian Education Council. That report will be released today for public comment. The report is telling us about the kinds of certificates that are issued for people who are leaving school at the end of year 12. The report maps the differences which exist across State and territory boundaries. I hope that upon the release of the report we will be able to see an active debate about these issues and about which of the differences between the States and the territories are really justified.

ANSWER.PARA: The terminology in the States and the Territories varies considerably. The courses which students study vary. The arrangements for assessing and reporting students' achievements vary, and the marks and grades given for tertiary entrance subjects also vary. In the area of assessment, in New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory subjects for tertiary entrance are assessed by a combination of external exams and moderated, school-based assessment, while in Queensland and the Australian Capital Territory these subjects are assessed by school-based assessments alone. Of course, the process of school-based assessments or the process of moderation varies from place to place as well.

In the area of tertiary entrance, we find that the scale used in the States varies enormously, as does the aggregates which are provided to determine tertiary entrance. For instance, in New South Wales the score is calculated out of 500, whilst in Queensland it is calculated out of 990. So, just to give you a comparison, Mr Speaker, a student in various States who reached the same level of achievement in, for instance, English would receive an A in Victoria and the ACT, 84 in New South Wales and Western Australia, 18 in South Australia and the Northern Territory, and a C in Tasmania.

Indeed, if we look across the whole range of different assessment practices, we see that it is only in South Australia and the Northern Territory, which are formally linked, that there is the same process. In other words, in no two States besides South Australia and the Northern Territory are there identical systems for assessing year 12 achievement and, therefore, entry into the university system. This obviously creates difficulties for students moving from one State to another, having passed year 12 in one State and attempting to get entry into a university in another State. It also seems to me that it places students at a disadvantage if there is not a process of uniform recognition across the country in terms of year 12 achievement.

I intend that this matter will be on the agenda of the next meeting of the Australian Education Council and I hope that through the discussions there and elsewhere we can advance this issue with a view to achieving a greater sense of uniformity and consistency across the country. Of course, this occurs at a time when there is a debate, which the Prime Minister has encouraged, about trying to re-examine the functions of the State and Commonwealth governments in relation to our various responsibilities. I hope that no-one will allow this debate to derail a quite proper move in the direction of achieving greater consistency and uniformity in some standard measures like year 12 assessment procedures.
Mr Speaker, I take the opportunity to table a copy of the report for the information of honourable members.

—Can the Treasurer advise the House in what manner the present economic policy settings are intended to reduce Australia's current account deficit and the consequent build-up in our external indebtedness?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the Government came to office it has tried to repair very quickly the policy framework left to us by our predecessors to bring a trend change in the current account deficit and inflation and to lift growth in employment, a policy which it undertook from its inception. One of the principal changes, of course, in that has been the very dramatic shift in the public sector balance from a strong deficit to a surplus on the Commonwealth's Budget. That has been perhaps the principal block upon which the change in the savings balance has been built.

ANSWER.PARA: No such change has been evident in the policy of the Opposition. At this stage, seven years on, the Opposition has not constructed a credible policy framework in its responses. Even though this Parliament is now six months old, there is no coordinated framework of policies to deal with the current account imbalance, inflation and some of the other problems endemic to the economy. The Opposition has three policies: privatisation, the consumption tax and a reduction in tariffs to zero. That is the totality of the policy response.

I have been asked a number of questions about privatisation. There is no current account panacea from privatisation. If the Opposition as a government succeeded in selling Telecom Australia for $20 billion, apart from the problems that would bring in terms of the domestic economy it would make not a jot of difference to the current account balance in terms of the savings-investment balance and the call on overseas savings. It would simply be a transfer to the Budget, drawing down a call upon Australian savings. If that is not what it means, and the Opposition is saying it thinks that foreign equity ought to be involved, which would see capital inflow onto the current account, that foreign equity would be involved only if the sovereignty we currently enjoy over telecommunications-or any other area, for that matter-were diminished. At any rate, nobody would handle a $20 billion foreign exchange exposure. So that would make no difference to the current account.

That is the principal point. Privatisation may improve the efficiency of a business and it may mean a more rational allocation of national resources but it will not make any difference to the current account deficit. Any policy built upon that premise is wrong and cannot make a contribution to the principal problem facing the economy. The consumption tax which we have heard so much about adds seven percentage points to the price level and to inflation. A 15 per cent consumption tax net of the wholesale sales tax lifts that inflation rate by seven percentage points. The Leader of the Opposition made a pathetic comment when he said that a change in the price level is not a change in inflation-that is, seven percentage points of price level just disappear from the inflation rate. Presumably it comes out of wages, but there is no way the Opposition would then have a wages policy in place to secure the discounts.

So the consumption tax will not change the savings balance because it cannot reduce marginal rates of tax. A consumption tax will only run down the Budget surplus and cannot change marginal rates of tax; therefore it cannot change the performance on savings but adds seven percentage points to inflation. As a panacea, that will do nothing to deal with the current account or competitiveness and will just make the place less competitive as seven percentage points of prices get built into inflation.

The shadow Minister has an objective of a zero tariff level by the year 2000, as I understand it. This comes from a member of a party which not only has never reduced tariffs but has always increased protection. The average level of protection increased during the seven years of the Fraser Government. This Labor Government has reduced protection levels. But we make decisions about whether we want industries. For instance, we want a car industry. We know that a car industry will not function at zero protection levels, but apparently those opposite believe that at a zero level of protection a car industry will remain viable. It will not. The Opposition is really saying it does not want a car industry.

If the Opposition wants to make those choices it has to think about how these tariff levels will impact on particular industries. That is why the Government's 33 per cent reduction in tariffs, phased down, gave industries a chance to adjust and why the car plan and the textiles, clothing and footwear plans have dealt with particular pockets of very high protection-which was, of course, introduced in the first place by those opposite. The Opposition's tariff policy will not do anything to rapidly improve the competitiveness of the economy; it will wipe some industries right out.

The totality of the Opposition's policy in this Parliament includes privatisation, which will do nothing for the current account, a consumption tax which will blow the inflation rate to pieces, and a tariff level which is a bit of ideology from a party which has never had the courage to reduce protection in the first place. In fact, it introduced the protection levels we now have. In other words, six months on and the Opposition has no policy structure to deal with two principal problems-the current account deficit and inflation. It has no wages policy and the business community is already crying for relief from the so-called anti-inflation strategy. It is now worrying about wage flexibility as it does not like enterprise bargaining.

Here we are six months on and the Opposition still has no economic policy-no policy on the current account and inflation and what passes as a policy on privatisation. Yet members of the Opposition come here and ask questions of the Government as though there were some virtue in their position. Their position would do nothing about the current account deficit and would make inflation worse.

QUESTION.PARA: When the Labor Party decided to mine Roxby Downs and let Ranger export, it decided not to have an anti-uranium policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand by the remarks I made whenever I am quoted as making them. That is not to say that there is no room for a supply policy. ANSWER.PARA: As honourable members may well know, there is a uranium review committee currently reviewing all aspects of the Labor Party's uranium policy. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. All members of this House will acknowledge the special importance of communications between our defence forces in the Persian Gulf and their families back home in Australia. I therefore note with concern references in the weekend press that mail sent from Australia to the Gulf force ships has been tampered with. Parcels have been opened and some, obviously including video and audio tapes, have been found empty. Will the Minister please inform the House what action has been taken specifically on this matter and generally to support the families of the crews of the ships deployed in the Gulf?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this question from the honourable member for Port Adelaide because it gives me an oppor- tunity to elaborate on the range of support activities which are being undertaken to assist the families of the crews currently in the Gulf. The Maritime Commander, the Command Services Personnel Office in Sydney, the commander of each ship and I personally have each written to the families of the personnel involved in the task force, conveying to them the range of support which is available to the families.

ANSWER.PARA: I also sent them a copy of the three speeches made by the leaders of the three major parties in this place, setting out the reasons for the deployment and conveying their support and the support of the overwhelming majority of Australians for the job our task force is doing there.

As well as that, the Command Services Office in Sydney is producing a fortnightly newsletter for issue to all the next of kin to keep them informed of the latest developments and social gatherings of the families are being organised. Also a 008 number has been established in Sydney to help with any queries and requests for assistance. All personnel services officers throughout Australia are in touch with the next of kin by telephone or, if that is not possible, by letter, to reinforce the message that help is available as needed.

Finally, the honourable member for Port Adelaide raised the matter of getting the mail through. Everybody in the Navy and indeed in Australia would understand the need to keep the mail flowing. As of late last week, a total of 47 mailbags had been dispatched to the task group, the majority of which reached the group though some 18 are still awaiting dispatch. There have been 18 bags dispatched from the task force.

I too noted with concern the reports that mail for personnel in ships deployed to the Gulf appears to have been tampered with and that parcels which appeared to contain video or audio tapes were opened and the contents missing. I should explain to the House that mail for personnel serving in the ships deployed in the Gulf is bagged and dispatched by the international mail section of Australia Post in Sydney. That is then carried by air to the Middle East by commercial means for forwarding to the Royal Australian Navy's task force. It is subject to customs clearance in those Middle East countries through which it must pass.

The House needs to understand that those countries have very strict regulations, particularly as regards the importation of pornographic material. As a consequence, some parcels in the mail dispatched to the ships from Australia appear to have been opened for inspection. As a result of that, the Navy is currently investigating other options for the delivery of mail to personnel and it is hoped that this will overcome those problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. Is the Minister aware that some of my younger constituents are getting STONED? Is it true that this phenomenon is spreading to other electorates throughout Australia? Will the Minister confirm or deny that his Department is involved? If so, will he provide the House with an explanation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to say that I am aware that many young constituents are getting STONED, as the honourable member for Chifley would describe it. For once, that can be considered to be a very good thing.

ANSWER.PARA: Many honourable members may not be fully aware that this phenomenon is occurring in many electorates throughout Australia. Yes, the Commonwealth has been very much involved. The more people in our community get STONED, the better off many of them will be. In this instance, the acronym STONED is the name of a board game that is designed to teach children and young people and their parents about the effects of drug misuse and abuse on their bodies. It means: Stimulants, Tranquillisers, Opiates, Nicotine and Education on Drugs.

Perhaps the reason why the honourable member for Chifley is so interested and involved in this program is that it was developed and designed at the Mount Druitt Hospital in his electorate. An evaluation of the game has shown that players have increased knowledge about drug and alcohol issues and that positive peer relationships have been established, leading to a healthier and more responsible lifestyle. It is certainly active in creating more lively discussion. It is a shame that honourable members opposite have embarked upon lively discussions while this question is being answered.

Alcohol abuse in our community is acknowledged by parents and by young people as the No. 1 issue of concern, as well it might be. About 21 per cent of all deaths in the Australian community are as a result of alcohol abuse. The heaviest drinking section of our population are those in the 15 to 34 age group. In fact, in that age group alcohol abuse accounts for 65 per cent of deaths. So, the more information that is put together, through campaigns such as the National Campaign against Drug Abuse, in cooperation and in conjunction with organisations such as the Mount Druitt Hospital in the honourable member's electorate, the better off and more aware we will be as a community.

The fact of the matter is that, in the Opposition's manic determination to sell these things, it does not see them as being of intrinsic value. —That is probably where I noticed it. The fact is that the Government will take a sensible approach to these things, and that is why it is not driven by dogma or ideology. I make the point again that privatisation will not matter a jot to the current account deficit in terms of the savings balance. While it can certainly improve the performance of the micro-economy, as I have said over and over again in the House, they are all slow burners when it comes to the current account and inflation. —Can the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services inform the House whether or not the Government is using the eligibility checking of pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) recipients by the Health Insurance Commission (HIC), announced in the Budget recently, to introduce a new Australia Card based on a centralised database with open and on-line access by government agencies to each other's information? Has the Privacy Commissioner been contacted concerning the privacy implications of changes to the PBS announced in the Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the question from the honourable member for Cowan and others who have raised this matter, on Friday and Saturday the Australian newspaper ran a number of what can only be described as sensationalised and misleading allegations concerning the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, prompted, I believe, primarily by Senator Boswell, the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: I issued a press release on this matter on Friday. The Health Insurance Commission also issued a statement. I can assure all members of the House that the Government is not building a single centralised database with open, on-line access by government agencies to one another's information. The Government is taking a series of measures to ensure that this does not happen. I wrote to the Privacy Commissioner on the night of the Budget outlining the Government's intentions, and I am seeking his close involvement with the implementation of the eligibility checking for the PBS. I hope to receive a response to that when he returns from overseas in a few days time.

If the article in the Australian were accurate and the HIC already had that power, there would be no need to contact the Privacy Commissioner, would there? The reporter, Tracey Aubin, and Senator Boswell suggest that regulations passed by both Houses last year have some kind of unconstrained powers buried in them that have escaped parliamentary scrutiny-powers that enable the HIC to do virtually anything it likes in building computer systems.

If that were the case, there would be no need to introduce legislative amendment, as the Government intends, because the HIC would already be able to do what it likes. Of course, it is not true, just as any suggestion that there is to be a new Australia Card is patently untrue as well. On Friday, Mr Wilcox, the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission, said:

There is no truth to the statement that the Commission is ready to call tenders for the computer equipment in a matter of weeks. No action will be taken by the Commission until there is clear legislative approval of the Government's Budget proposals.

Let us look at some of the claims and facts. The article in the Australian on Saturday, 15 September referred to regulation 105. I assume the author was referring to section 105 of the National Health Act which has been in force since 1953. Despite claims that the legislation was put through surreptitiously last year, the section that the reporter referred to was put through in 1953. I doubt that the reporter was even born at that time. I was only about 6 years old, and I think Senator Boswell was about 13 years old. So it is a little hard to stretch one's imagination that far. Any new regulations are, of course, subject to parliamentary scrutiny and disallowance motions can be moved, so the 1953 provision can hardly be said to be giving the Department of Community Services and Health, or the Health Insurance Commission as the body which administers the PBS, any unfettered powers.

In summary, parts of the eligibility package simply cannot be dealt with under the existing legislation, and the Government has decided that it wants the entire package included in the National Health Act after consultation with the Privacy Commissioner.

I make three basic points regarding privacy issues. Privacy issues are legitimately a matter of concern for all Australians, and that is why the Government is involving the Privacy Commissioner in these matters before any changes are made. That is also why discussion on these matters should be treated with accuracy and without scaremongering. I think that the best way to do that is to get the information straight. The author of the articles, Tracey Aubin of the Australian, did not contact my office before writing her first story. I went to her after she wrote it, and we have seen the result of that one. All I say in that regard is: why did she not call? As for Senator Boswell, the Leader of the National Party in the Senate, he is getting a reputation as a Sunbeam mixmaster-always mixing things up and beating them up.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Atkinson Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Acting Prime Minister to an article in the Australian Financial Review last week which stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Mr Keating's defeat on telecommunications . . . is a relatively minor setback to his overall objectives.

Does the Acting Prime Minister agree with that carefully briefed assessment? If so, can he explain why he attacked the Executive Director of the Business Council of Australia for suggesting that telecommunications was a distraction from the important macro-economic issues which the Acting Prime Minister is either unable or unwilling to tackle?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder who wrote this question out for the honourable member? Obviously he was flat out getting the message across the lobes to get that little bit of text down. I do not regard telecommunications as a distraction. Frankly, that comment from the Business Council of Australia, suggesting that that was so, was disgraceful. This is an area of economic activity that already is very important to the Australian economy, and will become more important as the years go by, particularly as information technology more substantially dominates activity in the world economy. This is especially so in an area where Australia has certain natural advantages, such as our position in the Asian-Pacific area and the fact that we are technologically competent in all aspects of telecommunications-technically, in marketing terms and in general strategic terms. Tackling telecommunications reform is an important part of the micro-economic agenda. It is very short-sighted for business to see it otherwise. I do not think business does see it otherwise.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason the Business Council of Australia was stung by any comments I or the Minister might have made about it is that it virtually had no position on the matter, by virtue of the fact that Telecom Australia was a member of the Business Council of Australia. I made the point then, and I will make it again, that the business community is always requiring of the Government that it reduce real wages, that it should hold wages down in a period of unprecedented demand, that in an area of the community which is allied to the Labor Party-that is, the trade union movement-we should exact from that sector and from those people concessions that go to their livelihood, their security and their future. Yet the Business Council of Australia could not see its way clear to nominate a position for itself and for business, virtually because it did not want to offend a constituent.

That does bring into stark relief the impotence of these organisations in dealing with major economic questions. I thought that the Council's absence from this debate had been a very notable one. I refer the honourable gentleman to a piece written by Michael Stutchbury in the Australian Financial Review last week, a very important piece of journalism. He said that the business constituency on inflation has disappeared, that once the heat was on, all the anti-inflation rhetoric dropped away. Now the Business Council of Australia is wandering around the portals of this building seeking further relief from interest rates and monetary policy, while six months ago it was talking about the virtues of an independent central bank.

The fact is that there is no staying power and no sense of strategy in these bodies. The same can be said about wages, and Michael Stutchbury made a similar telling point about wage flexibility. How much have we heard from business, particularly from the Business Council of Australia, about wage flexibility? Which business buckled first to the wage campaign of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)? It was Mayne Nickless, managed by Mr Webber, the former chairman of the Business Council's wage group, who was identified with the whole question of a new approach to wages and wage flexibility. What did he say? He said: `Well, we are in a cost-plus business. If there is no import competition for transport, and obviously you cannot bring a truck in carrying goods on the water, so we have no international competition and we will charge the domestic economy what the market will bear'. In other words: `There is no need for us to lift our game, improve our performance, lower our costs or resist wage claims.' This is an economy in which there has been a tight monetary policy and slowing economic activity, along with rising unemployment, and yet this industry gave in straight away to the ACTU's wage campaign. Remember that that statement came from the former leadership of the Business Council of Australia on wages policy.

So this makes a mockery of this whole point about wage flexibility. I have been telling this to the honourable member for Bennelong for years and he is still parroting his stuff. I do not disparage the notion that he is seeking but the only way to get wage flexibility is, basically, by breaking down the craft structure through award restructuring and by getting enterprise flexibility in the way in which the ACTU is trying to get it. Mr Stutchbury was quite correct in making this very salient point about the weakness of the business community in facing up to the whole question of wage flexibility and paying wage increases in a declining economy-not a booming economy where there are labour shortages, but where economic activity is declining.

The Business Council of Australia has proven several things in the last few weeks. Firstly, it is no longer there on anti-inflation strategy the moment the temperature starts to rise; on wage flexibility all that it trafficks in is theory; and its member companies are the first to yield to a campaign in a period of decelerating economic activity. Secondly, it regards telecommunications, an area of major reform in Australia, as a distraction.

The only thing I would say to my colleagues in the Opposition is that they would be able as a government, if they were to become a government, to rely upon the Business Council of Australia no more than we have been able to rely upon it. As usual, it will be up to the Government to do it all, as it usually is, in the areas of inflation, wages and telecommunications. That is the sad truth of it. There is just not the leadership on the business side in this country that we have seen on the labour side. That has not been a feature in the last 7 1/2 years. The last business leader in this country was the late Sir Keith Campbell who, unfortunately, departed this world within weeks of the Government coming to office. There has not been another business leader since then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Employment, Education and Training advise the House of any measures taken by the Government to improve the recognition of overseas professional qualifications so that the skills of migrants to Australia are fully utilised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was an earlier question relating to the recognition of qualifications within Australia, particularly within the school system. This question relates to a very important issue for this country-the recognition of skills of people coming to Australia seeking to advance their careers here by utilising particular qualifications. My colleague the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs last week released a report from the Centre for Multicultural Studies which pointed out the lack of success which many overseas-trained migrants had in obtaining suitable employment in Australia. It is a shocking situation where we have people who have skills, often in areas where there are shortages in Australia-indeed, their very selection to come to Australia is related to their skills and the shortages of those skills in Australia-and who find it very difficult, in some cases impossible, to obtain suitable employment in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: There are a number of things which need to be done and which are being done. It needs to be said in the first place, however, that once again we have the impediment of the federal system standing in our way. Many of the bodies which are responsible for providing the skill levels or the qualifications in particular professions are State based or, worse, are sometimes controlled by individual professions. Therefore, what the Federal Government can do is, of course, limited by the extent to which it can achieve cooperation with the States.

I am pleased to say, however, that some important steps have been taken with the States to try to ensure that there is reform of the recognition of overseas qualifications. We have also achieved the agreement with the appropriate bodies to move to new competency-based skills standards in a number of professions such as nursing, architecture, engineering, pharmacy, psychology and veterinary science, and there has been a substantial improvement in the information provided to intending settlers to Australia. We have also increased substantially from 180 to 500 the number of bridging places funded by the Commonwealth in order to assist those people who need to upgrade their qualifications for appropriate recognition in Australia to do so.

As well as that, last year we established the National Office of Overseas Skills Recognition which has an advisory committee chaired by Sir William Keys. That committee has been very active in examining these issues and making recommendations to us about how these matters should be pursued.

I want to say finally that there are some things that governments can do. There are some things that the professions-sometimes reluctantly-can be required to do. But in the end it also depends on employers taking a more enlightened view about the qualifications of these people who may come from non-English speaking backgrounds and who may have different cultures from those of the employers. It is important for those employers to recognise, whatever might be the cultural backgrounds of these new Australians and whatever might be universities or other institutions from which they have achieved their qualifications, that it is worth while for them to assess appropriately what the skills of those people are so that Australia does not miss out on effectively using the skills of all people.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) raised as a matter of privilege a letter which had been sent to him by a firm of solicitors, Dunhill Madden Butler. The honourable member quoted from certain paragraphs in the letter and stated that if he were to comply with the requests set out in the letter it would result in his being inhibited in the performance of his duties as a member of this House and as a representative of the Corio electorate.

INTERJECT.PARA: The letter about which the honourable member complains, among other matters, asks him not to distribute further a document which he had distributed to members of branches of the Australian Labor Party in Corio relating to the activities of the Farrow Group, or as it is often known, the Pyramid Group, and asks the honourable member to tell people to whom the document had already been distributed to put it to one side. The document also asks the honourable member to refrain from making such statements in the future.

The letter goes on to say that if the assurances sought are not forthcoming the writer will strongly advise his client to initiate legal proceedings against the honourable member for Corio. House of Representatives Practice states:

To attempt by any improper means to influence a Member in his or her conduct as a Member is a contempt. So too is any conduct having a tendency to impair a Member's independence in the future performance of his or her duty . . .
A United Kingdom House of Commons Committee of Privileges reporting in a somewhat similar case in 1947 had this to say:

Your Committee think that the true nature of the privilege involved in the present case can be stated as follows: It is a breach of privilege to take or threaten action which is not merely calculated to affect the Member's course of action in Parliament, but is of a kind against which it is absolutely necessary that Members should be protected if they are to discharge their duties as such independently and without fear of punishment or hope of reward.
Section 4 of the Australian Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 states:

Conduct (including the use of words) does not constitute an offence against a House unless it amounts, or is intended or likely to amount, to an improper interference with the free exercise by a House or committee of its authority or functions, or with the free performance by a member of the member's duties as a member.

The question to be determined therefore is whether the letter amounts to an improper interference with the free performance by the honourable member for Corio of his duties as a member. I can appreciate the honourable member's concerns in this matter. Whilst he acknowledges that the letter is written in a courteous manner, he feels that if he complies with the requests made he would be inhibited in the performance of his duties as a member.

The letter is certainly an attempt to influence him-it makes certain requests of him. The key question is whether it constitutes an attempt at improper influence. In considering this aspect, I believe the letter needs to be seen in light of the matters referred to in it: actions of the honourable member in writing to certain persons and distributing material concerning the Farrow Group.

Having carefully considered the material and the arguments that have been put before me in this particular matter, I believe this is a borderline case upon which the House would benefit from the advice of the Committee of Privileges. In these circumstances, I am prepared to allow precedence to a motion to refer the matter to the Committee of Privileges if the honourable member for Corio wishes to so move.
Motion (by Mr Scholes) agreed to:
That the matter of the letter of 6 September 1990 from Mr A. Elder of Dunhill Madden and Butler to the honourable member for Corio be referred to the Committee of Privileges.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to outline a coherent privatisation strategy for public enterprises, including the airlines, which has resulted in significant costs to the Australian economy.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In raising this matter of public importance today, I should first put on the record the fact that for the past five years the Opposition parties have had, as one of the cornerstones of their policy, the intention to move towards privatisation, to the tune of 100 per cent, of Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines Ltd. Today in the House we were given an example of why this particular matter of public public importance has been deemed to be so necessary. At this stage we have a situation in Australia where we are still none the wiser as to what exactly Government policy might be. We are still none the wiser as to just how relevant this Parliament is in being able to determine these matters of great moment. We are in a situation where it would seem that the Westminster system of government is under threat because of the line that has been taken by the Government and the union movement on the whole privatisation debate. We believe that the matter should be exposed as widely as possible in the general community of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for the Acting Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to stand up in the House today and say that this matter has been fermenting for quite some time-I suppose it is true that it has been fermenting for quite some time. Only five years ago, as we heard in Question Time, the Acting Prime Minister, as Treasurer, described privatisation as a Thatcherite vandalism splurge to try to destroy the authorities. In 1987, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself described privatisation as economic and social vandalism.

It is fairly incredible that the fermentation has been going on for some two years and we are still none the wiser, because two years ago at the 1988 Australian Labor Party (ALP) conference the Prime Minister went after that conference's support for changes on airline funding. The ALP in fact set up a special committee to investigate airline funding needs. That committee to this day is still to report. Of course, we learned as early as 11 July this year that the committee, which is headed by the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), still had not reported and that the Minister had been urged to resign because of his support for the Prime Minister. Mr George Campbell, the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union Secretary, argued that his resignation was due, saying that the committee had not met since June last year, that it wanted the issue off the agenda, and that only two out of the nine-member committee supported the changes to the current ALP policy.

We are told that the thing has been fermenting along. It has been a slow fermentation. In the area of fermentation there is usually a lot of froth and bubble and the end product is usually a giant hangover. The giant hangover is certainly there in terms of public policy in Australia. In terms of the financial situation of Qantas and Australian Airlines there is a giant hangover and the pain is there for the Australian people and Australian industry too. Lack of movement by the Government in this regard has maintained the situation of high international air fares, a failure to be able to fully compete effectively in the international market and the very real difficulties that are facing the government-owned airlines.

Exactly what has brought on this sudden rush? The Government's sudden rush of interest in the airlines privatisation issue was probably firmly put on the agenda on 14 June this year when the Chairman of Australian Airlines, Mr Ted Harris, argued that quasi-equity would not solve the airline's need for funds. He said:
The board takes the view that all it requires in terms of ownership is that we have owners who are responsible and who will enable the airline to compete on level ground.
He went on:
. . . we will not be able to do that in the future unless we have a proper injection of equity as we borrow more money.
He continued:
If the Government can't do that then it should move over and let somebody else do it.
Mr Harris said he did not understand the argument put by a section of the Labor Party that the airline must remain Government owned. He said:
I am not optimistic that quasi equity does overcome the problem. If it doesn't the Board will have to continue to press our case that some form of privatisation should take place.

Less than a month later, on 4 July, it was revealed that, due to a $700m cut in requested borrowings, Qantas was forced to cancel the orders for five Boeing 747-400 aircraft. At that time the Qantas Chief Executive, John Ward, said that if the Government continued to limit funding options then clearly future growth would be constrained. He said:
It is disturbing that a company that has been continually denied access to equity funds now finds that its access to debt funds is also being limited.

Qantas went on to introduce a scheme to axe 10 per cent of its senior management positions, with 60 employees forced to accept redundancy. But, because of the lack of any sort of flexibility in Qantas, to this day only 37 of those positions have been eliminated and Qantas faces a very serious problem indeed. What has happened to Qantas is a sad reflection on this Government's lack of action, failure to give Qantas its head and failure to move towards a responsible area of privatisation.

It is not without significance that of the 35 leading airlines in the world only six are now government owned. Two of those six are Qantas and Aeroflot. Aeroflot is now being split up ready for privatisation. It seems rather incongruous that here in Australia we have a national carrier that looks like going through much more trauma before the issue is fully resolved and that there is the prospect of a privatised Aeroflot before a privatised Qantas.

What is the situation with Qantas? It currently has a fleet of 42 aircraft and says it will need to expand to 80 aircraft by the year 2000 to maintain its present market share. This will require an ongoing capital investment program of more than $1 billion per year. Over the years Qantas, like Australian Airlines, has had difficulties with paid up capital. It is a reflection on both sides of the political fence that has happened. At present Qantas's total paid up capital is $149.4m. The real difficulty Qantas is facing is that its debt equity ratio is 78 : 22 this year. It requires $650m to produce more financially prudent debt equity ratios. Qantas is looking at a ratio of about 65 : 35 by June 1991, but the real truth is that if Qantas is going to become competitive with the major international carriers it requires $1.15 billion to reduce its debt equity ratio to the 55 : 45 level. That would allow the company to compete with some of its major competitors.

Qantas will need more money than that just for its ongoing expansion program. It is saying at the moment that its projected profits are being reduced by approximately $140m because of the higher debt equity ratio. As I said, Qantas went to the Loan Council this year-this was how serious the situation was-and sought $1,143m to get it out of its problem. This Government, which is so terribly concerned, as we heard today, with maintaining the standards of our airlines, gave it the princely sum of $477m. That shortfall is going to cause Qantas some very real concern indeed. There will be a run-down in its cash position. There has already been a deferral of new aircraft orders.

If Qantas goes on in the same mode throughout 1991-92 as it is going at present the impact will be even more severe because it will be cancelling future aircraft orders and it will not be able to compete with the international carriers that are coming through. Qantas, if it is going to maintain its present position as a leading world carrier, has to make some major changes, and it has to make them soon.

We have no indication from this Government that even on a 49 per cent equity basis we are going to get any real action for Qantas. We do not really know yet what the foreign ownership provisions will be. The present Chairman of Qantas, Mr Dix, has talked about introducing some foreign funding for Qantas. Yet we hear the Prime Minister say that as far as he is concerned he wants to see the majority shareholding remain in Australia. If we are talking about foreign funding we have to look at funding levels of up to 35 per cent to get real interest in Qantas.

Are we looking at a situation where we will have carriers such as British Airways, Japan Air Lines and Lufthansa investing in Qantas? Will Qantas be able to get into those international arrangements without interference as a result of next Monday's ALP national conference? Qantas has to do something like that. It has to get into such a position that it can compete with those international carriers. At the moment there are all sorts of alliances being undertaken around the world by major carriers to prepare themselves for the deregulation of the European market in 1992. They are going to take the deregulated American market head on.

One can give some interesting examples, such as comparing Qantas with the Scandinavian Airlines System (SAS). The Scandinavian Airlines System is very similar to ours. SAS operates from the northern end of the world. It is at the end of the run. Australia sits at the south at the end of the run. SAS is represented by three countries and they have roughly the same combined population as Australia. If we look at the ratio now, we see that the Scandinavian Airlines System has a fleet of about 120 aircraft and it is expanding. It has already moved into a cross-shareholding regime. SAS has gone in with Texas Air, which is part of Continental Airlines. It has a share arrangement with British Midland Airlines, Swissair, Austrian Airlines and Delta Airlines. It also has some marketing alliances with Thai Airways International, Aerolineas Argentinas, All Nippon Airways, Canadian Airlines International, Finnair and Lan Chile. All we have done in Australia is allow Qantas to go in on a 19 per cent holding of Air New Zealand. That is all very well and good and I guess that is a start. But basically all we have managed to let Qantas do is expand the capital base of Air New Zealand while its own is running down. That means that Qantas has some real problems.

There are some 39 foreign airlines operating into Australia. Of those 39 airlines, 26 are privatised carriers; 13 are fully government owned. Such luminaries that are government owned include Yugoslav Airlines, Olympic Airways, Air India, Air China, Garuda Indonesia, Merpati, Air Nauru, Air Niugini, Air Vanuatu, Cook Island International, Polynesian Airlines, and Solomon Islands Airways. There are no major carriers there, yet Qantas is expected to go out into the international market and bring business into Australia at competitive rates.

When we look at the real situation we should look at what is happening in the tourism industry at the moment. That is one that is always on the boil and one where airline reform is most urgently needed. We should look at the upturn from the Japanese market. We have been sitting here during the last week thumping our chests, saying how well we are doing in getting the Japanese tourists back. We have done well but we still have less than one per cent of the market.

The plain fact is that the prices of airline tickets between Japan and Australia are amongst the highest in the world. If one looks at real competition, one realises that the only reasons for our success in Japan are, first, that we have had some good promotion there and, secondly, that we are a new market and there is still quite a bit of interest in Australia. Despite the high air fares, the Japanese are coming here anyway. When we really do have to compete, the real area of competition will be Hawaii. The prices of airline tickets for roughly the same distance-between Tokyo and Hawaii-are about one-third of those being charged on the duopolist route between Japan and Australia. This is the sort of area that we have to get into.

Also, the equipment problems that are now facing Australian Airlines are equally critical. I was speaking to a board member of Australian Airlines the other day who was saying that there was just no cash there. We have already seen a situation where Australian Airlines is starting to send some of its aircraft overseas and is undertaking some major sales of aircraft to reduce its capacity so that it will be in a better financial situation to try to compete with Ansett and any other new carriers that might come in at the time of deregulation.

The Australian airline industry is facing a most critical time indeed. It has been facing a critical time for the last two or three years and yet we are still waiting until next Monday to ascertain exactly what will happen. The Acting Prime Minister (Mr Keating) comes into this House today and says that Cabinet has made its decision, but all one has to do is look at the weekend papers to see what has happened in terms of those special Australian Labor Party conferences. In the three major States, Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland, the special meetings at the weekend threw out completely the concept of the Government moving into the privatisation of the airlines or, indeed, any other instrumentalities.

This Government has a real problem in forcing the trade union movement to accept privatisation. From the Opposition side I think we must wish this Government well in its efforts, because if we do not and if some sort of privatisation does not come into play, then Qantas and Australian Airlines could well be in trouble. Privatisation to the tune of 100 per cent is the only way that we will be able to undertake that major micro-economic reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance states:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to outline a coherent privatisation strategy for public enterprises, including the airlines . . .

When someone raises such a matter we are entitled to expect that person to come into the chamber with a coherent privatisation strategy. In fact, Opposition members have not got a coherent privatisation strategy. What they have is a fire sale strategy, a strategy based on ideology rather than on the requirements of the economy overall or the requirements of the specific government business enterprises. It is the Government now and the Government alone which has a policy in the area of privatisation-a policy which matches the circumstances in which the particular enterprises find themselves, relates them to their current situation in the economy, and approaches the issue with less emphasis on ideology and more on overall performance.

What is the Opposition's position on this issue of privatisation? It is to sell Telecom Australia, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC), Aussat Pty Ltd, Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines and the Australian National Line. Its policy is to sell all the government business enterprises simultaneously. That means that something like $30 billion to $35 billion worth of assets will be dumped on the Australian market, and this is supposed to constitute a policy. The saving of these particular institutions is supposed to be some sort of contribution to the betterment of the Australian economy and a better performance by all. That is a load of nonsense. It is simply not possible to implement a privatisation strategy based on the Opposition's plans and regard it as anything other than a scandalous fire sale to the wealthy in this community and overseas of some assets that have been built up by the Australian taxpayers and by the operators of those operations over years and years. That sort of attitude is not new in connection with the views of governments that do not approach this from the point of view of the economic good overall or the benefit of the particular enterprise or the market in which it operates. However, this approach is in keeping with the traditions of those who come into this debate with the motive of ideology.

The most dramatic example of what happens when that approach is adopted is what transpired in the United Kingdom in the case of the partial privatisation of British Telecom. Like this Opposition, the British Government effectively mixed two problems. One was the problem of introducing competition in an area where competition is required; the other an ideological commitment to privatisation.

What occurred as a result of mixing the two? Firstly, there was no effective competition. It is only now, when they are contemplating the types of interconnect policies and the other things that are essential for effective competition in the telecommunications area, that competition is developing in Britain. The Australian Government is contemplating those issues now, at the beginning of the process, not at the end of it. As a result of the policies of the British Government, there was no competition in the area of telecommunications.

The British Government received #2.5 billion for the sale of 49 per cent of British Telecom. That amount represents probably one-fifth of the actual value of 49 per cent of that enterprise at that time. If honourable members opposite think that by dumping these enterprises on the Australian capital markets they will get full value for Qantas Airways Ltd, which is probably $2 billion or more, and full value for Australian Airlines, which is probably close to $1 billion, while at the same time trying to get $15 billion for Telecom and $5 billion for OTC Ltd, they are a bunch of maniacs. That is all there is to it. It is simply not conceivable that the Australian public will receive the return to which it is entitled if those government operations are sold down.

The Opposition approaches this matter on an ideological basis. It is interesting that the whole structure of political debate about government business enterprises has changed markedly in this country. For the bulk of the history of the institution of parliamentary democracy in Australia, it has been common ground between Government and Opposition that there should be a mixed economy, and that there is a role for the public sector in that mixed economy. That role is probably quite substantial in a developing country such as Australia, with the sorts of distances and small population sizes that prevail. There will always be a requirement for a healthy public sector. The question is always to get the balance right. That has been the common ground position between Government and Opposition over the years. We sought instead to concentrate debate on social welfare issues, the development of education policy, foreign affairs and defence issues, not on that fundamental issue.

That position has changed completely. The Labor Government is prepared to look constructively at the capital requirements of the various entities for which it is responsible. It is prepared to look at their management requirements, where they stand in the marketplace, what they require to be able to perform effectively in the marketplace, and, where there remains no justification for their position in the marketplace, to take them from it.

The Labor Government has not been inactive in this area. Since it has been in office, some $2 billion worth of government services have been taken out of the government sector and put onto a private contracting basis. When I confronted the requirement to devise a contract to construct frigates in this country, I coupled with that at that time-which was the right time-the issue of the privatisation of Williamstown Naval Dockyard. When the Commonwealth Bank absolutely required a capital injection, effectively in order for it to be able to grow and to continue to perform the essential stabilising role that it performs in the Australian banking sector, this Government put in place a capacity for the bank to sell down to the tune of 30 per cent.

The Government did not threaten these government entities or abandon them to the private sector to sink or swim on some ideological commitment. It made sensible decisions at a sensible pace, and it will continue to ensure that the Australian people receive full value for these enterprises. That is not the position of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on.

—The honourable member can sit there and guffaw away all he likes, but he is one of those responsible for these policy idiocies. The Opposition is going to have to live with that and we are going to pursue it on them. We are going to pursue it particularly in the telecommunications area, where it has sacrificed the essential issues of competition for a mindless ideological commitment to privatisation. What we are going to get from that, of course, is enormous public disturbance at the fact that their assets will be sold for a song to what will appear to be the wealthy friends of the Government-if those opposite get into government. If the Opposition ever gets that opportunity, it will be very much to its discredit were that to occur.

SPEECH.PARA: We are going through, within our Party processes, a sensible analysis of what might be done for these entities. It is not as though they have done badly under the regime that we have had in place to this point. Let me just produce a few figures for the Opposition on that. When we came into office Qantas had a fleet of some 24 aircraft. That was only seven years ago. It had had that level of aircraft for a very considerable period before that. It now has a fleet of 42. From being in a situation in 1983-84 where it was flying 24.8 billion seat kilometres, we now have in place a capacity in Qantas to fly 39.2 billion.

Qantas was making virtually nothing in the five years prior to our assuming office. Since then, it has been regularly providing dividends to the Government-a record dividend in 1988-89 and substantial dividend payments over the period as a whole. Let me compare. Between 1983-84 and 1988-89, dividends from Qantas totalled $132.7m; from 1975-76 to 1982-83, $6.2 million. Total shareholders funds as at 30 June 1989 were $916.5m compared with $244.4m for Qantas in 1983-84.

One sees a similar performance in the case of Australian. This year Australian has taken a hell of a knock, as one would expect, having been knocked out of the sky for effectively a third of the year by the pilots dispute. Prior to that Australian recorded an operating profit of $108m. That compares with the best year in the Opposition's term of office of $14m and an average performance of about $4m or $5m. That $108m was preceded by one of $66m, one before that of $42m, one before that of $37m, and one before that of $28m.

Under our management, these airlines have in fact done very well. What we are looking at in the context of selling down a proportion of Qantas, our national flag carrier, the carrier of our bilateral relations with a number of other countries in the aviation area, effectively is selling if not quite a monopolistic position then certainly a monopolistic Australian overseas involvement position, of which the Opposition would sell 100 per cent and of which we, in the positions we are putting forward and which we are suggesting to conference, would sell around 49 per cent. We are doing it not because of some ideological commitment to the issue of privatisation but because it seems in the interests of the airline that we should approach it in that way now. We approach the issue of Australian not because of some ideological commitment that Australian ought to be taken out of the public sector but because we think that there are other things that ought to be done in the public sector with injections of capital that would be capable of being implemented were Australian taken out of it.

That is our approach. We do in fact have a program associated with the steps-and there have been many since we have been in office-towards privatisation, towards more competitive markets, towards freeing up our public entities to act in a commercial manner. To their credit, they have returned to us tenfold what we put into them in giving them that freedom of action-the freedom of action they never had. One thing we have done to them is to increase the competitiveness of the markets in which they have operated, and they have responded to that very effectively. There were 23 international carriers flying to Australia when we took office. There are now 37. We have liberalised international freight and passenger charter policy, and freight charters have now more than doubled since 1987, and of course exponentially above what they were back in 1983-84.

We are the people who address these issues in government. Those opposite are the people who, when they are presented with these opportunities when they are in government, do nothing. Then, in paroxysms of guilt for their total failure to address from the conservative side the proper management of government affairs, they come in with this totally mindless policy in which they sell off everything lickety split. That is the major concern-not what is happening in the markets or what is happening in international aviation or the domestic aviation market, not what is happening in the markets with regards to telecommunications. That is all irrelevant! What we have is a major commitment to privatisation.

The people in this country can thank God that the Opposition never had an opportunity to implement its policies during the 1980s. Can anyone imagine where we would now be standing had the Opposition gone through with its fire sale privatisations during the course of the 1980s and who might now have been owning those airlines? Qantas-Skase Air and Australian-Bond Aviation are what we would have been looking at now.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition, apart from its mindlessness on this matter, has adopted a certain approach on all these sorts of issues. SPEECH.PARA: It is a tragedy for Australians that this debate should even take place, because this week we can see the Government for what it really is: it is governed by factions and beholden to outside vested interests. We are having the contrived arguments, the feigned indignation by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about public ownership versus private ownership. That serves only to illustrate his total hypocrisy and his cynicism towards the Australian people. The Government knows what has to be done about the airline situation, but refuses to do it-and why? They thought they were coming to the nirvana of free enterprise and capitalism. But they got a shock.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Jaruzelski of the Labor Party.

—The Minister even looks like Jaruzelski. Put a pair of dark glasses on him and he would be the spitting image of him. Members of the Polish delegation wanted to know how the Government was going to deal with privatisation in Australia. I told them that the Opposition had a policy on it. SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel should look at the graph. It shows-and I will show it to my colleagues as well- that Qantas has the highest debt equity ratio of any airline in the world. That is the problem that the Government should have addressed, but it has not addressed that matter. This airline is starving. If 100 per cent of this airline had been put up for sale three years ago, it would have been possible to get in the vicinity of $1.4 billion for it. Now, if 49 per cent of it is put up for sale, as the Government probably will propose, it might get $200m for it. The Government has run down the airline. We did not hear anything from the Minister about British Airways or the dramatic turnaround that privatisation visited upon that airline to the benefit not only of the employees-and do not forget the employees-but also of the taxpayers in the United Kingdom. I went to the United Kingdom and I talked to the Chairman of British Airways, Lord King of Wartnaby, and his Managing Director about the benefits of privatisation and what it can do for an airline if one has imaginative management and also if one lowers the debt requirements. We have put ourselves in a very uncompetitive situation because the Government wants to continue with its ideological position. It is not we who have the ideological position. We are taking the economically responsible path to dealing with the airlines' equity problems. We do not have the ideological hangups. We have set down the reasons why there should be privatisation, in common-as I keep on saying-with 83 other countries; there are socialist, communist and autocratic governments right around the world all agreeing that privatisation is an economic tool. It is not a panacea; it is an economic tool that must be embraced in order to mobilise community savings more effectively-and, again, the Acting Prime Minister and Treasurer acknowledged that fact in Question Time today-and to have better resource allocation so that we do not have to go back to the taxpayers and ask them to fund things that they should not be funding.

The role of government is to steer; it is not to man the oars. This Government has to remember that there is a great change taking place in this world. It is taking place in the heart of eastern Europe. People from eastern Europe come here to ask us how to do things. They do not come and ask the Government because it is living in the past. This conference on 24 September is about the ALP trying to hang onto the past. It does not have any vision of the future. It is taking us nowhere. Where is the Prime Minister? Events have conspired to take him out of the country this week. How ironic that he is away. The Acting Prime Minister had a chance in Question Time today to say exactly what he thought of the matter, to be a leader and a statesman, and he squibbed it. He squibs it every time the pressure is on. Woe betide this country if he ever becomes Prime Minister.

I now turn to the facts. It is all right to talk, but let us actually see the Opposition do something. The real reason is that for almost six months Australia's domestic aviation was sitting on the ground while Opposition members were encouraging the airline pilots in their fruitless dispute. Who is actually facing up to the fact that the airlines need equity partners and that in very recent times the world aviation industry and our domestic aviation industry are changing and changing rapidly? Who is actually facing up to the fact that the airlines have to have partners, have to share mutual facilities at different airports and have to be able to share computer systems and booking systems in order to be able to handle each other's passengers and baggage, cross selling and tourism and all those things? Who is facing up to the fact that the airlines need equity injections not only from the private capital market, but also from strategic exchanges with other airlines in order to promote their role in the global aviation industry? We are facing up to that issue.

Part of the way in which we are facing up to it is by holding a national conference of the Australian Labor Party in Canberra next week because the ALP at least recognises the fact that the decisions it made at the Hobart conference in 1988 cannot hold static and be binding on the Party, on the Government and on those who accept and follow ALP policies-and we were elected to put them in place-until 1991 when we have our next conference. Of course we cannot do that. So when there is a major shift in policy, brought about by rapidly changing world situations and circumstances, we have a national conference and we are accountable to our people and our policy-making structure.

I think that the Government is to be commended for that process of reference to its members. The Minister is right when he says that the Opposition has this crazy fixation with flogging off assets for the money. As the Minister pointed out, if one goes through the Opposition's shopping list for the fire sale, one sees that something like $40 billion worth of assets in today's terms is being offered. These assets, be they aircraft, airports, Telecom Australia, Aussat Pty Ltd, OTC Ltd or whatever, have been built up year by year by the investment of government or public funds, the retention of profits and by strategic operations in one form or another. It has not all been a massive injection of capital. But when one goes to sell them, one is, in fact, saying to the world and to the Australian capital markets, `Here it all is, let's have the money'.

What does the Opposition think the effect will be on interest rates in this country when it suddenly says to the market place, `Find $25, $30 or $40 billion for these assets'? The Opposition should not try to say we are not talking about this kind of money, because right at the heart of its policy is a commitment, in its first term of office, to sell Telecom. Telecom is the biggest single public institution in this country. It is valued conservatively at $25 billion. Where will we find $25 billion in this economy, if it is not borrowed capital from high fliers who are running around looking for somewhere to milk some profits? It is in the Opposition's policy to do that. That is not feasible, it is not responsible and it does nothing to help the stability and the comeback of the Australian economy.

I turn now to the decision the Government took to allow the Commonwealth Bank to buy the State Bank of Victoria and, in doing so, to raise an extra shareholding to pay for that by a 30 per cent sell down. That was not just a matter of the Government deciding to say to the Commonwealth Bank, `Slip down to the nearest stockbroker, stick it out there in the market and let us see how you go'. What the Government has decided to do is to explore some very strategic innovations in the Australian economy. The first thing that has been guaranteed for the first time in public enterprise in this country is that there will be a slice of that action for the employees; there will be an employee ownership package.

It is all very well for the honourable member for Bennelong to be given the credit as the first person in the House to raise this matter. I do not know whether the honourable member was. However, I can tell the House that lots of us in the trade union movement have been talking for decades about employee ownership. The Opposition might have only thought about it recently; it might have thought and spoken about it; but the Government is actually doing it, and that is the difference.

The second phase of the tendering for the Commonwealth Bank is that there will be a slice of the action for the superannuation funds, a slice of the action for ordinary people's savings-many people who never had the opportunity for superannuation at any time during the Opposition's 20 years in office since 1950 or whenever it was. Since the introduction by the Government of the two-tiered system, every worker now has superannuation. That money is going into superannuation schemes. The savings of ordinary workers are now going into superannuation schemes and the opportunity will now be available for them to be invested in profitable public enterprise. The Government is not just talking about it; it is doing something about it, and doing it in a coherent and structured way that, when all this is weighed up, takes our economy down the road of continuing as quite possibly the world's most successful mixed economy.
So I do not have any problems in explaining that to people. I shall certainly have no problems in defending it at election time, and I think that this matter is lacking in substance.

DEBATE.TITLE: CIVIL AVIATION AUTHORITY OFFICE AND WAREHOUSE, PERTH

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, I present the report relating to the following proposed work:

SPEECH.PARA: Construction of Perth Office and Warehouse complex for the Civil Aviation Authority.
Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Joint Committee of Public Works has concluded that there is a need for the construction of a Perth office and warehouse complex for the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). The proposed office building will have an area of 5,508 square metres on two levels and the area of the warehouse is proposed to be 1,120 square metres. The cost of $13.926m will be reduced by the sale of the CAA's warehouse site at Mount Claremont in Perth.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee heard evidence that the Western Australian field office of the CAA is presently located in expensive leased accommodation in the Perth central business district. The lease on this property expires in October 1991. The CAA accepted the report of a consultant who recommended the move from the leased accommodation to Perth Airport because leasing costs are high; CAA's major clients are at Perth Airport; and staff savings could be made by relocating the office staff. The CAA purchased a suitable block at Perth Airport in November 1988. The Committee supports the CAA's belief that it should be in a decentralised location close to its clients.

There are a few brief points I should like to make in connection with this report. First, the roof of the warehouse at Mount Claremont contains asbestos sheeting. Evidence was given that this is safe provided it is undisturbed. Should a new owner decide to demolish the building care will need to be taken to adhere to the appropriate West Australian code of practice for the removal of this material.

Second, the Committee was told that use of solar panels for heating water within the proposed buildings was not found to be practical commercially. It reiterates the point made during last week's tabling of the report into the Australian Taxation Office's dedicated computer centre: means of improving energy efficiency in new buildings will be kept under scrutiny by the Committee.

Third, the CAA's original proposal had included sale of its workshop at Mount Lawley. The combination of a National Trust classification on the main building, restrictions on construction on the block and uncertainty about the future of the CAA's workshops combined to remove this from the proposal. The Committee accepts this situation and, while not making a recommendation on the issue, endorses the principle of bringing all relevant CAA operations to Perth Airport.

Finally, there were concerns expressed about such things as public transport to the airport, banking and child-care facilities and the cost and availability of food in that part of the airport. The Committee notes that the CAA has been seeking to ensure these services are adequate for the staff at Perth Airport. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday evening I was referring to the introduction of the deeming provisions contained in the Budget as they affect age pensioners. SPEECH.PARA: I am surprised that there has been some concern expressed in the pensioner community about this, particularly about the amount of $2,000 excluded from the scheme. It is always better for pensioners to have that earning some interest because, without taking tax into account, they will always be 50c better off for each extra dollar that is earned in interest.

The other worthwhile feature of that scheme is that those who would otherwise not be eligible for the fringe benefits card will in fact preserve their rights. While dealing with deeming provisions, I should make one comment about an article that appeared in the Sunday Telegraph of 26 August headed `Pensioners to lose 83c in the dollar'. The article states:

TALK.START.PARA: —Scurrilous.
