SPEECH.PARA: However, it does illustrate the different approaches taken to this Budget by the media. Some sections of the media attempted to label the Budget a harsh Budget as it affected the needy. It is interesting that, on the other hand, the Opposition has consistently referred to the Budget as being far too soft.

I turn to the fourth group to which the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) directed his appeal in his speech, that is, youth. We certainly get out and talk to young people and we recognise and appreciate all that the Government has been able to achieve for them over the last seven years. There is wide recognition in the community, I am glad to say, that retention rates under this Government have almost doubled. Almost two-thirds of young Australians now enjoy a complete secondary education. Young people also appreciate the wider opportunities that are available in higher education, improvements in student assistance, and more opportunities through growth in the job market and more training opportunities, particularly through the Australian traineeship system. We are very pleased as a government to be able to note that unemployment has very rapidly disappeared as an option for those in the 16 to 18-year-old age group. It is a particularly hollow appeal coming from an Opposition which when in government presided over the highest level of youth unemployment in our country's history.

It will not take very long to refer to the so-called answers that the Leader of the Opposition promised at the beginning of his speech. He referred again to the Opposition's promise to abolish the unemployment benefit after a period of nine months. TALK.START.PARA: —A pretty cheap trick.
—Yes, it is. At the same time the Opposition promised to abolish a range of training programs which had been put in place to assist those people who are out of work.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, the Opposition's promises on tax reform remain unclear. The Leader of the Opposition also claimed that the Budget did nothing to boost national savings either in the public sector or indirectly. I suggest, in closing, that there is much more to being Leader of the Opposition than simply changing the place where he buys his shirts. This was the post-election Budget, the first Budget of the new Parliament, a great opportunity to take some far-sighted and correct decisions. We all know that the closer to elections, the more governments show a remarkable lack of desire to move in that direction. In fact, it was an opportunity to lead and an opportunity which was missed.

SPEECH.PARA: If this Budget had a set of objectives, they were best described by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on page two of his Budget Speech, in which he said:
This year inflation will fall further, the current account deficit will markedly improve and employment will pick up.

On the present record, to achieve any of these goals will be very difficult indeed and the Treasurer's undue optimism over recent years is surely good reason for our concern. In the Budget Speech of 1988-89 he said:
The Government's policies will secure for Australia an inflation rate of three to four per cent in 1990.
My word, he certainly was wrong then! In the same Budget Speech, he also said:
We are now well on our way back to prosperity.
Yet all the indices today are going in exactly the opposite direction. Who will forget his comments made in the previous year when he claimed that he had brought home the bacon?

The Government's lack of achievable goals, given the direction of the economy, has confirmed everyone's worst fears that the Hawke Government has no clear, long term view and no strategy to save the Australian economy from the recession which has been largely caused by its own policy failures. The Government's objectives, surely, should be threefold: firstly, to cut government spending even further; secondly, to reshape our taxation system; and, thirdly, to boost national savings. Regrettably, on all three counts it has failed in this Budget.

Government spending must be reduced as a means of controlling inflation. At least it must be comparable to that of our major trading partners. We must reform the taxation system if we are seriously to restore incentive and encourage productivity in the Australian work force. We must boost national savings if we want to reduce dependence on foreign investment and help to pay off our massive overseas debt.

The continued reliance on a tight monetary policy, which for at least the last two years has been the centre point of the Government's economic strategy, has clearly not achieved the results that this misguided Treasurer had hoped for it, unless, of course, those results were a massive rise in unemployment and a substantial increase in business failures.

What we have seen is the destruction of living standards for Australian families; record levels of personal bankruptcies-up a mere 11 per cent in the last financial year; small business failures at an unprecedented level since the days of the Great Depression; and the list goes on. Real earnings have fallen over four years, yet increased productivity under this Government's economic and industrial policies has failed to eventuate.

The vast majority of Australians and their families have clearly suffered as a result of the last eight Labor Budgets. Let us consider the following statistics, which make this point. In 1982-83, the current account deficit as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) was 3.9 per cent. In 1988-89, it was 5.5 per cent. In 1982-83, the small overdraft rate was 14 per cent, and for 1989-90, 22 per cent, although it is now slightly lower. In 1982-83, gross foreign debt was $35.9 billion; in 1989-90, $156 billion. In 1982-83, the weekly income required to support mortgage repayments was 19.2 per cent. In 1989-90, it had risen to 36 per cent. I note an editorial in the West Australian newspaper which said:

Mr Keating must be joking in asserting that `economic policy has worked and is working'. If the hardship that Australians have endured in the past year is a sign that economic policy is working then heaven help us when things really go bad.

It is a sad fact which should be clear to every member of this House that even before this Budget was drawn up-and certainly since it-economic realities have significantly changed to our detriment, and yet the Government imagines that, having hit the iceberg like the Titanic, we can remain afloat on other people's money indefinitely.

This Budget does nothing to address inflation. In the 1988-89 Budget Speech the Treasurer said that inflation would be down to 3 or 4 per cent. In fact, it is now over 7 per cent. The Budget contains nothing to prevent the large projected fall in business investment. While most parts of the economy now languish in recession, the Treasurer blithely claims that his policies are on track and are working. Working for whom? On which track? Where does the line take us?

How does the Treasurer anticipate this country's overcoming its foreign debt problems when the levels of business investment are falling? Yet we all remember that last year he claimed that they were, in fact, rising. We heard in Question Time today the Treasurer make a malicious attack on the Business Council of Australia (BCA). I quote from the information paper put out by the BCA at the time of the recent debt summit:
Over the 1980s there has been only a minor increase in the size of the capital stock relative to total production. This 'capital intensity' ratio has barely moved-from 2.8 in 1979 to 2.9 in 1989.
Despite the pick-up in investment in the last few years, Australia Pty Ltd has not been going through a massive re-equipment programme.
That is contrary, I might add, to what was claimed by the Treasurer last year. The paper continues:
The investment which has taken place over the last decade has not been sufficient to produce the surge in Australia's productive capacity required to trade our way out of our debt problem.

Not only that, the quality of our capital stock has deteriorated in terms of its capacity to service our foreign debt. Over the past decade we have invested relatively more in housing (from which we earn no income on world markets) than in business assets.

In part that deterioration in quality is due to biases introduced by the interaction of our tax system with inflation-reducing savings and distorting . . . investment in physical assets (towards housing and `paper shuffling' and away from productive assets).

Further with some notable exceptions (like tourism, mining and particular areas in manufacturing) our use of the funds also is under question. Such growth in the capital stock that has occurred over the last decade has tended to be concentrated in areas that tend primarily to serve the domestic market rather than those that compete internationally.

According to Budget Statement No. 2 of the 1989-90 Budget, the share of investment going into production of goods and services that compete in export markets or against imports has fallen over the past two years to below 50 per cent (after a rise between 1985 and 1987) and is still well below the early 1980s.

Many of the premises upon which the Budget is based are dodgy, to say the least. The Government has ignored the economic impact of the Middle East crisis. The Budget is predicated on an average inflation rate of 6.5 per cent, which in turn depends on the price of oil averaging $23 a barrel. The Government's accord mark 4 wages deal with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) would limit wage rises to 7 per cent. This is based on a predicated average inflation rate of 6.5 per cent, which in turn depends on the price of oil averaging $23 a barrel. In fact, it is already $31.78 a barrel. The Treasurer is indeed a supreme optimist if he imagines the problems of the Middle East will suddenly go away when clearly they may well be with us for much of this financial year.

But probably the most rubbery figures of all were those given by the Treasurer in regard to unemployment. Estimates from Dominguez Barry Samuel Montagu predict the labour market collapsing in the coming months as unemployment rises to a national peak of approximately 8 per cent. We will be back in the bad old days of 1982-83 which the Treasurer so likes to quote. In all those eight to nine years, where have we been? The Treasurer has done nothing more than complete the circle of our demise.

While Labor's reform agenda has been proved by this Budget to be non-existent, the coalition's policies are by contrast decisive and clear. We believe that an industrial relations reform package to deregulate Australia's labour markets is absolutely essential. We put forward that package in the last election, as we did the election before that. Yet the Government's moves in the area of labour market deregulation and reform have been pitifully slow, to say the least.

In the field of telecommunications reform we would introduce privatisation as the basis for greater competition in this key industry. Again the Labor Government is utterly divided within itself on the approach it should take to this most fundamental area of industrial reform. In transport reform, including the waterfront and coastal shipping, examples which stand out in lights have been ignored by the Government for a very long time. It costs more to ship from Tasmania to the mainland than to ship the same amount from Tasmania to Rotterdam. Trans-Tasman shipping costs are excessive and even small ports like Cairns carry massive overheads due to high labour costs which have lost for them trade with Papua New Guinea and the Pacific islands.

We have put forward a comprehensive package of privatisation measures-an area which the Government still seems incapable of addressing. We have talked about reform of the taxation system, including the adoption of a goods and services tax, the abolition of the wholesale sales tax and substantial cuts in personal income tax. We know that is what the Treasurer wants because it is what he told us about a few years ago at the time of the summit.

But such a radical change is not acceptable to this so-called non-conservative Labor Party which has demonstrated in the last few years that it is in fact the most conservative political force in Australia today at the very time when this nation needs change and some radical approaches to the fundamental problems before us.

The considerable falls in average disposable incomes have not been offset by a corresponding rise in productivity. This is because the Government, the captive of the trade union movement, has been incapable of tackling the important issue of industrial relations reform. From 1983-84 through to 1988-89 wages have declined by 5 per cent in real terms. Over the period 1985 to 1989 real incomes have fallen by 10 per cent. Yet regrettably we see no corresponding improvement in productivity.

The Opposition has a comprehensive policy of changes to the industrial relations system. This Government has done nothing to increase levels of productivity and therefore to increase our competitive edge in an increasingly competitive world despite the claims of the Treasurer year after year that his Budget would increase productivity and make Australia a more efficient trading nation. Australia has nominal wage growth far higher than that of our international trading competitors. One can only conclude that the reasons for that are the Government's attitude and policies and its total inability to stand up for what it knows to be right in the face of continual pressure from the ACTU.

As a result of all of this the accord mark 6 is nothing short of a disaster. It links wages to inflation and thus places a floor under inflation at the very time when the Treasurer, falsely, tells us in the Budget-and again will tell us, no doubt-that inflation is going to fall. It is time we asked the Treasurer a simple question: On the basis of your existing policy, how is inflation going to fall? Will it fall by having the entire work force out of work? That may well have an impact on inflation but what will it do to the aggregates of the Budget and anticipated expenditure?

We must reduce inflation to levels at least comparable with those of our trading partners; otherwise we cannot survive as a trading nation. Our lines of credit are drying up. We are no longer seen as the world's great source of investment. We are seen as a stupid people who have given up the real task of working our way out of our economic and social problems.

What have Labor's failed economic policies cost? The respected Nomura Research Institute predicts that while Australia's economic output will be 40 per cent larger by the year 2000, a mere 9 1/2 years away, the output of many of our neighbours will have grown by up to 160 per cent during the same period. By the year 2050 Asia less Japan will represent 60 per cent of the world's output. Australia presently occupies the position of the second largest economy after Japan in per capita terms, and third behind Japan and China in actual output terms, in the Asia-Pacific region. Nevertheless, the Nomura forecast is that during those few short years ahead Australia will slip to the fourth position in the regional order, overtaken by South Korea and even challenged by Taiwan and Indonesia.

When will this downward spiral stop? When will it be reversed? One can only conclude that it will evidently not stop under Labor's policies. It is not good enough to say that relative to past years Australia's performance may be marginally better. When we compare our performance, relative or not, to that of our major trading partners, the sad truth is that we are slipping further and further behind. It is time this Government told the Australian people the truth and time the Government itself faced up to those facts.

Of serious concern is the Institute's conclusion that the average Australian will be worth and produce less than half that of the average Japanese, less than the average Singaporean and equalling Hong Kong in net output. In other words, that tiny little land of Hong Kong, which has nothing but the potential of its people to sell, will in a few short years reach and surpass the total growth of Australia.

Did the Budget offer any prescription for improvements in Australia's international competitive standing? The answer is a very clear and unequivocal no. With nearly 20 per cent of export earnings required to service the debt we are approaching the recognised danger level of 25 per cent. According to the Business Council of Australia-that reviled institution that I referred to earlier-the debt is feeding on itself. Our service burdens are the third worst in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and our standing in foreign markets has, as I said, already suffered.

The joke in New York is that Donald Trump must be an Australian because his business, like so many of Australia's entrepreneurs, was based essentially on credit and the expectation of rising inflation to pay for it. What a poor commentary on our economy and our regulatory system of the past years under Labor. I quote again the BCA, which states:
The debt service is already equivalent to $250 per family per month. This burden on all of us is already biting through high interest rates, prices and mounting small business failures.

With favourable assumptions, simply stabilising our net foreign debt as a proportion of GDP may require shifting as much as 4 per cent of GDP into net export over the next five years. And the job will be harder if Australia's external environment worsens significantly.
The sad fact is that since the war Australia has never got anywhere near increasing its share of foreign trade by four per cent.

I turn briefly now to the question of social security changes. I would like to examine the changes to the unemployment benefit regime. During the election the coalition announced its proposal to limit unemployment benefits for a period of nine months. We believe that the indefinite receipt of unemployment benefits should never be seen as an adequate alternative to employment. Despite the comments from the Treasurer and from his Ministers that he is not going to be involved in a shabby auction with the Liberal Party, the Government has announced its own new look dole scheme. It has proposed that the current system be replaced by a Jobsearch allowance for those unemployed up to 12 months and a Newstart allowance thereafter.

With the Opposition having led the way on the reform of an outdated and inefficient unemployment benefits system, I must say that any move by the Government to change current practice must be seen as a step in the right direction. However, Labor's scheme involves little more than a name change and fails to set any new direction while our proposal was bold, responsible and would save a further $800m in a year. Labor's pathetic imitation only saves a mere $80m out of a total payment of unemployment benefits of about $4 billion per year which regrettably will probably rise in this Budget period.
