SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91 I wish to spend a few moments discussing the portfolio area which has a value to the country far greater than the relative percentage allocation in the Budget. I refer to outlays on foreign affairs and trade which amount to some $1,000m of Budget funds or 1.18 per cent of total 1990 outlays of $92,956m.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly at present Australia's domestic circumstances have precluded us from spending as much as we would wish in the foreign affairs arena which includes foreign aid, payment for salaries and the operating expenses of our departments overseas-this includes the Department of Trade-grants and contributions to international organisations and outlays on overseas property services provided by the Department of Administrative Services.

Like any good international citizen Australia would wish to be able to give the strongest possible help to those countries that are struggling to keep up with the West. Yet despite the present fiscal constraints the Hawke Government has budgeted for an increase in the 1990-91 outlays on foreign affairs of $117.8m. In real terms that is an increase of 1.1 per cent. The fact is that the Hawke Government has correctly recognised the importance of the strategic role that foreign affairs and trade would play in the important economic development of this country.

The Government has noted that our position on the edge of South East Asia and the Pacific Basin in conjunction with our excellent international reputation have opened up tremendous opportunities for Australia in the rapidly developing world market. Despite its relatively small budgetary allocations in the wider scheme of things the work of the Government in the area of foreign affairs and trade deserves recognition and certainly a good deal of attention.

Since it came to office in 1983 the Hawke Government recognised that fundamental changes were taking place in the relationships between nations. Although glasnost and its fall-out were still some years away other no less important developments were well on the way. Firstly, eastern Asia was beginning to awaken to the potential in the wake of the transport, communications and technology revolution. Traditionally post-war economic and national relationships were beginning to evaporate. Further, Britain had long since joined the European Economic Community and the old gentlemen's rules of trade were disappearing and Australia had been financially caught by the conservatives' obsession with the resources-led boom. To add insult to injury our old perennially safe export markets had fallen to pieces.

Labor correctly predicted that Australia had to play a new role in the changed circumstances. Internal discipline and restructuring needed to be fostered throughout our economy and externally we needed to establish our bona fides to the emerging nations in our neighbourhood.

Much has been said about the great work that the Hawke Government has done on the domestic front. Of course, not so much has been said about our very impressive economic record internationally. The truth is that under this Government Australia has been playing an active, prominent and highly constructive role in regional and world affairs. We have not only kept pace in the period of extraordinary fast moving and far-reaching change but have been one of the countries helping to set the international agenda.

Over the last 7 1/2 years Australia's external policy has been built on a basis of realistic interpretation of our goals and needs. In other words, through realistic assessments of both our national interest and our capacity to advance them for the Government our priorities have clearly existed in our objective of regional and global security, trade and economic policies and good international citizenship.

Indicative of the Government's understanding of the complementary roles of trade and diplomacy and foreign aid the amalgamation of the departments of foreign affairs and trade has been the catalyst for the success that has come Australia's way in recent years.

Under Labor the balance between defence policy, foreign affairs and trade policy and other external policy areas have been the subject of close and effective consultation between departments and ministries and clearly articulated ministerial statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —And committees.

—And committees, as the Minister at the table has suggested. Since 1983 the Hawke Government has been responsible for a number of major multilateral initiatives. Those have included the successful 1989 launch of the Asia-Pacific economic cooperation forum; our policy to bring to an end the Cambodian impasse; the 1986 establishment of the 14 member Cairns Group of Fair Agricultural Trading Nations; our 1989 initiative with France to protect for all time the fragile and unique Antarctic environment; Australia's leadership in the fight for a chemical weapons convention; and the proposal by our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the twentieth South Pacific Forum in July 1989 for a ban on driftnet fishing in our region.

SPEECH.PARA: All those initiatives are of major importance and they stand as testimony to the esteem in which our Government is held internationally. Obviously, time precludes me from going to some of the initiatives that I would like to refer to, such as drift net fishing, but I am sure that honourable members will be well aware of its effects on our fishing industry.

However, it would be remiss of me to move on without paying tribute to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) for his outstanding work in his search for a solution to the Cambodian problem. I hope that all honourable members join with me in congratulating the Minister on the high level of his work which has resulted in the development of a very promising situation. His breakthrough speaks volumes for both the calibre of Australian diplomacy and the strength of our international reputation, and, as I said, the terrific calibre and integrity of the Minister concerned. I believe that what is now occurring in Cambodia should make all Australians very proud.

I also take this opportunity to say a few words regarding the Cairns group and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) Uruguay Round. It is well known that the Government has worked vigorously to achieve an open and fairer world trade system, through the GATT Uruguay Round, for medium-sized trading nations like Australia. Fair and internationally agreed rules for trade are essential to our capacity to export.

The Government recognises that fair competition and access to world markets are crucial to complement our efforts to promote a more efficient domestic industry structure. The Hawke Government's 1986 Cairns group initiative has allowed for the establishment of a powerful third voice, along with the United States and the European Economic Community, in the Uruguay Round negotiations on agriculture.

At the present time Australia is working to ensure that our interests in other areas, including services, export of natural resources, manufacturing and intellectual property, are all addressed in this Round which is due to conclude in December this year. It is not an overstatement to say that Australia is widely recognised as one of the most constructive and active participants in all areas of the Round.

Under Labor, a host of bilateral initiatives and achievements have been recorded dealing with matters as diverse as trade and development, peace and disarmament, human rights, and global warming. One of the most important, both economically and strategically, was the December 1989 signing of the Timor Gap zone of cooperation agreement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and his Indonesian counterpart. This has cleared the way for a joint exploration of the highly prospective and long-contested area which could yield up to two billion barrels of oil or gas.

This is undoubtedly the most significant agreement and probably the most important development in bilateral relations since Indonesia gained its independence some 40 years ago. It concluded one of the busiest years in the history of Australian-Indonesian relations, a year characterised by sustained diplomacy and practical results, including the restoration of regular, high-level talks between the two countries, the framework for the resolution of longstanding difficulties concerning Indonesian fishermen intruding into Australian waters, and the establishment of the Australia-Indonesia Institute for further people-to-people contact.

Another landmark bilateral agreement has been the review of the operations of the closer economic relations agreement, which took place between Australia's former Minister for Trade Negotiations and his New Zealand counterpart in August 1988. This has allowed for continued improved access to markets across the Tasman in a wider range of primary, manufacturing and service industries.

Significantly, in its approach to foreign affairs the Hawke Government has taken the time to reinforce two of our strongest relationships outside New Zealand. This has involved the United States and Papua New Guinea. The Government ushered in a new, more genuinely post-colonial bilateral relationship with New Guinea with the conclusion of the joint declaration of principles in December 1987. The declaration has put in place a new and total framework for relations and the initiation of regular, high-level, wide-ranging consultations with Papua New Guinea at ministerial level.

In its dealings with the United States, particularly through ANZUS, Labor has stressed the point that a partnership exists, not the big brother-little brother relationship which was so eagerly pursued by the previous Government. Our new and equal partnership status has struck a responsive chord in the Americans who, through our now permanent ministerial trade talks, have been prepared to give ground on matters of dispute. A good example of this process at work existed at the October 1989 talks, where the Australian Minister for Trade Negotiations was able to double our access to the US steel market. Likewise, Australia has also succeeded in securing changes to the US draft farm and trade Bills, thus protecting our farming and commercial interests both in the US and in third country markets. In the general area of world citizenship, Australia has built up an excellent reputation as a country which stands behind its principles.

In the now hotly debated arena of environmental damage, Australia has shown itself to be in the forefront of those countries that are prepared to stand up and be counted. In March 1989 our Foreign Minister, on behalf of the Prime Minister, signed the historic declaration of the Hague on the protection of the atmosphere.

Australia further established its international credentials at the South Pacific Forum in July 1989 with the Prime Minister's announcement of a major Pacific based study of climate warming and its impact on sea levels. Likewise, in the area of peace and disarmament the Hawke Government has earned a reputation as a nation of principle. We have had a reputation as a vigorous and respected promoter of arms control at the United Nations, the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva, and elsewhere. We have created the full time position of Ambassador for Disarmament, vigorously opposed French nuclear testing in the Pacific, and played a key role in the creation of a nuclear free zone in the Pacific.

Australia has remained a strong proponent of the early conclusion of a comprehensive test ban treaty to ban all nuclear testing. We have proposed the establishment of a fully operational global seismic network to monitor such a ban and have upgraded Australia's seismic monitoring facilities accordingly.

Our last, but major, area of achievement which I believe I should refer to relates to the Government's efforts on behalf of human rights. Multilaterally, we have been active in the United Nations in the negotiation of new international instruments to cover the rights of the child, the rights of human rights defenders and the rights of migrant workers. In terms of bilateral human rights representations, Australia raises more individual cases than probably any other country in the world. In the 12 months to May 1989, for example, Australia raised more than 400 cases with 68 different countries, covering both the plight of particular individuals and situations of widespread and systematic abuse. That is a record of human rights support of which we can really be proud.

Since March 1983 foreign affairs has undergone a chameleon-like change under the direction of the Hawke Government. We now have an international policy which accurately reflects our three main priorities: our social concerns; our economic priorities; and our regard for fair play, social awareness and the rule of law.

It is impossible to escape the conclusion that, on the results being achieved at the present time, and which I have now presented to the House, our budgetary allocation to foreign affairs and trade is indeed money well spent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91, may I say that within the Australian community there is a sense of frustration and bitter disappointment with the Budget that was presented just a few short weeks ago by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I think it is fair to say that the Budget has been described as half a Budget, the Budget that you have when you are not having a Budget and when you are not having a depression. It has also been described as a `steady as you sink' Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The real result of the document that the Treasurer handed down those few weeks ago is a sense of frustration in the community. There is a sense of frustration that the Government has lost touch with what is happening out there in the real world. There is a feeling that the Government has lost touch with the little people of Australia and that, indeed, there is very little hope for them.

I am absolutely delighted to see the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) seated at the table today. I am sure that he is certainly aware of what is happening in our particular part of the world. The Minister and I share one of the fastest growing areas of Australia as part of our adjoining electorates. I refer in particular to Logan City.

Logan City is now the second biggest city in Queensland and the ninth biggest city in Australia. It has another distinction. Logan City has more than 4,800 small businesses scattered throughout its length and breadth, many of them in the Minister's electorate. In recent weeks in Logan City there have been scenes of very great tragedy as small business after small business have gone to the wall and more and more people have lost their jobs. The number of unemployed in the south side of Brisbane has increased by some 20 per cent. The failure rate in the small business area is usually between 10 and 15 per cent per annum, but in Logan City it has now reached 27 per cent.

These are not fly-by-night businesses. They are established businesses, some of which have been in existence for more than 20 years. Because of the Government's tough monetary policy they are now facing extinction. It is a tragedy that at the moment we are seeing Australia's biggest sector of employers-small business-facing unbelievable hardships in the name of Government monetary policy and in the interests of trying to get the banks back onto the straight and narrow.

One of the real tragedies of the large corporate collapses in Australia is that it is now the small business community that would appear to be picking up the tab. I am horrified by the number of small businesses in Logan City which have been forced to the wall by banks claiming really quite small amounts of money to keep their ships afloat, with very little regard for what is happening there and what is happening for the employment prospects of those people.

I believe that the Budget was deficient in several aspects. In this House today the Opposition has been able to expose some of those deficiencies. I have no doubt that the Treasurer, in fact, was looking towards a major privatisation program as part of his Budget strategy to try to get things back on the ropes. Perhaps we will not see the full effect of this year's Budget until after next Monday's meeting of the Australian Labor Party federal body at which the future of privatisation in Australia will be discussed. In so many areas we must act quickly and sensibly. The time has come to get rid of some of those ideological hang-ups and to get out there into the real world and make things happen for Australia.

It is my responsibility to look after my shadow portfolio areas of tourism and aviation in relation to the 1990-91 Budget. There is no worse reflection on the attitude of the Government towards Australian industry than that which we saw during the presentation of the Budget. In his Budget speech to the House, the Treasurer said not one word about tourism. There was very little said in terms of aviation. Yet, these are two of the most vital industries in Australia today.

I do not make those statements lightly. The plain fact is that tourism is now this country's biggest export earner. Last year tourism earned $6.1 billion for Australia. It is Australia's biggest private sector employer, with more than 500,000 people employed in the tourism and hospitality industry. There was not a word about that particular industry in the Budget. In fact, one had to plough through the Budget Papers to learn that the total allocation of funds of the Federal Government to the tourist industry this year was $40m.

A major campaign was recently conducted by industry groups, including one that was headed by a former Minister, who said that the Government should be heading towards $100m as the budget for promoting Australian tourism overseas to help in the recovery program. In actual fact, the allocation that was given this year is exactly the same as was given for the past two years. That takes into account the fact that special allocations were made last year to try to help in the recovery of the Australian tourist industry after the disastrous airline dispute.

I must say that $40m is a small sum. I say also that it is about time the Government, during its two remaining years in office, looked towards restructuring the tourism industry. If we consider the total allocation by the Government to the tourist industry, I think it will be obvious that there is very little commitment to that restructuring. I refer in particular to the departure tax that is imposed on every traveller who leaves Australia to go overseas, whether they be Australian nationals or international visitors. In 1978, when the House of Representatives Select Committee on Tourism recommended the introduction of the departure tax to help fund the promotion of Australian tourism overseas, there was a great hue and cry from the industry, but when it was all boiled down, the industry decided that it was not a bad idea. Last year the departure tax in Australia reaped for the Government $38m. The total allocation to the Australian Tourist Commission last year was $40m. I suppose it is drawing a long bow, but one could almost come to the conclusion that the commitment of this Government to tourism in a personal sense was $2m.

There is no doubt that this year the Australian Tourist Commission will have a very tight time indeed maintaining its promotional efforts overseas. Anyone who comes into this place and says that the tourist industry is still not feeling the full effects of last year's airline dispute really does not know what he or she is talking about.

I concede that in terms of the numbers of international visitors from places such as Japan and other areas of Asia, there has been quite a substantial increase. But the fact is that the business from North America that was so vital to Australia is down. The business from Europe is down. In fact, we are finding it very difficult indeed to attract Australians to travel in their own country.

If one looks at the current figures, really the only State that has had any sort of major recovery has been Tasmania. The big losers in terms of the domestic tourism market have been north Queensland, the centre of Australia, and very much Western Australia. I am delighted to see the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) in the House today because I know that his electorate covers so much of that area of north-western Australia which is really feeling the pinch of what has happened in the last 12 months. In the town of Broome, the four major tourism resorts there are now all in liquidation because the tourists are just not going there. In fact, only one resort is managing to keep its head above water, and then only because of very substantial cash reserves.

So, the Government has a very real job to make sure that the promotion of Australian tourism does get under way once again. Last week the Minister for Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) announced the second phase of the domestic tourism recovery program. The total sum that was allocated to that domestic tourism recovery program was $50,000. To its credit, last year the Government provided $11m for the revitalisation of tourism. After some very funny things that went on in terms of awarding a contract to an advertising agency, a major campaign headed by Johnny Farnham burst forth on the television screens of Australia. That $11m worth of advertising resulted in a take-up of 11,000 phone-in inquiries. A response of 11,000 inquiries at a cost of $11m would have to make this the most expensive advertising campaign in the history of Australia.

That is not to say that the principle of the domestic advertising campaign was not right. We needed that campaign to try to get people to travel again. As well, other factors came into play. The advertising campaign was not all that it could have been, but there needs to be a greater confidence in the Australian community about travelling again, especially in light of what happened with the airline pilots dispute. We still have a very great way to go indeed before we get Australians travelling around the country again.

Can I say though that there is one thing on the horizon that does give us some hope, and that is the introduction of the deregulation processes into the domestic airline scene come 1 November this year. Many people in the tourist industry are putting a great deal of faith in what is going to happen there. I too rather hope that we will see a major expansion of domestic tourism following the introduction of deregulation. We have certainly got a long way to go.

It never ceases to amaze me that only 8 1/2 per cent of Australians use our domestic airlines system; that only 16 per cent of Australians have ever been on an aeroplane. The principal reason for this is that it costs too much. Now there is an opportunity for people to travel and we would hope that, in the competition that follows from deregulation on 1 November, there will be more value going back into that market. What gives me hope is what has happened in the United States of America. In 1978, when deregulation was first introduced, only 20 per cent of Americans actually used the airlines system there. The figure in 1988 had risen to 68 per cent.

In Australia there is a huge potential market out there waiting to be tapped, a market of people who could be described as `have-not'-have not had the opportunity to be able to travel on Australia's airlines, have not had the money to be able to afford to travel on Australian airlines. I guess in the newspapers at the moment we are seeing the introduction of what may happen once deregulation comes in, with fare discounts of up to 50 per cent and with the opportunity of travelling at all hours of the day and night at discounted rates. We hope for the sake of tourism that that will help.

It was interesting that the Industries Assistance Commission report on travel and tourism cited a couple of things that were major inhibitors to the growth of tourism in Australia. Those two things were the high cost for international visitors coming to Australia and the high cost of getting around Australia once they had arrived. There was another factor and that was the lack of seats on certain routes at certain times of the year. I guess the Government has got half of it right: that when we enter into deregulation it is going to be cheaper for people to travel around Australia once deregulation comes in.

Can I also say that, in terms of the promotion overseas of Australia by the Australian Tourist Commission, I think most of us were terribly disappointed when we learned that the principal amount of money would have to be put into the Japanese market and that funding would be withdrawn from North America and from Europe in particular. The Japanese market really is quite incredible in the contribution it makes to Australian society, and I am certainly not one of those people who would ever make any criticism of the fact that we are pinpointing that particular market.

There are several interesting things about the Japanese. Last year 349,500 Japanese visited Australia, and that figure is rising all the time. They stay in Australia for nine nights. Some 83 per cent of them are pure tourists inasmuch as they use our infrastructure. The interesting thing is the amount of money that they spend: in Queensland, upwards of $227 per head per day. They are our biggest spenders, but the point is that the tourism market is a very fickle market. We have to be very careful indeed that, if we find that there is too much criticism of the Japanese tourist market, we could well have a situation whereby some of those operators that are in Japan at the moment might look elsewhere to escape the criticism of sending so many people here. It is not wise to put all of our eggs into the one market; we should be looking at spreading our promotional efforts. I guess that on $40m that is very difficult indeed.

I would urge the Minister for Tourism to have a look at what he can do in terms of restructuring the funding arrangements for the Australian Tourist Commission. I think he should look seriously at what happens with the departure tax. He should look seriously at an integrated program from the industry itself to make even greater contributions than it does already to the promotion of Australia overseas. At the moment about 20 or 24 per cent of the total funds that are spent overseas promoting Australia come in one sense or another from the industry itself. Maybe over this next decade we have to look more and more to the industry taking over that marketing effort. But something has to be done because we just cannot afford to let the efforts made so far in building Australia as a major tourism destination fall by the wayside.

One thing that was not evident in the Budget Papers was what exactly was going to happen in terms of international aviation. I mentioned a little earlier in my speech the situation that existed in privatisation or lack of it, inasmuch as the debate is going on towards next Monday with no-one really knowing what is going to happen in that respect. In a speech earlier today I mentioned some of the disadvantages that Qantas had by not being able to compete in some of those markets because of its present structuring. It worries me when we see the state that Qantas has itself in at the moment, and I think everyone should be concerned with what is happening.

We mentioned earlier the amount of funding that Qantas needed to get back on the rails again. What we failed to mention was the fact that Qantas, even though it is operating reasonably full aircraft at the moment, is coming closer and closer to catastrophe. For example, at the moment on the Kangaroo route between Australia and London, Qantas has to operate at a 78 per cent load capacity to be able to break even. So every aircraft that operates between Australia and London has to have 78 per cent of its seats taken by paying passengers just to break even.

The most profitable route for Qantas in recent years has been the Japan-Australia run. What is happening there? Twelve months ago Qantas needed to sell only 55 per cent of its seats on those planes to make a profit. Already in the last 12 months this has blown out to 66 per cent. It must be a real concern for Australian tourism because while we have figures like that emerging all the time Qantas has no prospect of being able to get into a competitive mode to compete with what is happening with the megacarriers. Indeed, on many of the routes coming into Australia the megacarriers will be knocking Qantas out of that run more and more because they do have the flexibility and the financial clout to be able to provide that real competition.

Once again, I would urge the Government to move towards a total privatisation of Qantas as soon as it possibly can, otherwise we may be in trouble. What worries me is that, within that same Industries Assistance Commission report, it was urging the freeing up of Qantas because it thought that if the market was open to competition we would probably see a 25 to 27 per cent reduction in the price of international air fares coming into Australia. So that has to happen.

While the IAC report contained a sense of urgency in terms of loosening up the Australian market, really the Government has done very little to do it and, in actual fact, there seems to be an attitude abroad now in certain sections of the Department of Shipping and Aviation Support and, indeed, Qantas that we should put up the shutters again and try to provide a more and more protectionist policy for Qantas so that it can exist in the short term. That is not the way to run our airline and that is not the way to run Australian tourism.

What we must have now is a vital international air regime that will allow people to come into Australia as cheaply and as efficiently as possible. We have to do that because, if for no other reason, in tourism we have the only industry in Australia that has the capacity to provide long term employment for our young people. I have quoted this figure many times in the House before and I will quote it again. It is the figure that was given by the old Bureau of Industry Economics some years ago now as to the effect on employment of international tourism to Australia. The figures that are worth repeating over and over again are simply these: that every time we have a net increase of 25,000 in the number of international visitors coming into our country we create another 1,400 jobs-particularly jobs in the skilled and semi-skilled area and particularly jobs for females. We have to get that employment there because the fact is that there is no other industry in Australia that has that sort of potential to provide mass employment. We must make sure that there are no inhibiting factors in terms of artificial barriers for international visitors coming here and, indeed, that there are no artificial inhibitors in letting Australians see their own country.

I repeat once again: tourism is our biggest export earner, our biggest earner of hard currency, our biggest private sector employer, and yet in these Budget Papers the Government has done nothing in a real sense to try to increase the numbers that are coming in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1), I want to range over quite a few issues. As Mark Antony once observed, the good that men do is oft interred with their bones, but the evil lives after them. It is the evil which I will be paying attention to.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the greatest problem in this country-and it is one which is not recognised generally, certainly not by many politicians-is that we have a growing dichotomy between city and country people. We as a nation are growing apart, and I am afraid that this Budget, if anything, makes that position worse. I will get to that in a minute. If this problem is not tackled, it is going to destroy this country far more surely than the current account deficit or any of those problems that are put forward here.

I guess there are a number of historical reasons for that dichotomy, although it is true to say that Australia has always been the most urban country in the world, even 100 years ago. But there was a fellow feeling in those days between city and country, a feeling that each depended on the other. That has gone and has largely been replaced by massive ignorance. I do not believe that in the cities of Australia we find any animosity towards the rural sector or the country in general; it is simply ignorance. The city people do not understand what is happening and do not realise that most of the jobs provided in the cities are actually the product of the wealth that comes from the hinterland of Australia. I might add that the hinterland has not done a good job in selling that idea.

We talk a lot about being the clever country. I guess it is a noble objective and one we would all like to see achieved, but it seems to me that there is clearly an inequity in the availability of education. If one lives in Sydney or any of the towns scattered around the eastern seaboard of Australia, one can be the richest person in the world and one's kid can walk down the street to high school virtually for no charge; it is virtually free education. If one happens to live in remote Australia-in western New South Wales, or most places through my electorate-one cannot do that. In many cases, a very high cost is involved in sending one's kids to school. I contend that, in the name of equity, it does not matter how rich we are, we should have that ability to send our kids to school at a reasonable, comparative cost, and that ability is just not there.

This problem was partially tackled by the Whitlam Government when it introduced the non-means tested section of the isolated children's allowance. The allowance was raised in 1984 and again in this Budget, from $900 to $1,500. In real terms, the allowance should probably have been raised to $2,700 to restore it to its 1984 value. I think this would have been money very well spent. Quite clearly, if we are talking about the clever country, at the moment we are saying, `Ah, clever, except in the country areas'. I contend that the country areas need that education as much as anywhere in Australia. I will continue to push for a greater recognition of this need.

The problem is compounded by lowering the means test level at which country people are cut off. The figures are quite ridiculous, because it does not take much of an asset to exceed the value of the means test. If that asset is non-performing and cannot be sold, it seems to me that people are, once again, in double jeopardy. I was very disappointed to see that in the Budget and will be working to make sure that we get a more equitable and rational position in this regard.

Turning to the economy, I think that the current account is probably our greatest problem. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) had a lot to say on tourism, which is a subject that he certainly knows well. I think that we put far too much store by tourism. It is touted around that tourism is worth $6.1 billion as an export earner. But that is a gross figure, not a net figure. From that we have to deduct all the costs involved in achieving that earning, and those costs are considerable-far more, I would contend, than in many other areas. When we say that it is the biggest export earner, we only achieve that result through a division of the mining industry. If all the mining products in Australia were added together, the net figure would come to considerably more than $6.1 billion.

It seems, therefore, that the way out of the woods for Australia in its financial plight is to do better that which we already do well, and I believe that we have to look very much to this. We are a great country when it comes to mining and rural produce. We have to continue to do those things well and to downstream process our raw materials. If we were to take mineral sands, of which Australia is overwhelmingly the world's biggest supplier, to the first stage of processing, its value would be increased some 10 times; yet every attempt we make to downstream process mineral sands is fraught with all sorts of objections from environmental groups and even government departments, many of whom are becoming imbued with the sort of mentality that seems to pervade the new class that runs the environmental groups in Australia.

This area of downstream processing has to be considered very seriously. Although we earn $6.1 billion through tourism, the timber industry saves this country something like $10 billion a year in export replacement. If we did not have the timber industry, we would be importing that much extra. If the industry were allowed to flourish and develop as it should, we could increase that saving considerably. We import $2 billion worth of timber product, and that could easily be produced in Australia or exports could offset any import that does occur.

I was impressed by the demonstration of the timber industry that took place around Parliament House recently. I pay tribute to the truck drivers and workers in the timber industry who came up here and had the perseverance to stay around for a week. I believe that it was through their efforts that some degree of success was obtained, and not through the efforts of the high fliers in the industry. I was rather appalled on Friday to find that many of those workers were not informed about or thanked by their leadership for what had been achieved through their efforts. I certainly hope that the timber industry remedies that in future because it owes a great deal to those people.

One of the beneficiaries of the achievements of that demonstration will be Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd, who exports woodchips from Australia. I have nothing against exporting woodchips, but I would rather see us exporting pulp and, still better, making paper. I find it rather disturbing that a company like North Broken Hill Holdings Ltd, which has made its best endeavours to establish the industry in Victoria, should find that it cannot get access to the Harris-Daishowa facilities it uses to export woodchips. This Government could and should lean on Harris-Daishowa to make those facilities available. Harris-Daishowa is not and has no intention of going into paper manufacturing in this country. If we exist forever, we will never see Harris-Daishowa making paper here. On the other hand, the intention of North Broken Hill is clearly to make paper, and every effort, pressure and threat ought to be brought to bear on Harris-Daishowa to make it more amenable and willing to work with other people in the industry for the benefit of Australia.

The rural sector has been a great supporter of Australia. It is true to say that our prosperity was built on the rural sector, of which wool has been a very big component. Wool is in tough times, and I feel that in Australia we now have to support the industry and not back away from it. Some nerve is going to be required, because I believe that it is going to be a long haul to turn around the lack of buying that is occurring at the moment. I believe that governments should be prepared to underwrite and provide support for the wool industry off the Budget.

It is difficult to sustain a wool stockpile when one is paying interest. However, if the Government owned the wool, it would be much easier to sustain that stockpile, especially by the use of on-farm storage whereby storage costs would be zero, or very close to it. I do not see any tangible difference between a government owning bars of gold and owning bales of wool. I would be supportive of any initiative to provide Budget support for the wool industry. That would be in Australia's long-term interest. Nothing could supply the world with a clearer sign of our determination to support the wool industry, which is a great national industry. I believe that faith in that industry would be well and truly repaid.

Other things must be done. Marketing should be carefully examined. It grieves me that during the wool crisis in about 1971 the talk was that Australia should sell its wool on the North American market. It was pointed out that at that time the United States of America was the biggest per capita consumer of fibre and the lowest per capita consumer of wool. In 1990, the same statistics apply: the United States of America is still the highest per capita consumer of fibre and the lowest per capita consumer of wool. Obviously we have not marketed well in that country. We should also be supporting the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) in its endeavours to find new uses for wool and new techniques for wool. Some of these things are being done. Every dollar spent on that type of research is well spent, and funding in that area should be increased.

Australia is smitten with privatisation; it is one of the new buzzwords, along with micro-economic reform. I am cynically amused by the enthusiasm that has developed in this regard. I should say a few words about Telecom. We are told how vital communications will be in the future. Nobody disputes that; clearly communication will be of great importance. But there is not one organisation in Australia that can say honestly that its business has been impeded in any way by Telecom. Any business that alleges that has occurred is talking nonsense; any person who says that is probably a befuddled academic who has never had to operate in the market-place. However, many businesses can say that their operations have been enhanced by Telecom, particularly if those businesses are in the more remote areas.

I believe that Telecom, which is generally conceded to have provided a world class service, has been able to give that service under the existing regime and could have continued to do so. After all, reductions in prices for telecommunications have little to do with competition but more to do with technological innovation and government demand. Telecom was quite capable of providing the services that this country needed. This debate has raised the subject to an unnecessary level and deflected us from more important issues.

If we are serious about micro-economic reform, we should be looking at something like lack of the English language in the workplace, which costs this country in excess of $3 billion every year. It adds to the incidence of industrial accidents and reduces safety in the workplace. Those problems could be easily cured if we were prepared to tackle migration and the education system. We fail to tackle this problem; we talk about it but skirt around it. The level of standard English in this country will probably continue to slip, as it has done in recent years. That will be a tragedy for Australia and at great cost to our economy.

The other matter I raise is the effect of pressure groups on the economy. Those pressure groups take all kinds of guises. I was appalled to learn today that only about $3.5m is available for grants for industry research and development funding for new materials research. That is an area in which Australia does have some advantage and experience and could do quite well. Yet funding for that research is a mere $3.5m. On the other hand, I noted that in the forward estimates for the Budget about $106m has been allocated for the War Crimes Tribunal, with $18m of that amount for this year. I do not expect all of that funding will be expended. After the first half dozen cases have been run and it is found that it is not possible to get a conviction-and I think the chances of getting convictions are virtually zero-that Tribunal will probably be abandoned. The discrepancies in these type of fundings are an indictment of our values.

I supported the War Crimes Tribunal legislation because, as was the case with many members of parliament, it was not of direct concern to me at the time, and the pressure of work is such that sometimes one does not notice legislation that slips through. Having looked at the legislation retrospectively, I am appalled by it. I do not know why we ventured down this road or what the Tribunal can do for Australia. I do not understand what it will do for our system of justice. If any person in Australia today who was guilty of a war crime has not suffered enough agony and turmoil in themselves, nothing we can do to them will make any difference. But this legislation will impose an enormous burden or slur on their children, something that the children probably do not deserve.

Given the passing of time, memories fade and become distorted. It will be virtually impossible to get coherent and accurate evidence. I hope that this legislation can be reviewed, although I do not expect that there will be any convictions under it, certainly none that will stand up to appeals. When that happens the whole thing will be quietly dropped. Certainly that will be a saving for the Budget.

One thing that bothers me is the lack of flexibility. People with great ideas in industry have nowhere to take them. It is difficult to do anything because of the interest rates that operate in the market today. Other countries have all sorts of mechanisms in place to assist industries. Recently the Italian economy has overtaken the British economy because of the close cooperation between government and industry. Australia tends to be going the other way, for a variety of reasons. That is a mistake that I hope can be redressed before it is too late.

The Commonwealth Development Bank is supposed to function to help Australian industry, without necessarily regard to security. It is supposed to back Australians with good ideas. It no longer does that. In any event, if one wants to borrow more than $1m it is difficult to do it from the Commonwealth Development Bank and these days $1m does not go a long way. On the other hand, the Australian Industry Development Corporation is reluctant to lend less than $10m. It is difficult to get money from that source. I would like to think that both of those organisations will be massively refinanced and told to get on with the job they are supposed to be doing, and clearly are not doing.

That brings me to the privatisation debate. Privatisation should not be an ideological matter. In my view it is not essential to a socialist platform but should be judged very much on its merit. It is not an end in itself, but a means to an end. In some cases it might be the right strategy, but in others it is not. I should not like to have happen here, in our mad rush to privatisation, what has occurred in the United Kingdom, where assets have been sold off and the money squandered on all sorts of intangible things which show no ongoing profit. That would be a dreadful mistake. Any benefits from privatisation should be put back into the economy to benefit industry, so that people will be able to obtain long term jobs. This country needs jobs for its children. Those jobs should be meaningful and well paid. The jobs in the tourist industry depend very much on this approach, because tourism is a discretionary area of expenditure. When the economy is flat people are less likely to travel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to participate in the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91 and to follow my friend the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). I shall make a few comments on the remarks he has made. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie has earned himself an enviable reputation as one who is courageously prepared to call his Party to account.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of great distress to me that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie delivered a speech to a press gallery that was all but empty. It strikes me that one of the tragic things about the speeches in this Parliament is that those speeches which are given most courageously, whether from my side of the House or from the Government's side of the House, are all too often given to an empty press gallery. When, in showing even more commitment than it takes to deliver a speech, someone from my side of the House, or, very rarely indeed, from the other side of the House-the only person who fits this category being the honourable member for Kalgoorlie-is prepared to vote against the party line, the press gallery, which ought to applaud that action as democracy being effected, tends more simply to say that the leader of the party is losing control. I regret that the remarks of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie and the remarks of so many speakers concerning this Bill are delivered to an empty gallery.

When the Treasurer (Mr Keating) handed down his 1990-91 Budget it was largely heralded as a non-event. Editorials around Australia said that this Budget had failed to address the essential needs of the community. I would like to quote from the editorial of the Herald of 22 August, the day after the Treasurer's Budget Speech. The Herald headed its editorial with the words, `We are not convinced'. The Herald editor wrote:

Watching Paul Keating deliver his eighth Budget last night it was as though the Treasurer wished he were somewhere else. Not even opulent confidence, conveyed by the knife-edge creases of an expensive suit and natty matching tie and handkerchief, enabled him to argue convincingly his audience should share his optimism for the Australian economy.

Speaking was a Treasurer who has had stewardship of that economy for seven years. He argued his policies are working. But the truth is that Australia is still saddled with $124 billion foreign debt of truly banana republic proportions, to borrow Mr Keating's earlier words.

Nor are there signs that his confidence of being able to stabilise this massive debt are justified: a sharp fall in business investment puts in question the economy's ability to deliver the product growth necessary.

And it is far from realistic for the Treasurer to expect small business people, whose ranks are steadily dwindling through insolvency induced by the Government's draconian policies, to whoop with joy at the Government's minimal concessions, or to take his outward confidence seriously.
The Budget was a damp squib.

The Budget failed to address the fundamental needs of the Australian community and has failed to attack head on that which we all fear most-that is, a $124 billion foreign debt which is growing every day.

As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not claim to be an economist and frequently when I am in my electorate people say to me, `But Mr Andrew, what is the Opposition on about? Treasurer Keating tells us that he is not only balancing his books but also handing down a Budget in surplus. Treasurer Keating goes on to allege that that is more than your Party was able to do in its last two Budgets. What are you on about when you are critical?'. I respond with an illustration that I hope serves to convey to people precisely what is wrong with the Australian economy. I say that Australia's economy is just like the farm and, currently, if one were to call that farm `Australia' and if my desktop were to be that farm, one can see that there is more coming in the front gate than is going out. There is more coming in, if you like, in seed, lambs for fattening, fertiliser and chemicals than is going out in finished product. There is more coming in, to the tune of $1.5 billion every month.

When the Treasurer says that he is handing down a balanced Budget, it is like the farm housewife-no sexism intended, Mr Deputy Speaker-taking the household budget of the farm and saying, `I am going to balance the household books'. Of course, she can do that because all she needs to do-as the Treasurer does-is charge enough rent to everyone who lives in the house to ensure that the household books are balanced while the farm continues to go broke. That is what is happening in Australia. The Treasurer is managing to balance his books. So what? The nation for which we are all accountable and responsible continues to go deeper into debt. The reason that the Opposition is indignant about this Budget is that we see nothing in it that addresses the fundamental problem that the nation faces-the problem of going deeper and deeper into debt. Balancing Treasurer Keating's books is only tinkering at the edges.

Let us keep in perspective what this foreign debt-this debt in our balance of trade-is all about. In the Adelaide Advertiser and in the South Australian press generally there was a great hue and cry when it was reported that an alleged $700,000 was being spent in the parliamentary dining room on dining room modifications. Mr Deputy Speaker, you and I have been in the dining room and I find it hard to see where that sort of money has been spent. Frankly, I am just a little sceptical about that figure. But it does not matter for the purpose of this debate. If the money was spent, there can be no justification for it. But let us keep it in perspective. The amount of $700,000 is only the amount of money for which the nation will go into debt while I am delivering this speech-$700,000 every 20 minutes. The nation will go into debt to the tune of $2m an hour, $50m a day, $500m every 10 days, and $1.5 billion a month. It is unbelievable stuff, but that is what is happening, and the Budget that was handed down in this chamber did nothing to turn that situation around.

That is why the Opposition is less than enchanted with that Budget. It failed to address the real needs of the Australian community. Our criticism of the Budget is that it did nothing at a time when something needed to be done. If one is an Australian taxpayer, in spite of all that the Treasurer tells us about what he has done for us, the truth is that one continues to pay tax at an exorbitant rate. The Treasurer will say-and the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), who is at the table, may even say it-that the tax rate has fallen.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the reality is that when you and I came into this Parliament in 1983-84, 72 per cent of Australian taxpayers paid tax at a rate of 30 per cent or less. Last year only 48 per cent of Australian taxpayers paid tax at a rate of 30 per cent or less, or, if I put it around the other way, in reality, 28 per cent of taxpayers once had an income tax rate of over 30 per cent, and today 52 per cent of taxpayers have an income tax rate of over 30 per cent. Nothing in this Budget and nothing in the action taken by this Government over the last seven years have encouraged Australians to be more productive and unless we are more productive we will not have coming out of the front gate more than is currently going into it.

I represent an electorate largely made up of rural producers. Rural producers have good reason to be indignant at the action taken against them in this Budget. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie, as I have said, has already courageously referred to it. In this Budget the Treasurer had the sheer, bare-faced audacity to pretend that he was offering farmers tax deductibility for fencing in order to prevent land degradation. That is great motherhood stuff in 1990 when simply to utter the word `conservation' wins everybody on side.

However, on closer inspection what did we discover? We discovered that tax deductibility for fencing for farmers to minimise land degradation was granted only if a farm already had in place or was putting in place a whole farm plan. That might seem fair enough superficially, but I have been told by the South Australian Department of Agriculture that it has been caught on the hop; that it is not ready either to put in place or to approve whole farm conservation plans. Further, the technical and further education colleges in South Australia say that the setting up of appropriate courses to ensure that farmers know how to go about a whole farm plan will take up to five years.

Would it really have mattered if the Treasurer had simply allowed tax deductibility for fencing for conservation? Does he not believe that every individual farmer is capable of making his own responsible fencing decisions? For crying out loud, Mr Deputy Speaker, do you know a farmer who fences for fun? They choose to put fences only when the fences are going to keep the planted trees free from what would otherwise be invading stock.

A technique was once introduced, I am pleased to say by the Liberal and National parties, that allowed tax deduction at an accelerated rate for water conveyancing. Nothing did as much to sort out the indiscriminate use of water irrigation as did that provision, and this lot rubbed it out. Now they are prepared to introduce tax deduction for fencing of some form to minimise land degradation but only if the criteria the Government has laid down have been met.

What Australia needs is a measure that says we trust people to get on with appropriate water conveyancing and appropriate minimisation of soil degradation. We need conservation measures, not conservation thwarted by a heavy-handed government. However, Mr Deputy Speaker, that is only dealing with the edges of the major problems that Australia's rural producers face as a result of the Budget.

I could not believe my ears when the Treasurer stood up and said that he was imposing an assets test on the family allowance. I share all of the indignation of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie: with an assets test for the family allowance set at $300,000, there would scarcely be a farmer in Australia who would qualify for the allowance. It is totally indefensible and totally discriminatory. I venture to suggest that even the South Africans would hesitate at this sort of discrimination.

It does not matter what the cash flow is. It does not matter how large a family is. If the assets exceed $300,000, the family no longer gets the family allowance. It does not matter what it earns. If Australia's rural producers saw their rural assets as being worth in money terms half a million dollars, and if that was all it meant to them, they would have liquidated them. Frankly, Mr Deputy Speaker, you and I know that they see their asset as something that has been in the family for generations or as something they have acquired by going without. They do not see it in simple capital terms.

This year of all years, when we know that grain prices are falling dramatically, when wool is proving to be a major burden in terms of the way we move it through the market, and when even the fall in the floor price, which the Opposition supported, has not been successful in generating farm incomes-this year when farmers face the reality that in all probability they will have negative incomes-there will be no family allowance. How can anyone-I invite the next honourable member to speak to tell me-defend a policy as discriminatory as that?

There is no question about whether a family actually deserves the family allowance. Simply having in one's name a non-productive asset worth over $300,000 means one can kiss the allowance goodbye and with it the capacity to budget for a portion of one's family's needs. If that was not enough-I am reluctant to proceed with this litany of dire predictions-what else do we have? We have the assets test on Austudy tightened closer. Anyone who has a farm or business valued at over $400,000 no longer gets Austudy. A Government that declares that what it wants is a clever country is saying to rural young people in a year when rural incomes will be at a low unprecedented for three decades, `You will not get Austudy.'

A child from a country farm is no longer able to have the access to Austudy that the urban counterpart might reasonably enjoy. Worse than that: a child from a country farm is very likely the person this Government needs because that person is most likely to be innovative, most likely to show some capacity to get on with the job. Yet this Government says that there will be no Austudy and, consequently, in 1990-91 no tertiary education for such children.

I wish I could finish there but we have the additional burden of the Government saying to farmers that that is not enough, that it will make sure that the export inspection charge, of which it currently recoups 60 per cent of the cost, will be totally borne by farmers as from 1 January next year. The farmer, who already faces negative income, will now have to bear, of all things, the total cost of exporting-the very capacity to generate product that the Government needs in order to get more out of the gate and less in.

My farmers have in some cases been prepared to say, `We could tolerate that-not like it, not welcome it but tolerate it-if in this user-pays technique we had some say in the way the export inspection is conducted'. But no, the Government says how it will be done and farmers foot the bill.

If I speak beyond my 20 minutes, the $700,000 of debt that I referred to earlier in my speech will be exceeded and I have much else to say about the way in which the Government has dealt with pensioners and about the uncertainty that has been generated for all pensioners who now find themselves uneasy about what they do with anything in excess of $2,000 that they might invest. They now find themselves uneasy and uncertain about the Government's pharmaceutical benefits scheme because it had been announced and then suddenly changed. Pensioners-the very people who made this nation what it is-are plagued with uncertainty because of the actions of the Government and are treated as if they were major players in the money market.

I could go on but instead I would like to ask: is it not really a tragedy that in spite of the increased tax take that has characterised all of the Treasurer's Budgets, the infrastructure in Australia continues to run down? I conclude by adding that there is another way to go about addressing Australia's major problems, and this other way has been endorsed by the Opposition, when through the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) we have indicated what we will do in industrial relations; through the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) we have been bold in our statements about a broad-based consumption tax; and through the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) we have indicated what we would do in industry protection. It is time the people of Australia had an opportunity to change the Government. We cannot afford to go on marking time.
