SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address my initial remarks today to some of the matters that were raised in the latter stages of the debate on the social welfare legislation. The changes were being discussed the other night and some honourable members opposite levelled criticism at people in our society, including some members of parliament, who choose to access the public health system, even though they are earning reasonable salaries or wages. I say to those honourable members opposite and others who may share their view, that if we confine the public health system to the poor, we condemn them to a poor public health system. All the crocodile tears in the world will not alter that fact. I am sure that if we got to that stage, many honourable members opposite would shed crocodile tears.

SPEECH.PARA: It may have conveniently slipped the memories of those honourable members that the poor and the less well-off in this country-and in New Zealand, where I originally came from-are not asked to pay anything towards the cost of maintaining Medicare or the public health system which they are able to access free of charge. That is the way it should be; that is the way it will continue to be under a Labor government.

This Labor Government believes in the ability to pay principle, embodied in the phrase, `From each according to his or her means, to each according to his or her needs'. This is a basic tenet of our Party and our Government and one which the vast majority of Australians support in a general sense because it is the fair go principle. Who would pay for the upkeep of Medicare and the public health system if the least well-off in our society were the only ones allowed to access it? Are honourable members opposite seriously suggesting that upper and middle income earners would be required to continue to contribute to this system through their taxation, even though they were not permitted to access or utilise it in any way? So much for freedom of choice, much vaunted by honourable members on the other side of the House!

Honourable members should bear in mind that the proponents of this idea are the very same people who bleat constantly about the fact that they have to contribute to Medicare now, when they can still use it if they want to and when they make claims on their private health funds to assist in paying the accounts of their private doctors, private hospitals and private specialists. The reality is that if we refuse to allow upper and middle income earners to access public health services they will have every expectation that their contribution to that system will no longer be sought through taxation. Where then will the money come from to support and maintain, let alone expand, the public health system? Bingo! There will be no money and the public health system will collapse or limp along on small handouts from the Government in the name of welfare. We do not want a welfare health system. We want a public health system, a uniform health system, a universal health system in this country.

The Opposition-or those honourable members opposite who claim to have this view-would finally have achieved the objective of many of its members; that is, Australians would be almost totally reliant on the private health system and private health cover once again. We would be back to the bad old days of compulsory private health insurance and no protection for the poor, the aged or the chronically ill. No, thank you! While middle and upper income earners utilise the public hospitals they actually ensure the maintenance of quality services for all patients. The poor and pensioners are seldom in a position to insist on their right to high quality care. How much less able to defend such a position would they be if they were constantly fighting for funding of a system which only they were able to access? It is the old story of the general eating the same food as his troops. How else does one know what sort of food is being served, how else does one judge quality?

Honourable members opposite can carry on until they are blue in the face about this matter and never convince me that the withdrawal of non-pensioners or non-low income earners from use of the public health system will improve the service and the efficiency provided to patients. Furthermore, they can sneer all they like about politicians getting privileged treatment. The fact remains that I personally and, I am sure, other members in this House have never sought or received special treatment at a public hospital; nor have my husband and children. I am quite prepared to wait my turn and accept the ministrations of whatever practitioner or specialist is assigned to me. That is the real test of the system. That is the only way that I can be sure, as I am, that the Australian public health system is the best in the world. I can also be sure that my constituents are receiving a satisfactory level of health care through that system.

To preserve the quality of the system we have it is essential that articulate individuals continue to access it and test its ability to deliver a comprehensive service of high standard. I say again, if we confine the public health system to the poor, we condemn them to a poor public health system. People who do not believe this is true, should remember the days before Medicare and Medibank, when there was no public health system of a universal nature. Women frequently sacrificed their health for the sake of their families' health. If there were a bill to be paid, it would be paid for others in the family and the woman would not take herself to the doctor when she was ill. I do not ever wish to see a return to a system which puts women in that position. At the present time, at least under Medicare, they have an assurance of being able to access any hospital or specialist facility they require and they also have access to bulkbilling from most doctors.

I am pleased to advise the House that recently in my electorate a rather large medical centre changed its practice and decided to bulkbill, against its previous opinion, because it was losing too much money. I had already explained to many of my constituents that the 85 per cent fee reimbursement from the Government would, in fact, have covered the cost of bad debts or postage or claims to patients for moneys that they owed. That now appears to be the case. This particular medical firm has obviously realised the fact that 85 per cent on a continuing basis and from a regular payer is better than perhaps 75 per cent when it is not quite sure that it is going to get it.

We also had the strange situation with this particular medical centre where if a patient went along before 8 o'clock in the morning-for want of a better time; more probably 8.30-when the computer was not switched on, he would be treated as a bulkbill patient, but once the computer was switched on the family income was looked into by the doctor to see whether it was appropriate to bulkbill. I have a very firm view on this. Just as a doctor likes to keep his patient's business private and between him and his patient, so the patient should have the right to keep his financial status between him and his accountant or him and his bank manager. The patient ought not to have to disclose his financial position to his doctor in order to receive bulkbilling treatment. I am very pleased to see that medical centre adopt bulkbilling, because a lot of constituents in my area were actually accessing the service it provided but complaining because they were unable to get bulkbilling.

As many members of this House would be aware, there will be a review of the health needs of the Australian people over the next 18 months or so. It will take quite a while to do. I am sure that people will have an opportunity to put to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) their views on the current system. I think that is a good thing. I do not think that anyone here would see it as anything else, but basically it must always be an underwrite of the Medicare system, which is such a good system in this country.

Another area in which our Government is determined to achieve improvement is the area of social infrastructure provision in outer metropolitan areas. I represent an outer metropolitan area and I know that the people in my area have lots of difficulties with transport, housing and access to services. Often it does not appear as if these people have a problem because they have one car and seem to be reasonably affluent from the outside, but they have great difficulty in using the public transport system because it basically travels north and south in the Cowan area and we need more comprehensive east-west systems for people to be able to access essential services when their one car is being used.

In that context, I note the commitment to family resource centres and the $15m which the Government intends to provide in this area over the next three years. In Western Australia, the State Government has made a noteworthy commitment to establish family centres in a number of suburbs throughout the Perth metropolitan area, and quite a few are being developed in my electorate of Cowan. These centres provide an excellent community facility which has the capability of growing and changing with the community's needs. The State Government puts in the entire capital cost of that facility and the community committee which administers the centre actually determines all other use of it, except for a program for four-year-old education. As some honourable members would be aware, children do not attend compulsory schooling in Western Australia until age six, so quite a number of children are seeking alternative activities, educational activities at that, and so the State Government has made an undertaking to assist in this area through the family centres. Through the provision of those centres they now are able to extend four-year-old programs for young children awaiting attendance at school.

As an active member of the interim management committee of the Marangaroo family centre, I was delighted to be able to invite the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the opening ceremony earlier this year. I know that he was impressed with the quality of the facility as well as the principle which it embodies. The community made him very welcome. Management committees of such centres work extremely hard to ensure the successful delivery of services that their community requires. Depending on the age group of the community around the centre, those services can be very varied. In some areas they may be almost entirely child care or out of school care because of the age of the children and the age of the general population. Demography determines the use of these centres. In other areas, where the population may be a little older, or in this area in years to come, when the population ages, the centres will be used perhaps as autumn centres.

When we consider social infrastructure it is important to ensure that there is flexibility and that we no longer go down the track of having specific-purpose buildings that cannot be changed when the population in the area changes and has different needs.

I would like to convey my personal congratulations to the members of the management committee of the Marangaroo family centre, with whom I have worked for a considerable period, as well as the members of the management committee of the Kingsley family centre which is also providing an excellent model of active community participation and cooperation in the northern suburbs. The Kingsley family centre has an extremely good relationship with a local primary school and is able to share premises and arrange for the use of the building by school groups at night time. Thus, we end up with a more flexible and appropriate use of all the buildings in the area. This is essential in outer metropolitan areas-and probably inner metropolitan areas, but the populations there perhaps have not yet got around to having to use their resources quite as flexibly as this.

It is appropriate at this time also to mention the Woodvale family centre, which will be holding its first public meeting at the North Woodvale primary school tomorrow evening under the chairmanship of my State colleague Sam Piantadosi, a member of the Legislative Council. I wish those present at the meeting well in their discussions and consideration of the needs of their local community and I am sorry I will not be able to attend because I think inaugural meetings and public meetings of these family centres are a great learning curve for members of parliament. One is able to ascertain the exact needs of the community when these are expressed in very broad terms at such meetings.

I also want to mention the importance of an aspect of the Budget relating to youth activities. In the portfolio of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) there has been an allocation for activities for young people aged 11 to 16. That is very important. These children will be coming from disadvantaged areas. A particular group in my area will be hoping to access some of this money. I certainly intend supporting their application, if not actually helping them complete it.

In that context I would like to refer to a fitness centre in my electorate. It went out of business about two years ago when many fitness centres went out of business in Western Australia. Having charged life membership for many people and then run out of money, such centres went broke. For more than two years this centre has been sitting around being gradually vandalised. The local community has been very worried about it but nobody has done anything to overcome the problem. So, in the past 10 months I have been actively involved in trying to ensure that we can resurrect the centre, recommission it or do something to make it a useful community facility. We have now at least got to the stage where there is a possibility of having the swimming pool recommissioned for local use on a commercial basis, with possibly a Skillshare project operating out of one end of the building and a youth activities and drop-in centre at the other. These sorts of things, if generated by members of parliament with other people of goodwill in the community, can make a facility like the former Fletchers fitness centre, which was an eyesore and an area of great concern to the parents in the district, a positive boon to the community.

This area of Girrawheen to which I am referring is a very disadvantaged area. It has no real community facilities that are easily accessible to the whole population. I hope that we might be able to get some funds to provide some equipment for the centre, which would be very helpful. The group that will be applying for the funds is running a drop-in centre in the area and has a small room on which it pays about $1 a year, or a very nominal rental. But it only has one pool table. Eighty kids come in there. One just cannot operate a facility like that for very long. Whether or not these moneys go to Girrawheen, I am very anxious to see that they go to areas where kids are crying out for something to do.

I want to give an illustration. The swimming pool at the Girrawheen health centre, as it was called, or the Fletchers fitness centre has a great dip in the bottom to allow diving. The kids have been using the drained swimming pool as a skateboard rink, for which it is very suitable. In order to enter the building when it was locked up the kids were very creative: they climbed in through the roof and under the doors. We know that these kids want to use the building. Now we just have to make sure that the building will be used properly. I would like to congratulate all of the people involved, including the new owner, George Wuu, who is making every effort to renovate the building and recommission it so that it can be used for the community it is supposed to be serving.

Earlier I briefly discussed women in the community and women's health. This Government is sponsoring a national women's health program. I am sorry to acknowledge that the Western Australian Government has not chosen to participate in that this year but I am confident that we will be able to get it to do so next year, with a bit of luck. Certainly in my area and around my electorate generally there is a great need for proper women's health services in accessible places. Once again we are talking about outer metropolitan suburbs where the transport services are north-south. It is inappropriate to place facilities like women's health centres in situations where people cannot access them by bus-we have no train service yet.

At the present time, along with many other people in the community, I am pursuing the establishment of a women's health service which we hope will be a jointly hosted Federal and State facility with family support of all sorts and teenage assistance as well. It will take a bit of time to get it but, as I say, I will ardently lobby the Minister for Health in the State Government in order to ensure that he understands the needs. Hopefully we will get them to join in the national women's health program from July next year. I have no further comments on the Appropriation Bill at this stage, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I thank you for your time and your tolerance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1990 Federal Budget is a great disappointment. In the first Budget following an election one would have expected the new Government to outline a bold period of initiatives for its new term in office. We have not had that program of action to revitalise the nation; we have had a lacklustre Budget which has failed to come to grips with the major economic and social problems confronting our nation. The Budget offers no hope for inflation, no hope for our national debt, no hope for the unemployed, no hope for an end to high interest rates and no hope for any stimulation of investment. Indeed, the theme of the Budget could well be `steady as she sinks'. The Budget lacks vision and hope for the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) would not have chosen to make some reforms. He has had something of a change of attitude in recent times and he wanted to include the privatisation of Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines Ltd, Telecom Australia, the Commonwealth Bank and other government institutions in this particular Budget. The reform package fell off the cart on the way. It was hijacked by the feuding factions and the trade union movement. Ironically, it took the factions only a few days to collapse in the wake of the State Bank of Victoria scandal. Even the Left was prepared to sacrifice its sacred icons to protect its incompetent mates in the Victorian Government.

Now we have the humiliating spectacle of the elected government having to go along cap in hand next Monday to seek permission from the trade union movement to introduce the reforms that it believes are right for Australia.

Over recent years the Treasurer has been introducing his Budgets with glowing promises about J-curves and the nation's emergence from the economic crisis and the Budget that brings home the bacon. This year's Budget makes it clear, if anyone had any doubt, that the glowing descriptions of previous Budgets were an illusion. The fruits of past failed policies are all too apparent in the predictions for this year's Budget. There will be no slowing in the growth in our national debt. Interest rates will remain high and unemployment will grow.

Just weeks after the presentation of the Budget most observers agree that the Treasurer's bleak picture of the Australian economy in the year ahead was unduly generous. Indeed, the potential of the Iraqi conflict has the capacity to totally destroy the Budget philosophy in just a few weeks. The increasing cost of oil, the cost of Australia's military presence, the loss of trading opportunities and the strengthening of the Australian dollar blow the Budget strategy to pieces.

While the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has acknowledged that farmers should not wear the potentially billion dollars plus cost of trade sanctions against Iraq on their own, there is no provision in the Budget for any compensation package. The Budget documents indicate that unemployment will grow to 7.5 per cent by the June quarter of 1991. But unless there is some significant change in economic policy, some real stimulus to national development, some real encouragement to the productive sector, that figure is likely to be nearer 10 per cent or even higher.

The nation was looking for leadership, and people are ready for tough decisions so long as they can see that they are part of a real program for economic change. But unfortunately all they got was disillusionment and hurt. Pensioners, students and the unemployed will be sharing in the impact of failed Labor Government economic policies. The Government has resorted to hurting the disadvantaged and those who are least able to protect themselves. Wasteful social engineering programs remain in place but structural reform issues have been avoided. The sick and the infirm will be penalised through new prescription charge arrangements. Almost half a million will be affected by changes to sickness and invalid pensions. The iniquitous assets test has been made tougher and tertiary students will have to repay their education contributions faster.

The Government is spending $4m on public relations campaigns to sell the Budget but even this will not be sufficient to convince the Australian public that it has been well treated. Once again it is the productive sector which has been hardest hit by the Federal Budget's measures. Despite talk of tax cuts, tax collections have once again increased and real expenditure is up.

At a time when the nation desperately needs to boost its export income and encourage those producing our national wealth in an effort to come to grips with the crippling debt problem, the Budget includes measures which will actually hamper exports. The amazing decision to increase export inspection charges for primary industries from 60 per cent to a full 100 per cent cost recovery of the export inspection service is the kind of taxation imposition which will further jeopardise our capacity to compete on world markets. Export inspection certificates are required by importers yet Australian exporters must pay. While we as a nation bend over backwards to break down the impediments to products coming into this country, we penalise our own exporters.

In an article in the Queensland Grain Grower on 29 August Mr John Spinks of Associated Grain Pty Ltd in Dalby described the Federal Government's cost recovery on agricultural charges as `user pays gone crazy'. He said that the export inspection charges for a 21 tonne container of grain would now rise to $8.57 a tonne. If the container holds a light grain such as sunflower the cost will be nearer $12 a tonne. Mr Spinks said:

Our margins aren't $12 a ton and we have risks in our trading operations. It also makes us less competitive overseas. We seem to be working more and more for the government. It's not one simple tax-they are all around us.

In many instances the new export charges will be imposed by the Government even when phytosanitary certificates are not required. While other countries subsidise their producers and encourage their exports, we not only expose our producers to the cold winds of international competition but also tax their every attempt to succeed.

Overall Government expenditure in the rural sector continues to decline and will fall from $445.4m to $423.3m this year and then to $308.9m over the next three years. Included in those figures are significant payments as compensation to the forest industry for not producing. For farmers the bottom line of the Budget is that the rural sector will have to pay $1,369.9m in levies and charges while the Government contributes a mere $423.3m.

The biggest rural sector Government contribution in this Budget is to rural research. The development of the Federal Government's Rural Research Corporation has hijacked control of the industry's levy funds and guaranteed that research priorities are dictated by the academics rather than those who fund the research and are supposed to get its benefits. In fact, one wonders whether this Government's approach to rural research is more aimed at having farmers fund research institutions than achieving improvements to rural productivity.

The Government is invariably keen to promote its initiatives in the area of conservation. In this year's Budget there is a tiny new initiative-100 per cent tax deductibility for fences built to protect land or trees planted as part of a conservation program. However, it seems that very few if any farmers will qualify for this kind of concession, particularly as it is dependent upon the development of a whole farm conservation plan.

Farmers in the rural sector have a major role to play in the conservation of our national heritage, including the prevention of soil degradation and the protection of forest land. The biggest cause of forest destruction and land degradation around the world is poverty. In many instances the rainforest jungles of Asia and South America are not being cleared for the value of their timber but to establish additional food production areas. Indeed, if those lands were able to appreciate in accord with the economic value of properly managed forests, the people may well be able to be encouraged to develop sustainable forest industries rather than quickly degenerating farm industries.

In Australia the major factor limiting the development of conservation measures on Australian farms is an inability to pay. This Government has adopted a continuing succession of anti-farmer measures which are placing the very economic survival of our rural sector in jeopardy.

A recent Department of Primary Industries and Energy survey of the farmers of the South Burnett area in my electorate has shown that almost one-third of the farmers in the region are at risk. Most have lost confidence in the future and many are unlikely to survive the continuing impact of the current Government's economic policies. A farmer who is struggling for his very survival cannot spend the time and resources that are necessary to plant trees or maintain conservation programs. He is forced to increase his cropping and stocking program rather than reduce the pressure that he is facing on his land.

When the banks are screaming for higher and higher Keating-imposed interest rates and when the Government imposes more and more costs and charges a farmer cannot afford to do what he knows is in the best interests of the conservation of his land. The greatest thing that this or any government could do for conservation in this country would be to improve the economic status of the custodians of the land.

Australian farmers can do more for positive conservation in a day than governments can achieve in a decade. The Government's one billion trees program is just an example. There is an allocation of something like 4c a tree in this year's Budget. Despite all the printed literature and the much publicised ceremonial occasions, the fact is that very few trees have been planted under this program and the Government has now even admitted that it never really intended to plant one billion trees. There are more trees planted by foresters in Australia in a day than the Government is likely to achieve in its one billion trees program.

The Government's total disregard for the national road system has been further accentuated in this Budget. Labor's record on roads is deplorable. It sees motorists as mobile tax offices with no rights to any reasonable return for the amounts of taxation they contribute to Government revenue. During the last election campaign the Government was shamed into some small new commitments and so the increase of $160m for roads is a welcome Budget initiative.

However, the forward projections indicate yet another intention to freeze road funding into the future. Some $1,495m is projected for expenditure in each of the next two years, but that will be followed by a decline of $70m in 1993-94. Labor has clearly not learnt anything from the road funding campaign associated with the last Federal Budget. Labor in Government has slashed road funding by 30 per cent in real terms. Its neglect of our nation's road system is a disgrace. Labor's road neglect contributes significantly to the increase in transport costs, the national road toll, the increase in urban pollution and the isolation of the bush.

Every dollar spent on roads returns many times as an investment to the nation. One million dollars spent on roads creates 60 jobs and reduces unemployment benefits alone by $400,000. Better roads encourage decentralised industry, increased tourism, lower costs and a more productive society. By the time the national road system is handed back to us following the next Federal election, the extra $1 billion we promised will not be enough. In many cases the damage will be irreversible. By then almost all allocated funds will be required for maintenance purposes without any capability for improvements.

The fact that we have so many Labor State governments is further bad news for the road system. Labor has so slashed road funding in Queensland, even after only one Budget, that some projects have already been stopped. If all that is not enough, we have the Inter-State Commission report on road use charges and that will be more bad news for motorists. Despite the fact that the Inter-State Commission report recommends a new national fuel tax of 20.5c a litre, the report proposes no additional money for roads. The Inter-State Commission report is without doubt a recipe for more bureaucracy, more taxes, and further national decline.

Queensland motorists will be the big losers under the Inter-State Commission report. The years of the National Party Government have protected Queensland from the insidious fuel taxes that apply in other States. The Goss Labor Government is already showing signs that it intends to use the Inter-State Commission report to get around its election promise not to introduce a State fuel tax. In its submission to the Inter-State Commission, the Queensland State Government has implied support for the basic thrust of the report and restricted its criticisms to aspects of the administration arrangements.

Proposals to impose up-front charges of around $18,500 on semi-trailers will have a cruel impact on all regional and rural Australians. These kinds of cost impositions will not only bankrupt transport operators but guarantee price increases on every item in every store. It is inconceivable that any Queensland government could embrace proposals which so clearly disadvantage the motorists of that State.

Hidden away in the fine print in the Budget is the Government's long-awaited response to the review of the aerodrome local ownership plan (ALOP), and unfortunately it is more bad news. The Commonwealth Government has announced its intention to terminate the program altogether. Over 270 airports in rural and provincial areas of Australia now operate under this program which provides a 50 per cent Federal government contribution towards aerodrome capital and maintenance costs. In ending the ALOP this Government is breaking agreements made over a period of more than 20 years with local governments which took over the ownership of local airports with a promise from the Federal government of the day that it would continue the 50 per cent share of costs into the future. Many of those agreements are in writing, but it seems that past contractual responsibilities carry no weight with this Government.

While it is happy to collect massive taxation from the aviation industry, those who in future will be required to maintain airports outside the major cities will get none of that money. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) in a press release on the Budget night tried to dress up the Government's real intention in a positive way by announcing that:
for the first time local interests can exploit the commercial potential of their aerodromes to benefit the regions they serve.
He also said:
Local communities will be invited to take over the management and operation of their aerodromes.

But surely even the Government knows that the vast majority of these airports have no capacity for exploitation or even to cover their own costs. The Government's real intention is perhaps better revealed towards the end of the press release where Senator Collins says:
For those ALOP aerodromes where the offer is not accepted by local owners, the Commonwealth will consider ceasing funding support.

Local communities are in a no-win situation. If they do not accept the full cost of maintaining and caring for their airports, the Government will stop funding anyhow. The Federal Government is shifting the multi-million dollar airport maintenance responsibility on to the ratepayers of rural and provincial Australia. Those who have waited patiently for airport upgrading will get nothing from this Government. The Government left it to the First Assistant Secretary of Transport, Mr David Buckingham, to explain its abdication of responsibility for aerodromes at the recent conference of the Australian Airport Owners Association at Port Augusta. Mr Buckingham said that the Government would consider making one-off social benefit subsidies to ALOP aerodromes which are not assessed to be commercially viable. The subsidy is to be paid in the form of a once only capital grant from which future maintenance and operational costs are to be met.

Aerodromes under the ALOP program fill an essential local need. They are vital links in the chain of communication between rural and provincial areas and the rest of the world. Airports are not just useful when Snowdon Airlines wants to travel to the Tennant Creek dog show or visit the Collingwood football match. They are required for basic communications with the rest of the world, particularly in times of emergency or sudden calamity. Very few of these airports have any potential to actually pay their own way. Some have so few daily movements that it is impractical to collect landing charges.

If the Government really intended to provide appropriate funds for maintenance annuities for all the non-commercial airports currently under the ALOP program, the Budget should be foreshadowing allocations of several million dollars. However, total forward estimates for this purpose in the Budget is only $18.6m. Clearly, very few, if any, of these airports can expect any future contribution from the Federal Government. Indeed, the Federal Government is totally abdicating its responsibility towards rural and provincial airports and placing their owners in a cruel vice. The local people will allow their airports to close eventually when they cannot afford to meet the maintenance demands of the Government's Civil Aviation Authority or when additional burdens are imposed on ratepayers whom, I might add, copped plenty of beatings in this Federal Budget with further cutbacks projected for local government funding in the years ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset he expressed some concern for those who are sick and infirm and some regret that the Budget somehow had not properly addressed their legitimate interests. He went on to talk about those who are paying into the higher education contribution scheme, HECS.

That was, no doubt, one of the events which led to the defeat of the Opposition in the recent election.

The honourable member for Wide Bay criticised the Government because the rate of repayment was changed. The policy of the Opposition does not provide for repayment. The student must pay the money at the start. The inconsistencies of the Opposition are glaring. I propose to make some more comments about that shortly.

I welcome the challenge thrown down by the honourable member for Wide Bay to compare the performance of the former National Party Government in Queensland with that of the current Goss Labor Government. I would be quite happy to compare the performance of the former National Party Government with that of just about any other government in the Western world. Before looking at the specifics of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91, I believe it is important to look at some broader aspects of the Budget and the economic framework in which it functions. For the fourth year in succession, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has produced on behalf of the Government a Budget which is not only balanced, but includes a surplus.

To put that into perspective, tables of Budget outlays and revenue since 1953-54 indicate that no other government has achieved a surplus in the last 37 years, let alone four in succession. This is a major achievement, made all the more significant when it is recognised that the Government now provides a range of services and programs which were not even contemplated in the 1950s and 1960s. Moreover, as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP), Government outlays are now at the same level as they were in 1960-61. Together, these measures have reduced pressure on interest rates and thereby provided direct relief to Australian families and business communities.

It is a matter of some regret that the banking industry in this country has been slow to pick up the opportunities afforded to it through these policies. I welcome the recent statements of the Treasurer in which he admonished the banks for the way in which they have sought to reap profits from their own errors, the way in which they have sought to isolate their shareholders from their own bad decisions and to force upon decent Australians-home loan borrowers, small business people and large business owners, those who are paying their way-the consequences of their own errors.

It is worth recalling that the Fraser Liberal-National Party Government, in its term in office, accumulated a Budget deficit of $17 billion. Talk is cheap. Honourable members opposite talk about fiscal responsibility, but the record shows that when they had the opportunity they did not in fact implement those policies. It has, in fact, fallen to the Hawke Labor Government to set the ledger straight; not only to balance the national Budget, but also to put it into surplus. The last Liberal-National Budget presented in this place projected a shortfall of revenue to outlays equal to 2.6 per cent of GDP. In contrast, the Budget before this Parliament today projects surplus revenue over outlays equal to 2 per cent of GDP-some $8 billion.

This Budget is not only economically responsible; it is targeted to provide services to those most in need. I am delighted that this Budget increases expenditure on education by $921m, or 7.3 per cent in real terms. Funding for schools will receive an additional $248m, an 11.5 per cent increase over the last year. Higher education also benefits from this Budget. The Government's program to increase tertiary places continues, with an extra $24m in the triennial funding program for higher education. By the end of 1993, this Government will have created 70,000 new student places since 1988. By any measure, that is a substantial achievement.

Funding for an extra 1,400 postgraduate research awards is also included in this Budget. I take special pride in that because I place a particularly high value on education in the process of not only providing a fair and equitable society, but also supporting the moves to restructure our economy and provide it with the vitality, enthusiasm and the knowledge that it will require if we are, in fact, to be internationally competitive in an increasingly competitive world.

The Hawke Government's commitment to develop Australia as a clever country has received tangible support in this Budget. The cooperative research centres announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the election campaign earlier this year have also been included in this Budget, with an allocation of $4m to assist in the establishment of the first 15 of those cooperative research centres.

A good deal of public comment has focused on the Budget provisions concerning the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and deemed interest on savings of pensioners. Since the Budget was introduced into this House I have spoken to hundreds of pensioners and senior citizens who reside within my electorate of Brisbane. In nearly every case they not only accept but also agree with the main provisions of this Budget when the actual details have been put before them. It is to the shame of some honourable members opposite and certain sections of the media that their incomplete or inaccurate reporting of the Budget has caused deep concern amongst the pensioner community, many of whom are in fact directly assisted by this Budget. However, the rumourmongering and misinformation in relation to changes brought down in the Budget for our elderly have been added to by difficulties imposed on pensioners by other tiers of government.

The Government has assured pensioners that no-one who presently has a fringe benefits card will lose that entitlement as a result of these changes. In fact, single pensioners with less than $20,800 in savings and no other income will not have their social security entitlements reduced at all. For pensioner couples, that amount is a sizeable $36,000. The Minister has advised that pensioners and beneficiaries who place low yield money in higher yielding investments will achieve a net increase in their disposable income while preserving their Commonwealth Government fringe benefit entitlements and their pensioner health benefit cards. In effect, these pensioners will receive a higher income, made up of interest from their banks and a pension payment from the Federal Government.

It is about time the banks started to pay those pensioners a fair return on the deposits they have been taking. For too long, the banks have taken pensioners' life savings, given them no or nominal interest, and then lent that same money at rates between 15 and 22 per cent. The banks have taken unfair advantage of pensioners for too long. The bottom line for most pensioners is that a fair return on their bank deposits, plus their pension entitlements, is greater than their current pension income.

Pensioners and senior citizens in my electorate of Brisbane will also benefit from the Goss Government's decision to introduce an extensive package of reforms for Queensland's elderly. I am pleased that the honourable member for Wide Bay is still in the House to consider this comparison. The most significant of these reforms was the introduction of a senior citizens card in that State's recent Budget. The senior citizens card is a move designed to recognise properly the enormous contribution to society made by our senior citizens. It delivers a range of benefits to pensioners over 60 and to all senior citizens over 70 years of age.

The various programs initiated by the Hawke Government in recent years have tended to shift the focus of the Budget away from the traditional area of public interest, namely, tax rates. TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments on the matter of privilege raised by the honourable member for Calwell earlier today. Honourable members will recall that the honourable member raised as a matter of privilege an article by Mr M. Daly in the Melbourne Sunday Herald of 16 September which the honourable member stated revealed details of a submission the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations had determined should be kept confidential.

INTERJECT.PARA: As I indicated to the House on 11 September, there are precedents for the disclosure of confidential committee documents being pursued as matters of privilege. I note that the Joint Committee has concluded that the article has constituted substantial interference with its work and that it wishes the matter to be referred to the Standing Committee of Privileges.

Having considered the article and the honourable member's remarks, I am prepared to accord precedence to a motion in respect of the matter. Nevertheless, the procedure of the House of Commons in these matters, to which I drew attention last week, as well as requiring the relevant committee to form a view as to the damage done by the disclosure, requires that committee itself to seek to ascertain its source. The honourable member for Calwell has advised that the Committee was giving consideration to the matters raised on 11 September. Before proceeding further with the article complained of today, I believe that the Committee itself should consider taking whatever steps it may wish to in order to ascertain the source of this latest disclosure.

As this is the second occasion in four sitting days on which such a complaint has been raised, perhaps I should reiterate the points I made last Tuesday and expand on them. Before doing that, however, I might counsel the Committee that it might be in its interests to investigate this matter as soon as possible.

I noted last Tuesday that since 1985-86 the British House of Commons had followed a specially developed procedure in these matters. If disclosure of the proceedings or draft reports of a committee is made, the committee concerned seeks to discover the source of the leak and to assess whether it constitutes or is likely to constitute a substantial interference with its work, with the select committee system, or with the functions of the House. If the committee considers that there has been or is likely to be such interference, the committee reports to the House accordingly.

This is the attitude I propose to take for the remainder of the Budget sittings. When a committee becomes aware of the unauthorised disclosure or publication of material, I propose that the Chairman, or another member acting for the committee, should inform me as soon as practicable. What I envisage is that the committee concerned would then follow procedures such as those applying in the House of Commons. If, as a result of its consideration of a matter, a committee presents a special report to the House stating that substantial interference has occurred and outlining the steps it has taken to ascertain the source of the problem, the Speaker would still be able to accord priority to a motion because he had been advised when the matter first came to light-that is, when the committee Chairman or member advises me accordingly.

To enable members to have an opportunity to consider the special report from the committee before a motion is proposed, I would intend that a motion to refer the matter to the Committee of Privileges should not normally be moved until the next sitting day. That would give members of the House a chance to see the committee's report and to form an opinion of the report prior to the matter being debated, if necessary, in the House.

I should make it clear to honourable members that I am not in any way reducing their rights to raise complaints under the established procedures. Rather, I am spelling out to the House the particular position I propose to take in respect of complaints of the kind raised last Tuesday and again today by the honourable member for Calwell. This will give members an opportunity to form a view as to whether these procedures are worthwhile pursuing in this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak tonight on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2). Before I make my opening remarks, I refer to some comments made by the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) in regard to bottom of the harbour schemes. I ask the honourable member: Who introduced the legislation into the Parliament so that those bottom of the harbour schemes could actually be done away with? I wonder whether he knows that it was the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) who took measures to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps we ought to reflect on some of the other things that are happening in Australian society today if the honourable member for Brisbane wants to go back that far. What about all the work practices which this Government has allowed to continue in the industrial relations area which cost this country millions, probably billions, of dollars a year? For the honourable member for Brisbane to refer back to bottom of the harbour schemes and suggest that the honourable member for Bennelong and the former Government did nothing is arrant nonsense; it is not the case. In fact, it was the honourable member for Bennelong, who later became the Leader of the Opposition, who took action to change things.

In rising to speak in this Budget debate, I should point out that the first and clearest thing about this Budget is that it was built around no central framework. Five months after the election this present Government was unable to come to grips with some of the major decisions with which it was faced. The Budget has no framework, and yet there is no doubt that this was the year's most important statement to the Parliament. The Government had five months and was not able to come to grips with those necessary decisions, around which the Budget could be built. So we find that those decisions which should have been made will now be made by people outside this Parliament in the next week.

What was the context in which this country was given this Budget in 1990? What is the backdrop against which it was framed? What is the situation which many Australians and we as a nation face? The context can be summed up in a few clear statements. First of all, this country is faced with a massive debt crisis which has ballooned under this Government. A very clear example that can be used to illustrate that point is that this country, which came into being in 1901, had run up a debt of $33 billion by 1983. It took 82 years to run up $33 billion worth of debt. It has taken another seven years to run up $115 billion to $120 billion of debt under this Government. That is a graphic illustration of the way that this economy has been managed by this Government.

Secondly, the inflation rate is double that of our major trading partners. Year by year this country becomes less and less competitive in world markets because our inflation rate is running away from us at twice that of our major trading partners. That is to say nothing of the backdrop which we are experiencing of high interest rates and people paying high interest rates for housing, in small business and so on. Of course, even though we have borrowed money from overseas, we now have rising unemployment rates. We have got this huge debt crisis blowing out month by month in the trading of this country, and yet we are now faced with unemployment rates as well.

Not only that, but we have also had six or seven good years of marketing. Commodity prices have been good. We have had good opportunities in the world market, and yet under the economic strategy of this Government we have gone further and further into debt. In addition, we have a Government which really has shown that it is not all that interested in development. It has shown to the business community that it prefers the green vote in Australia. As a consequence of that, in many parts of Australia there is now a substantial lack of confidence among members of the business community to go ahead with new projects or to replace old equipment which should be upgraded so that in their manufacturing processes they can be competitive and efficient on world markets. But that is not being done.

Not only is that not being done, not only is money not being spent in Australia to expand our industries, particularly manufacturing, but also the major companies are looking for-and, indeed, actually finding-places overseas and setting up manufacturing businesses in other parts of the world. That is because this Government has not given them the confidence that their developments will be able to go ahead. Of course, we only have to think back to the Wesley Vale development and Coronation Hill as illustrations.

The reactions of the public to this Budget can be summed up in a few short, sharp sentences. One comment, of course, has been `a Budget steady as she sinks'. It really is a Budget without a backbone. The way this Budget has been perceived out in the community is that there has been no central plank around which it has been developed.

Let me investigate why that perception has occurred. The fundamental reason is that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has adopted the attitude with the economy that 'she'll be right, mate'-that typical Australian approach. When difficulties arise, instead of grappling with them and showing some analysis of the issues and problems, the Treasurer, with the prime instrument, the prime document that comes into this Parliament each year, says that the problems are too big, that he has not been able to get the party together to make the right decisions, so `It'll be all right, she'll be right, mate, and it can all roll on and it will all come out in the wash'. I do not believe any Australians now accept that as an appropriate approach to the economic problems facing this country.

Second, the Government has been giving out the wrong signals to the community, right back from the earliest days of Budget preparation. I believe also that this Government is now believing its own rhetoric that everything is okay. I shall go through seven very short quotations of things that this Treasurer has said on introducing each Budget. Going back to 1984-85, we find on page 1:
The Government policies are on track . . .

How many times have honourable members heard that the policies are on track? That is a statement that goes back to the earliest days of this Government. We then go to the next year, 1985-86. On page 1 we see:
The evidence of our achievement is indisputable.
In 1986-87, at page 2:
We have made enormous progress in the past 3 years in modernising and freeing up the economy.
In 1987-88, at page 2:
. . . our economic strategy is now bearing fruit.
In 1988-89, at page 1:
We are now on the way back to prosperity.
In 1989-90, at page 2:
The challenge before us now is to get the best from this stronger economic structure.
Then, in 1990-91:
Economic policy has worked and is working.

Why is it that Australia has this huge overseas debt crisis if we have been on track for seven years? Why is it that we have a high inflation rate, double that of our major trading partners, when the Government says the economic policies have been working? If the economic policies of this Government had been working, we would not have a huge overseas debt crisis, we would not have an inflation rate that is double that of our trading partners, we would not have interest rates that are at least 1 1/2 times those of many other countries, and we would not have rising unemployment.

It is total nonsense for the Treasurer to come into this House this year and say that the economic policies of the Government have been working. People have lost faith in this Government. I shall illustrate three different areas in which they have lost faith: the way in which the Government has treated the States; the way in which it has treated people at a personal level; and the way in which it has dealt with the responsibility of people in the welfare system.

Let us first look at the States. This Government has said repeatedly, 'We are going to cut our budget. We have to cut our cloth so that it fits'. What one finds, however, is that the way in which this Government treats the States is markedly different to the sort of cost cutting it undertakes as the Federal Government. In 1982-83 the amount of money out of Federal revenue returned to the States was 40 per cent of the Federal Budget. Now, seven years later, 30 per cent of Federal Budget outlays is returned to the States.

The Government has been saying to the people that it has to cut its expenditure; but where has that expenditure been cut? It has been cut at the State level, but the Federal Government has not cut its own Budget to the same extent. The reason for that, and no doubt it has been a purposeful, reasoned strategy, is that the Government wanted to increase the power of Canberra. This Government likes centralising power in Canberra and taking it away from the regions of Australia, therefore controlling as much as possible from Canberra.

Those double standards have led to the great degree of cynicism now evident in the Australian population. On the one hand the Government says that the States must cut their Budgets, but federally over seven years effectively the Federal Government has not cut its Budget to anywhere near the same extent as it has cut the Budgets of the States.

Secondly, many responsible people in our community see the welfare system as undermining stable social structures rather than buttressing the values that strengthen the quality of life in the community. I have some figures, which were up to date in about 1988, which show that a single income family with a dependent wife and two dependent children received, if they stayed together, about $2,000 of government support. If they separated, in effect they were $150 a week, or about $7,500 to $8,000 a year, better off. The system in Australia at present does not buttress those who take a responsible attitude to nurturing children, but actually encourages people to separate, because the financial benefits are at least $150 a week if a couple breaks up or separates. It is tragic when the Government actually gives a financial incentive to people to be irresponsible and not nurture their children in a caring family environment.

Thirdly, parents have had their authority undermined, and that is especially so in regard to Medicare. A child of the age of 14 can demand privacy, can choose not to tell the parents something. The parents do not have a right to know, if the child wants otherwise. It is tragic that that sort of situation is developing in Australia for it undermines stable social structures in the community. All honourable members will be aware of many situations, particularly with regard to accommodation in housing commission homes in different States, where people, especially unmarried mothers-and I realise they do have to be cared for-have sought placement in commission housing. One finds that in the allocation of accommodation a single unmarried mother often will get preference over a married couple with one or two children.

What is being encouraged in this country? Do these attitudes encourage responsibility or discourage it? These days many people in the community query the very types of values that this Government has put in place.

At the personal level, to illustrate what has happened, from 1982-83 to 1990-91 income tax in this country has increased by 102 per cent. In the same period the average weekly earnings that people are being paid have increased by only 48 per cent. I can go on. The honourable member for Brisbane spoke about how much the Government had done for age pensioners. Their benefit has increased by 58 per cent, but revenue to the Federal Government has gone up 102 per cent in the same time. This Government has been sucking in much more taxation than ever before, and that money has not been returned to the ordinary citizens of this country. One would expect that if taxation revenue increased by about 100 per cent, unemployment benefits might have gone up by a similar percentage. They have not increased by anywhere near that margin, but by only 65 per cent. With regard to education, Austudy has increased by 68 per cent.

What are the Government's policies? I was interested to note today when listening to the debate on the matter of public importance that it seemed that Government members were able to espouse the Opposition's policies, or purported policies, better than they could state their own policies. If one went into the community and asked what was the telecommunications policy of the Labor Party at this stage, nobody would have a clue. The faceless people behind the Labor Party will have to make that decision next week-not the Cabinet, not the shadow Minister, not the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke); people unelected to this Parliament will make that decision.

We have the situation of Keating versus Beazley and at the same time the Prime Minister wipes his hands of the whole issue. What about shipping and the waterfront? What is the Government's policy on this? How is the situation being revitalised and cleaned up? Why is it that it costs more for a container of products to go 130 miles from King Island in my electorate to Melbourne than for it to go from Melbourne to Glasgow? Why does that occur in Australia? The material is processed in Scotland and the alginate from the seaweed comes from King Island.

—I have been there several times.

—I know my electorate like the back of my hand. Why do we have that situation in Australia? In this debate it has also been illustrated that it is cheaper to send a car from Melbourne to the west coast of America than it is to send a car from Melbourne to Tasmania. SPEECH.PARA: In the area of industrial relations, all of the work practices are holding this country back and we are becoming more and more inefficient and less able to be competitive because the Government will not tackle the unions which give it its support. The Government will not address those issues. What is the Government's policy on inflation and the overseas debt-these two factors which are crucial to the way that Australia's economy is going?
