In particular key areas we are waiting until this coming week to see which way the Government will jump after the people who are not elected to this Parliament give them their riding orders.

Unfortunately, this Budget has failed to address the economic issues which confront Australia at this time. It is a lost opportunity and it is a great tragedy that this Government has come back into power in this country and has not been able to get its act together and bring down a Budget which will help solve Australia's pressing economic situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not amazing how differently two people can see the same document? This is a very weighty document, and in my remarks tonight I would like to consider the ways in which this document reflects the kinds of priorities that are appropriate for dealing with Australia's economic problems. Most honourable members who speak in the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91 dwell either-as the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) has done in most of his remarks-on the macro-economic side of it or choose to dwell on individual programs. I would like to take a third tack and look at the priorities for expenditure programs that are a part of the Budget. That is very rarely talked about, but if one looks through this Budget one can see that some areas of expenditure have risen quite substantially because they directly reflect the Government's priorities. Those priorities, I expect, could be very simply summarised as covering two major areas-either economic development or social justice.

SPEECH.PARA: The major national economic problem at present, most people would agree, is the size of the current account deficit. The question, therefore, is: What can be done by government to improve the dynamism of the economy so as to build up our capacity to export? There is a macro- economic question concerning what can be done to restrain imports as well, but the Budget, through positive fiscal policy, can build up our capacity to export, which involves increasing national productivity.

The social justice question-the other main orientation of government policy-some people would call simply the quality of government services. The Budget does a lot to improve the quality of government services in a whole host of areas. I would like to go through and dwell upon the broad priorities that are reflected in these spending decisions. Firstly, I would like to mention two major areas of restraint which have made these other areas of growth in outlays possible.

The most obvious, of course, is that public debt interest in this Budget is 22.4 per cent lower in real terms than it was in 1989-90. That means that public debt interest is, in fact, $1,270m less this financial year than it was in the previous financial year. Of course, that is a direct result of the Government's fiscal restraint. The Government has been running a surplus for some years now. The benefit of that has been that it has been able to pay back a lot of public debt, and therefore it has been able to reduce the level of public debt interest. So it has $1,270m more this year which it can use on high priority outlays.

The second area that is very important and where I think there is scope for still more restraint is defence expenditure. In the last couple of years we have seen an improvement in the global strategic situation that is quite unprecedented in the post-war period. The Cold War is over and the superpowers have come to a number of agreements which have allowed them to sign disarmament agreements in several areas. They are both substantially reducing their defence expenditure and that is also happening in a number of the major western European countries. It is very appropriate, therefore, that Australia should be able to restrain its own defence expenditure. In fact, defence expenditure is up by 5.8 per cent in money terms, but that means that it is maintaining the real level of defence expenditure rather than increasing it.

The saving from not going ahead with an earlier planned 2 per cent real increase in defence expenditure is $161m in 1990-91. That is a very important saving. Of course, some people would note that we are now involved in a conflict in Iraq and that will increase the demands on our defence vote. That is absolutely true, but within a Budget of nearly $9 billion-$8,970m-it should be possible to cope with the outlays that are involved in the Iraqi conflict without too much trouble.

Those two areas of restraint have created the opportunity for the Government to increase substantially its outlays in a number of very important areas which will directly contribute to increasing the dynamism of the economy or improving community services. I would like to go through a selected number of areas which I regard as being of very high priority and which have been substantially improved in this Budget. I will do that in the order in which they are shown in the Budget statements, not in any order of priority, because it makes this speech easier to prepare.

The honourable member for Braddon drew attention to the problem of marriage breakdown. That is a major problem in our society and, therefore, anyone concerned with that problem will warmly welcome the increase in allocations for marriage counselling. The Budget includes a promise that support for marriage counselling and family mediation will rise by $15m over three years from 1990-91-an increase of 13.7 per cent. That is a very significant increase. In my own electorate the allocation for marriage counselling will go up by 60 per cent-something that I have been strongly urging and which I wholeheartedly welcome. I think that the funds will be particularly well spent. Marriage counselling is a very cost-effective activity.

Another area where the Budget has allocated a substantial increase to outlays is education. Education outlays rise by 14 per cent, which is an increase of $920m or 7.3 per cent in real terms. In terms of the possible ways in which we could increase the productivity of the Australian economy, it is hard to imagine any area which is of a higher priority than education. Education is also a tremendously important community service, which meets the goals of improving both the dynamism and the social justice of the economy.

There is a whole series of components to that increase in education spending. For example, there are increases in higher education student places, the cost of which is $130m. I wholeheartedly welcome the increase in higher education capital funding of $89m. Yesterday I visited the Australian National University for its open day. One of the principal messages that the senior administrators from that university wanted to convey to me was the need for more capital investment in the university. For some years now the university has been unable to improve its capital equipment. The increase in the Budget will allow that kind of improvement to occur in universities throughout Australia.

There are to be continuing real increases in general recurrent per capita funding for schools and an increase in Austudy payments. This is important not only to increase the number of students attending universities but also to improve the support they receive. So there are a whole lot of initiatives in that education program which anyone concerned with either the economy or community services would welcome.

Another one which is worth mentioning is the additional funding for migrant education, $10.8m. On Friday I opened a new migrant English language centre in the ACT. It is centrally located and provides a very important service for new arrivals so that they can move effectively into the Australian community and get effective employment.

Another area of outlays which many people will welcome is the 12.1 per cent increase in spending on culture and recreation. In a country which has a very high level of media concentration, the roles of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) are especially important. Yet the ABC and SBS are receiving the same real level of funding as was provided in 1989-90, namely, $33m additionally. Quite frankly, I do not think that is nearly enough but at least it maintains the real level of their outlays, and that is an important aspect of the Budget.

As well as that, there is additional funding to upgrade and expand national transmitting facilities. I am particularly glad to see that because for some time I have been talking in the House on the problem of receiving even ABC radio in a number of areas. Those transmitting facilities will allow a greater proportion of Australians to receive the ABC clearly.

Now I turn to some of the economic services where the outlays have been increased. These are centrally important in expanding the dynamism of the economy. The area of transport and communication, for example, receives an increase of 14 per cent or 7.4 per cent in real terms. A lot of those funds are to be used for increased payments for roads. During the last election campaign there was a lot of debate about roads and the Government promised to increase that funding. It has fulfilled that promise: the increased payments for roads comprise $100m for the provincial cities and rural highways program; $53m for the road safety improvement program; and $25m for the establishment of an urban public transport program. Indexation of the Australian centennial roads development program permits an allocation of $91m. So that is a very substantial increase in total road funding, which will be welcomed by every driver in Australia.

In relation to another centrally important area of outlays, labour and employment, there is also a substantial real increase of 8.2 per cent, a 15 per cent increase in money terms. At a time when regrettably unemployment is rising again, it is very important to provide programs which will maximise the opportunity of getting those unemployed back into employment. That is why the Government has substantially increased funding for employment programs. That increase includes, for example, an increase in the number of disadvantaged job seekers expected to be assisted under the various labour market programs, including Jobtrain, $28m; the early intervention program, $7m; the new enterprise incentive scheme, $6.1m; and Skillshare, $15m.

I should like to draw attention to the new enterprise incentive scheme, which provides funds to encourage people to start small businesses themselves. In other words, the Government is encouraging entrepreneurship. That is one of the most cost-effective ways of getting people back into productive work. There are also increased funds for a number of existing programs like Newstart and JET and for apprenticeships. That too is an area which will increase the dynamism and the social justice of the economy.

I want to turn to an area which is of the highest priority for building up the dynamism of the economy, and that is scientific research. There can hardly be any area of Government outlays which in the long run makes a bigger impact on the productivity of the economy, on our capacity for innovation and, therefore, our capacity to export. It is particularly pleasing to note in the Budget that spending on general and scientific research is to rise by 19 per cent. That is a total level of spending this year of $763m, an increase of $122m or 12 per cent in real terms. That is a substantial increase in a Budget which was severely restrained by macro-economic considerations. Outlays are expected to increase in real terms in each of the forward years as well. Those increases this year go towards the introduction of the cooperative research centres program, which was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his election policy speech.

That is a particularly important program, which I wholeheartedly welcome. I am sure that all honourable members who are concerned about the dynamism of the economy will welcome that program. Certainly it has been warmly welcomed by the scientific and scholarly community in Australia. It will lead to $100m a year being spent within about three years on cooperative research centres.

In addition, funding for research infrastructure in higher education institutions rises by $34m, as announced earlier by the Government. There is additional funding for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), which has risen by $5m. I should like to see that figure increased substantially. The CSIRO is a scientific research body of which Australians can be particularly proud. It has built up a major international reputation for the quality of its work. It has been restrained until recently and its funding needs to be substantially increased further.

Another area which has received substantial funding this year is environmental research, for which funding has gone up by $14m. In addition, the Commonwealth provides considerable support for industry research and development. It is important, of course, not only that we have public sector research but also that the Government support private sector research. It has had a major program for some years now through the extraordinarily generous 150 per cent tax deduction arrangements which were begun in July 1985 and which are estimated to cost this financial year $200m in forgone revenue. That is a major incentive to the private sector to increase its research and development.

There is one final area that I would like to dwell on and that is overseas aid. We have a responsibility through our foreign affairs concerns to express our social justice commitments internationally as well as locally. A billion people are living in absolute poverty internationally, the larger proportion of them in our region. We therefore have a very strong humanitarian as well as strategic motivation for our overseas development assistance. It has been very difficult for the Government to build up its overseas aid, but in this Budget, I am absolutely delighted to say, there is a real increase of 1.7 per cent. That is a substantial increase in money terms on the previous year.

I congratulate the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) for having persuaded his Cabinet colleagues of the importance of that. He will be wholeheartedly supported by hundreds of thousands of Australians who want to see our overseas aid increased. It was very impressive to see during the election campaign the 25,000 people who sent cards to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). It was regrettable that, despite that, the Opposition in the election campaign said that it would reduce overseas aid by $100m. The Government said it would maintain the real level of aid; it has done so and done slightly better than that. I congratulate the Government for that piece of enlightened social justice, which is also significant in economic development terms.

This Budget reflects the central priorities of the Government, but also, I think, of the majority of people in the community. It will contribute to increasing the dynamism of our economy. It will contribute to increasing our exports in both the medium term and the long term. I congratulate the Government on that and hope that those priorities will be reflected in future Budgets as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak in this Budget debate. In this context I would like to draw the House's attention to the estimated outlays in the 1990-91 Budget of $9,253.5m for the Department of Employment, Education and Training, otherwise known as DEET. It is my belief that the proportion of this allocation used to foster the so-called education export industry should be reduced, as the industry no longer has the support of the Australian people. The claims of enormous revenues to be generated are turning out to be nothing more than a product of a fevered imagination.

SPEECH.PARA: I stated in the grievance debate speech on immigration which I presented to this House on 31 May 1990 that I would be conducting a survey to determine the attitudes of my electorate to the current immigration policy. With the assistance of my staff and volunteers from the Liberal Party of Australia I have carried out the survey. Over 550 people in my electorate were telephoned on a random survey basis from 9 July to 10 August. Given that the Deakin electorate is middle urban Australian in composition and given that it is regarded as a marginal seat, the results of the survey should interest a number of members. Those responsible for setting our immigration targets might regard our present immigration policy as about right and enlightened or, as I have heard it described, even `adventurist'-that is, leading public opinion for the supposed good of the nation. My survey would suggest differently. I put it to the House that the policy is now so removed from general public support that its very existence is a source of community divisiveness. It is in great need of radical reform.

The survey findings present a gloomy picture of immigration policy in Australia today. Sixty per cent of respondents were dissatisfied with the Federal Labor Government's immigration policy. Fifty-seven per cent would prefer Australia to recruit only skilled migrants. Forty-one per cent would prefer those migrants to come from the United Kingdom or Europe. Many of those who stated that our migrants should be admitted from around the world often clarified this statement by saying there should be an even blend of migrants and that no one group should dominate the program.

Fifty-seven per cent believe that ethnic lobby groups have too much influence over government immigration policy. Many, it appears, now believe they have no control over the destiny of their own nation. Decisions affecting the future of all of us are now made by the faceless men and women of the `Immigration Club'. Forty-six per cent believe the Federal Government should not have given the Chinese students the right to remain in Australia. Sixty-five per cent believe these students should not qualify for government grants or benefits. Finally, 76 per cent-a very high proportion-believe that illegal immigrants should be deported.
The people of Deakin would no doubt support the recommendation in the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, which states:

Anyone who is illegally in Australia by unauthorised stay beyond the expiry of a visa, or by illegal entry, should forfeit the right to apply for immigration while here or be automatically rejected if they have already applied.

The electorate would be critical of the recent report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, as many of my colleagues have been, as it presents a watered down solution to the problem of illegal migrants. We have only to talk to the man in the street to realise that many Australians are unsure of the future, believe our nation is being fragmented by competing cultures and languages and believe that Australians are being persuaded to forget their heritage in order to accommodate everybody else.

I turn to the education export industry, which has become almost another immigration scheme. Much has been made of the benefits of this industry to Australia, with the Government claiming it could become one of our biggest export earners. A report in the Australian Financial Review of 18 June of this year claimed that in the 1989-90 financial year one section of this industry, the English language intensive courses for overseas students, otherwise known as ELICOS, had revenues of $58m. While this might sound an impressive figure, there has been no allowance for the costs involved in producing that revenue.

It is possible to obtain accurate costings of some elements of the ELICOS program. The cost now includes social security payments to those ELICOS and other students from the People's Republic of China whom the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has allowed to remain in Australia. I believe this will be in the order of $50m. Additionally, there are the costs involved in repaying deposits to the at least 5,000 Chinese students-probably more on some estimates-who, due to visa changes, no longer qualified for a visa but who had already paid their course deposit. I am led to believe this will cost between $30m and $50m. But what are the costs incurred by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in policing the expired visas?

There is also the cost to the community arising from liquidation of those schools which entered the industry in good faith, but which now, due to government policy, have been forced to close. The changes have put hundreds of Australians out of work and disrupted the studies of the students. In a move which has all the hallmarks of the Pyramid settlement, the Hawke Government is not only paying the living allowances of those students who lost money when those colleges collapsed but also has come to an agreement with the remaining companies in the industry to accept the students from firms that collapse at reduced rates, with the Australian taxpayer, once again, picking up the tab.

Finally, there is another major cross the Government has failed to take into account. Students on the whole either borrow the funds for their courses in their home countries and repay those loans with the money they earn in Australia or they bring to this country their spouses, who work to repay the loan. Either way, more money is sent out of Australia than is actually brought in. I suggest the total of these costs far exceeds the revenues.

Much has been written about the corrupt practices in which the English language schools have been involved. In a speech to the ELICOS industry the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) said in part that there was a perception around that the private sector was being run by a motley collection of sharks, spivs and fast buck merchants. Whilst I partly agree with the Minister, there is obviously more than one guilty party.

It is particularly incumbent upon the Minister to look at his own responsibilities in this area. It is clear that little attention has been paid by the Minister to the Department responsible for administering the ELICOS scheme, his own Department, the Department of Employment, Education and Training. This Department appears to have been placed in somewhat of a dilemma. It was faced with the problem of whether it should charge full steam ahead in this new and potentially profitable export education industry or take a more conservative approach and endeavour to protect the fee-paying students, the reputation of this new industry and the migration program.

DEET, I am told, was aware of major problems with the ELICOS scheme from as early as 1987, only one year after the industry commenced as a money-making venture. DEET, with the support of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, chose to ignore the rorts, the impact on migration policy and the reputation of the industry, and concentrated instead on trying to make a quick quid.

The first consequence of this approach was that a large number of students from the People's Republic of China obviously saw the loophole in the scheme and fully exploited it. It has been estimated that 27 per cent of the thousands of Chinese students who entered Australia as students in 1988-89 stayed on in this country to become illegal immigrants.

As a result of the public outcry, the Government has ordered a crackdown. In its later form this has meant that 30 Chinese students who are now illegal immigrants have been detained and held in the Maribyrnong detention centre in Melbourne; a number have since been released, have escaped or, after assaulting the attendants, have been transferred to Pentridge prison. The problem is that if the Government wants to detain any more of the thousands of Chinese students who are now illegal migrants it cannot use the Maribyrnong centre as it is now full.

As a further consequence of the crackdown we have recently had a number of collapses of companies involved in the export education industry, with the most recent ones being the Academy of English and its sister company Riddell Commercial College Pty Ltd. The former director of planning and projects at the Academy of English, Mr Frank Young, claims that almost half of the 115 ELICOS schools operating around Australia early this year have now closed.

With each collapse come further documents highlighting DEET's failings. The documents show that the schools have tried to abide by the letter of the law. DEET has deferred and changed decisions all too often for the benefit of the student rather than the interests of this country.

I would like to refer to some of the correspondence that I have recently received. The first is a letter from the now defunct Academy of English dated 16 July of this year which was sent to Mr B. Hogan of the section in DEET responsible for ELICOS-the overseas student section, previously called the overseas student office (OSO). It says in part:
We are aware that students have been granted extension of visa below that level (90 per cent attendance) on representation to OSO.
By way of background I should explain that 90 per cent attendance means that students are allowed to miss only one day out of every 10 working days.

The Academy of English was not the only one aware of DEET's policy. In a letter to OSO on 27 June 1990, seeking guidance, L. V. International Business College, one of the few still in operation, complained that the student Kishore Kumare had been expelled from the school on two occasions and had an attendance level of 30 per cent. The school appears to have abided by the Government's requirements but the Melbourne office of DEET kept authorising Kishore Kumare's return to school.

If the Government policy called for attendance levels of 90 per cent, why has DEET allowed students who have not achieved this rate the right to remain in Australia? One possible reason for this lack of action is hinted at by a former teacher at one of the colleges. The teacher, Ms Sharon Levy, claims that less than 10 per cent of her Chinese ELICOS students actually met attendance requirements. In effect, I believe DEET was overwhelmed by the problem and hoped, by ignoring it, that it would go away.

Judging from discussions I have had, there is a strong indication that some DEET officers are only too willing to give blanket approval for the extension of visas. The schools whose profit depends on student numbers, once aware of this weakness, exploited it at every conceivable opportunity. This policy also had tragic consequences. Taylors College wrote to DEET in July 1988 advising that the Malaysian Chinese business studies student Yap Hai Foong had been asked to leave as his behaviour, attendance and grades were not up to standard. Rather than being deported, this individual was allowed by DEET to re-enrol in another college, Riddells, which has also recently closed.

Mr Yap Hai Foong next came to notice in October 1988 when, with a colleague, he attempted to rob a TAB agency in South Yarra, Melbourne. Stopped by police, Yap was shot by a policeman. This tragic event may well have been avoided if DEET had taken a firm stand on this matter much earlier, as it should have done.

There is some indication that the Victorian office of DEET is the easiest of all for students to exploit. I have been advised that at least one student facing deportation in Queensland on the recommendation of the local DEET office simply moved to Melbourne, enrolled in a new course, hired a solicitor, convinced the Melbourne office that Queensland had the facts wrong, and had the decision reversed. It strikes me as somewhat illogical that DEET does not have a consistent national policy on this matter. It is not only the schools that have expressed frustration with DEET. Numerous landlords in Melbourne have advised DEET that their tenants are rorting the system. It appears that DEET takes as much notice of the landlords' information as it does of the formal advice from the schools.

In its efforts to assist the export educ- ation industry the Government has licensed some very unusual courses. One of the few growth areas at the moment is the kung-fu schools. Whilst I applaud their `coals to Newcastle' success in attracting students, I am seriously concerned that ELICOS students are withdrawing from their courses and enrolling in this softer option or, alternatively, extending their stay in Australia by enrolling in these non-formal courses.

One of the major kung-fu schools is the World Wing Academy, although it was previously called the Wing Chun school. DEET conducted an investigation of this school and found widespread evidence of abuses, primarily related to the fact that, although the school had 450 students enrolled, on the two occasions DEET inspectors visited the school they found a total of only 10 students. DEET, in a surprising act of vigilance-most remarkable for DEET, given its record-actually suspended the school as a course provider. In an act which is perhaps more typical of DEET's behaviour, the suspension was mysteriously lifted some months later. Although the school was allowed to accept only 100 students, this, too, has changed. It is now, for some strange reason, allowed to accept 200.

I notice from media reports that in this Budget session the Minister for Employment, Education and Training is proposing to introduce legislation which will clean up the industry. The legislation, according to the media reports, will require that the approved institutions maintain trust accounts for student deposits. There is no mention of legislation requiring DEET to tighten up the administration of its program. Given its previous maladministration, there should certainly be such a tightening up.

At this stage there is no sign of the proposed legislation. The whole country is aware of the boasts the Labor Government has made about the potential bonanzas from the industries it has sponsored. I am sure the whole country is now aware that these boasts, when made about the export education industry, are just the flim-flam of snake oil salesmen. The industry does need to be cleaned up and so does the body that monitors its performance-that is, the Department of Employment, Education and Training.
In conclusion, I seek leave to table correspondence that I have already referred to from the Academy of English in Melbourne and the L. V. International Business College.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This years' Budget, like Budgets in previous years, is based on the integration of three arms of government policy: economic policy, environment policy and the Government's successful social justice strategy. As outlined in the statement circulated at the time of the Budget under the heading `Social Justice in the 1990s', with the Government's active social policy now in place and with an impressive record of income security and welfare reform already achieved in the 1980s, the Government now intends to extend its social justice strategy.

SPEECH.PARA: As an important part of the extension of that social justice strategy, the Government will be undertaking two major reviews. The first of these is the national housing strategy. Since 1983 the Government has been involved a great expansion of funding for public housing and a rearrangement of those measures that have ended up with large increases in the levels of rent assistance available to the disadvantaged, pensioners and beneficiaries.

Integral to those arrangements has been the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. That agreement allowed for innovative ways of arranging funding for both public and private residents and flexible tenure choices to deliver housing stock to those who were most in need. The aims of the strategy will be to analyse the various demographic and other factors involved, contribute to the assessment of how responsive housing policy is at the moment, and also look further at innovative ways of providing appropriate and affordable housing, especially for those on low incomes and those with special needs. It will look at remedying some of the fundamental structural problems in the overall housing market and, importantly, will explore the linkages between the provision of housing, employment and other infrastructure, especially community services.

The second major review that is presently being undertaken is the national health strategy review. Basically this arises out of the need to put in place new Medi- care arrangements in two or three years time. This opportunity has been taken to have a wide review of overall health policy. An important aspect of that review that is wider than just looking at the reagreement of the Medicare arrangements is the consideration of better integration of health and community services. Again we see a review that intends to highlight the need for linkages between different areas of policy provision. Importantly, it will also look at some of those public health services, especially in preventative health, that have perhaps been neglected over recent times.

At the same time as these two major national reviews are being undertaken, this year's Budget places importance upon further investigation of what is known as locational disadvantage. During the campaign before the last election, especially as highlighted in the election policy speech, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) indicated the Federal Government's willingness to pay particular attention to the needs of the urban fringes of our major cities.

This is particularly of interest to me because my electorate, being on the northern urban fringe of Melbourne, suffers many of the things that have been loosely identified as locational disadvantage. We have newer areas where people go to make their home, away from both physical and social infrastructure, which leads to all sorts of pressures, not only on an individual's personal well-being but also on the well-being of families.

Some of the important things that the Government hopes to tackle under the heading of locational disadvantage are access to jobs, training and educational opportunities and recreational facilities. This is very much about looking at people's access to important facilities throughout all stages of their lives.

Access to social infrastructure means looking at adequate support devices that are often not there when people move into newer suburbs. In my particular area we have new suburbs which have gone into municipalities which are already facing a great deal of pressure because of underservicing. I have spoken on a number of occasions in this place about the need to address these deficiencies as well as the adequate provision in newer urban areas of the types of facilities that people require, especially when they are just starting a family-a time when the economic pressures are quite overwhelming and are exacerbated by trying to set up a home in a newer area. My electorate also has a very high migrant population. Some of the issues of the Government's present migration policy have to be looked at.

As with the national housing strategy review and the national health strategy review, one of the important aspects that has to be recognised in looking at urban fringe development is that no matter how much goodwill the Commonwealth Government has it cannot achieve anything by itself. A number of the responsibilities are shared with State and local governments and some of the responsibilities belong directly to State and local governments. For instance, if we look at the responsibility for land use and transport planning, we find that these are very much the cooperative effort of State and local government.

Whilst we should quite rightly have a major interest in these issues, often that fact has been overlooked. At least in this term of office the Government has put itself on notice to the public that it is willing to look at these issues and, wherever possible, to become actively involved in the planning and delivery of services.

I know that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, share the frustration of a number of people in this place. That is, when we look at a number of the programs that emanate from the Federal Government we find that they are often either delivered by a State government or delivered with the cooperation of a State government. Often the contribution of the Commonwealth Government is overlooked. There is nothing more frustrating than when something in one's electorate is announced and duly some representative of the State Government goes ahead and takes full credit for what is occurring. As I said, this is the source of a great deal of frustration to some of us. I know that on some occasions it has been a great source of frustration for you, Mr Deputy Speaker.

Another frustration is when one goes out to try to lobby on behalf of the community or a community group and tries to exert some pressure on Federal Ministers, only to be told, 'No, it is under a Commonwealth-State arrangement and it is best that you try to lobby the State Minister'. We really need to look at some of these issues.

I was pleased to see the speech that was made by the Prime Minister at the National Press Club on 19 July entitled `Towards a closer partnership'. He addressed a number of the problems that confront Australia as it goes into the twenty-first century-problems that arise from the way in which the Federation actually works.
Australia's second Prime Minister and one of the Founding Fathers, Alfred Deakin, once said about Federation:

To those who watched its inner workings, followed its fortunes as if their own, and lived a life of devotion to it day by day, its actual accomplishment must always appear to have been secured by a series of miracles.

If miracles were needed to found the Federation, it is difficult to imagine what it would take to reform it, especially if it requires a change to the Constitution. It is a sad fact that throughout Australia's history as a nation there has been tremendous difficulty achieving constitutional reform. Of the 42 proposals to alter the Constitution since Federation, only eight have been successful.

The Constitution was hammered out in the 1890s to meet the needs of Australia in a new century. Australia was then a vastly different place with different needs, and was part of a different international community. We should remember that at that time the sun had not set on the British Empire. When our predecessors went down to the Parliament in Melbourne at that time they were able to either take a steamship or come down by train. Communication was much different. The print media was dominant.

There is no reason to assume that the provisions of the Constitution are appropriate to respond to the needs of Australia as we prepare for the twenty-first century. As Sir Robert Menzies, a person whom I am not usually driven to quote, said in 1967:

A written Constitution is an express scheme of Government designed to give a basic structure in a changing world, not designed to inhibit growth in a growing world, nor to make the contemporary world subject to the political, social or economic ideas of a bygone age.
Is not that exactly what is happening today? The anecdotes are well known but worth recalling. The Prime Minister exemplified this in his address that I mentioned earlier at the National Press Club.

A cargo container being sent by rail between Sydney and Perth may be subject to three non-integrated rail systems, four changes of locomotives, five different safe working systems, six different sizes of loading gauge, 10 different engineering standards of basic standard gauge rail track, and 12 or more hours at sidings or junctions for crew changes, refuelling and inspections. Obviously in reforming our national rail network we need to overcome these hurdles that Federation has placed before us.

Let us take another area-education. It is sad to say that school children in different States of Australia learn different systems of handwriting. This is a symptom of a wider malaise. In May 1988 the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) highlighted the need for a national perspective on schooling to help Australia adjust to current economic and social pressures. Among other things he identified the need for curriculum reform and especially the development of a common curriculum. A Curriculum Corporation of Australia has been launched to develop cooperative curriculum materials on behalf of State education Ministers. A statement of common principles and agreed areas for collaborative action of curriculum development for mathematics was developed by the Australian Education Council.

This statement, commonly known as the Hobart declaration on Australian schools, clearly sets out the mathematical knowledge and skills to which all Australian students are entitled. The significance of the Hobart declaration should not be underestimated. Further areas of curriculum reform have been and are being developed as flagged in this Budget. Beyond this it is to be hoped that a comprehensive national curriculum is on the horizon.

No-one could doubt the overwhelming success of the Government's home and community care (HACC) program, first introduced by the Government in the 1984-85 Budget. This program involves the participation of all three spheres of Government and the community sector. Despite the undoubted success of this innovative program, it became apparent after a period of operation that differences in standards, service levels and interpretations of the program guidelines had developed between States.

In the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration entitled There's No Place Like Home, which reviewed the efficiency audit of the HACC program, some of these issues were identified. In evidence before the Committee, the Australian Office for the Aged stated:
Whenever you have a joint administration you are going to get friction and overlap and administration falling down cracks.

In Victoria there have been some problems in relation to the definition of the HACC target group. In his recent address to the National Press Club, the Prime Minister suggested that the welfare area is an appropriate starting point for a review of Commonwealth-State relations. I agree with this. In fact, much of the necessary review of the HACC program and the problems it has encountered has taken place in various reviews such as the Auditor-General's review and review of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. So there is a good basis for starting to eliminate inequality and inefficiency where it has arisen. The Commonwealth is implementing the first national system of needs-based planning for aged services. It is important for the national Government to ensure that all Australians have equal access to equal services.

Let us look at further disparities as a result of Federation. Each State has its own separate design requirements for water meters and its own standards for chemicals used in agriculture. We have different road laws, driving licences, product packaging and safety standards. One State demands that margarine be sold only in a package shaped like a cube. I could go on. As Europe proceeds inexorably towards complete economic union in 1992, Australia languishes in a Federal system designed to satisfy the vested interests of the 1890s.

Tackling these issues should be the agenda for micro-economic reform, not simple questions of ownership. What Australia needs in the 1990s is to confront the question of reform of the Federal system. No-one could deny that the functions and roles of all spheres of government have not vastly changed since the Second World War. Local councils now provide a vast range of services beyond those provided even 20 years ago. Long gone are the days of the three Rs of local government-roads, rubbish and rates.

As people's expectations have changed so too have the requirements of our system of government. The recognition of the need for reform of our Federal system is long standing. As Don Dunstan said in the 1970s:

The system as a whole is inefficient and debilitating. And as the years pass the writing of the Constitution becomes enveloped in the mists of time, that well known contagion of Federated States can be seen developing high-minded reverence for the Founding Fathers. Any criticism of their document becomes a kind of political blasphemy. They are even now being seen as far-sighted, despite the fact that when they drew the document up about the only matters they considered crucial to national Government were defence, an end to customs barriers and an efficient post office . . .
In fact, as Dunstan went on to point out, the Founding Fathers were State politicians protecting their State interests. He said:

We are now left with the results of their work; a system of sovereign governments whose boundaries bear no relation to physical, social or economic geography, and which are limited in their attempts to legislate efficiently in such important areas as trade practices or national transport because the framers of the Constitution on the one hand did not believe that governments should be concerned with the economy or business practices, and on the other they foresaw no problems emerging.

It is not true to say, however, that the Founding Fathers gave no significant domestic powers to the Commonwealth. In fact, the Federal Government has far more access to the financial resources of the nation than under comparable federal systems. In Australia approximately 77 per cent of total public revenue is raised by the Federal Government. This compares with 62 per cent in the United States, 51 per cent in Canada and 49 per cent in West Germany. If anything, the federal system is unbalanced.

There is no area where the policy difference between the Labor and Liberal-National parties is so stark than in relation to the reform of the role and power of the Federal Government. Many commentators regarded the Whitlam Government's attempts to resolve this imbalance as one of a centralist government, but this was not the case. Certainly the Whitlam Government tested as never before the extent of the Commonwealth Government's powers in relation to domestic affairs, and certainly that Government, to its credit, explored the greater involvement of the Commonwealth in the provision of an array of services. But the Whitlam Government was as much regionalist as it was centralist. It was under the reforms of that Government that considerable power was devolved to local government.

As Australia heads for the next century facing great challenges as a nation, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has put forward some half-baked schemes such as giving the States the power to raise their own revenue along with other powers which will inevitably lead to greater barriers between them.

It is often said that Australia is over-governed. This may be so. In an era of mass communication perhaps it is the need for State governments that is waning. Ordinary Australians are appalled when the morass of bureaucratic overlap is pointed out to them. As the Prime Minister has said:
We have imposed upon ourselves a burden of different rules and regulations and requirements which needlessly weighs against the tremendous advantages we can have as a nation-continent.
