SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the nation sees the current Budget as a wasted opportunity, a chance after an election for an incoming government to show some vision and set out some plans for the next three years. Usually, the first Budget after coming to office is one in which the Government takes the hard decisions, realising in a practical political sense that that is the time when the community is most likely to assess the Government as doing what it was elected to do. The Government then has roughly a two-year period to put those plans in place and to gain popularity through the third Budget for the forthcoming election.

SPEECH.PARA: In this instance, the Government has adopted a Budget which says, in effect, that the nation should be steady as she sinks. This Budget does not contain one initiative or one vision for the future. In fact, the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in commencing his Budget Speech, said:
Economic policy has worked and is working.

For the people of Australia this Budget represents more of the same policies. When one looks at the result of the election, one sees that the community could not make up its mind as to which party it wanted to govern but in fact cast slightly more votes for the Opposition than it did for the Government. I would have thought that any wise government in those circumstances would say, `Let us pick up some of the best ideas from the Opposition. Let us use our own best ideas and get into place at the earliest opportunity a policy that we can consolidate over the forthcoming three-year term'.

The two to three years that is the life of a parliament in Australia give the Government at the most three opportunities for major economic impact. I do not think that everything should be done in the Budget, but coming so shortly after the election, following the swearing in of the Ministry and members of parliament, the Budget was the first opportunity for the Government to say that it had some idea of where the nation was heading. In fact, the Government, since its election, has given every impression that it did not expect to win and that Ministers came to office with half thought through ideas that they are now floundering to knock into shape as hard policies.

The half thought through ideas of the Government are not backed by detailed examination and research. In fact, one can run through the areas in which the Government is staggering at the moment and realise that in the areas of privatisation, work practices and wages policy, and the environment, the Government has no clear plan, no idea, no prospect for the future. The Government is dealing with each issue as it arises. That is a process of crisis management.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is virtually paralysed.

—That is a very good description. The Government is paralysed between periods of feverish activity. It is attempting to sort out the rights and wrongs of particular issues and as well deal with the furore and divisiveness of the back bench and the Caucus room, eventually to come forth with a policy that represents the Labor Party. In doing so, the Government is stretching a very long bow. Having belted factions into shape, conducted public meetings and gone through all the processes, the Government claims that that is the policy for all Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, it is not. It is a policy for a small group of people in Australia. It is a great shame that this incoming Government that has done much-not all of it good, not all of it bad; more bad than good, I would suggest-has no idea where it is going to be in three years time. It has no idea where Australia ought to be in three years time. It has no idea where the men and women and families of Australia should be in three years time. So, staggering from crisis to crisis, it gives every impression of being a government that is on its last legs. It does not have the will or the drive to carry forward the great responsibilities of government.

I guess there are many on the back bench of the Labor Party who are absolutely frustrated by this process. They are the people who have some ideas and want to see things done. Some of those people are on the extreme left of the Australian Labor Party and some of them are on the right. The trouble is that they are not communicating too well with each other on these important issues. They have not pre-planned the processes. They have not thought them through. In fact, the policies presented by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his election policy speech were a grab bag of ideas stitched together and presented in the usual slick manner to make them sound good. The Labor Party did not take the care to ascertain whether these policies could be translated into realistic on the ground legislation or decisions.

What does the Australian community want? The two main sections of the community I can identify that have really strong views are the Australian families and Australian small businesses. These groups seem to hold the key to much of the success of our nation. Small businesses want lower interest rates. They want enough skilled workers, a reasonable level of taxes, and they want to avoid having the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) control their businesses.

They are fairly simple and achievable goals. This Government could assist business to achieve those goals but it has no plan for those great employers of Australians. So, what is the result of not having a clear-cut goal? The result will be rising unemployment, businesses closing down, and pain and disaster for many Australian families. Those people are looking right down the barrel of a gun.

In my own electorate business after business is closing in the most painful, horrific ways. Some of them have been forced to close by some of the activities of slick money operators. Honourable members know the type. They are the friends of the Prime Minister. They are seen frequently at the Lodge. The Prime Minister telephones them for advice. I will not mention names, but they are at twenty-first birthday parties and all sorts of events together. These groups together run Australia as Australia Incorporated. They include a dozen people at the most.

Some of those people, by their callousness, have brought about needless pain to small businesses. Much of the pain, however, has been brought about by the conscious policies of the Government and the conscious policy of the Treasurer squeezing this country with high interest rates until enough businesses are broke for the Treasurer to say that the problem is fixed; until there is enough unemployment for him to say the problem is fixed; until there are enough taxes paid for him to say the problem is fixed; until there is enough compliance with the ACTU for him to say the problem is fixed; and until there is enough reduction of educated and skilled young people for him to say the problem is fixed. That is the policy instigated by the Treasurer. That is what he is saying here day after day. That is what he said in his Budget Speech-that the economic policy has worked and is working.

The other group, the families of Australia, want enough to live on, they want their jobs and they want to be left alone by government. One has only to look at the record of this Government to realise that the disposable income for each family has declined dramatically, especially over the last three to four years. At the end of the week the amount of money left which can be used for non-essentials has diminished. For those on fixed incomes, it has gone completely; they have no options left.

After multiple changes to all the retirement benefits of Australia-six or seven in fewer years-then fiddling at the margins with health schemes and pharmaceutical benefits, that group of people on fixed incomes are in a dreadful circumstance not understood by government. Their families the younger families of which they are still members-are now saying, 'How can we continue to support our older relatives in desperate days when we ourselves are meeting so much of our outgoings with higher interest rates and increasing inflation, extra cost every shopping day, extra cost every yearly family budget?' So these two groups-the small business community of Australia and the families of Australia-are the ones that are suffering most. Their needs are simple and straightforward, but the Government offers neither vision nor prospect for them. All the Treasurer can say is, 'Our economic policy has worked and is working'.

This Government is a crisis management government-do nothing: crisis: do nothing: crisis. Since it has been returned to office it has been one thing after another in that pattern-do nothing: crisis. Do not plan ahead; do not do anything to generate a strategy to solve a problem before it becomes serious but just stagger from one crisis to another.

One has only to look at some of the reports that came out in June, and I refer in particular to the quarterly business survey of the National Australia Bank. In June, I would like to tell honourable members opposite, there were precisely the problems that we are coping with now in September with this Budget, spelt out by one of those terrible National bankers. The survey shows that employment expectations by a range of employers were for increasing unemployment for the June quarter, for which they did not know the figures, for the September quarter and for subsequent quarters. The writing was on the wall then in the survey by the National Australia Bank. We can look through the manufacturing industries, the construction industry, retail, wholesale, transport, finance, and recreation industries, every one of which said, 'There is going to be increasing unemployment in the months ahead'. This is a survey conducted on a regular basis over hundreds of businesses.

Another question was: what is the expectation for the business? They said that jobs were going to be lost. When they were asked the question about their forward ordering situation-`What likelihood have you got in the next three to six months to extend your order book, pick up business and recover the situation of increasing unemployment?'-what did they answer? They said that their order books were getting worse and worse. Their expectations were down and down. Not only were they expecting to lay off people-and are now laying off people-but also they were not expecting any expansion in their businesses which would allow them to recover that situation. Throughout those areas of mining, manufacturing, construction, retail, wholesale, transport, finance and recreation, the expectation for the order book was bad news, disastrous news.

This is a staggering government-crisis: inaction: crisis: inaction-the sign of a government that is in absolute decay. It is a government with no plans for the future; a government which can do a deal with its mates in the Victorian Government to buy out its bank and then encourage that Government to spend more money in sponsoring the Olympic Games. Imagine it. The Victorian Government is an incompetent government, its incompetence proved over and over again with all of the fancy, shonky deals it went into, and this Government is going to allow, encourage, in fact sponsor that incompetent Government by bailing it out, first of all by buying its bankrupt bank and then by giving it dough to run the Olympic Games. Senator Walsh is right: why would we give that mob encouragement to spend anything?

Neville Wran had the opportunity to run the Olympic Games in the bicentennial year. He knocked it back. I think that was a tragedy. We could have had it in Australia in better times. We could have had it in Australia when people were more confident and had more money. But in this day and age, to encourage the mob in Victoria to run the Olympic Games is the last thing any responsible government should do.

Gross domestic product (GDP) is heading down. We only have to look at the figures for the last three years to see that. The gross and net debt is going up, and yet the Treasurer says, 'The economic policy has worked and is working'. Fancy that! So that is the Treasurer's policy: declining GDP, increasing gross and net debt, and the Treasurer saying, 'That is what I want'.

Over the period of the last few months I have mentioned the Government's do-nothing crisis in privatisation. We are right in the middle of it now. I do not know what revelation next Monday will bring. I see the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Walker) smiling. I spoke to one of his senatorial colleagues from New South Wales this morning, in fact, and he said that that was quite a meeting on privatisation held in New South Wales yesterday, and next Monday may well be the same. But here is the Government going out to a group of people that are not really supporting privatisation and putting its life in the hands of people who do not support it.

I support privatisation wholly and solely and we thought through detailed policies to privatise. As for Martin Ferguson and wages and work practices: goodness, gracious me, dark days! That is going back to the dark old days of confrontation. I had a lot of respect for Jack Ferguson, Martin's father. His word was his bond. He was a wonderful State member. He was of the left of the Labor Party, but he was a good bloke. However, Martin is out to make his mark and he is going to do it at the cost of the jobs of many thousands of Australians. He is going to put businesses out of operation just to suit his ego and make his mark. It is tragic that the Labor Government, which claims to represent those people, claims to be able to manage with accord after accord after accord, has failed.

Crisis management! We do not have to look at the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). Let us look at the environment for the classic example. The Federal Government gets involved in a State issue down there at Eden in relation to forestry, and says, 'We have to have a say here'. Having had the say, having got the cards in its hands to control the situation, it cannot do it. It does not know what to do. It does not know what the solution is. So we have the spectacle here in the chamber of Ministers playing with words against each other and leaks from the Cabinet room against each other. Do nothing: crisis: do nothing. The pattern is there: a failing government, a government that does not want to go on.

It is a government that can in seven minutes deregulate and deregister the pilots. It has taken seven years to do nothing on the waterfront. How about that? Seven years to do nothing on the waterfront, and yet it can pick out the pilots and knock them off. Easy, is it not? Okay, it does not matter in the ballot box; where it counts is on preselection. That is the fact of the matter. The Government is dealing with its mates, and that is where the country is going wrong and the Government has lost its way.

There are so many items in the Budget that I would like to give passing comment to. The decision to dump the first home buyers scheme, I think, was a tragedy. The scheme was failing and costly, but there is nothing to replace it. The Government is just dumping it on the States and hoping they will pick it up somehow or other. There are no plans, nothing has been thought through. It just hopes that the State governments will look after the first home buyers in this dreadful period they are going through.

We can look at the decisions the Government has entered into on the assets test for small business people and for farmers. The family allowance and the family allowance supplement are now tested by an assets test. Above all, there is the tax regime. We are now approaching a situation we had a couple of decades ago where there is positive encouragement for people to devolve their businesses into family trading or investment companies. The tax rate on family or investment companies is at 39 per cent and the upper personal tax rate is at 48.25. For three years that has been the situation. People are now going to stop behaving as individuals. They are going to start to build family companies, and that is a tragedy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker Mr F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91 will concentrate on the plans of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for micro-economic reform and, more particularly, on the economic implications of the Government's stated and foreshadowed proposals for the privatisation and deregulation of a range of government enterprises.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition and political commentators are somewhat prematurely proclaiming the Hawke-Keating Administration as that point in history when Labor broke away from its traditional heritage and extinguished its light on the hill. They see this happening in Labor's rejection of the Keynesian social democratic policies of deficit financing and public sector expansion in favour of adopting a right wing economic rationalist approach to solving the structural problems of the Australian economy.

That speculation has, of course, been greatly encouraged by recent ministerial comment. The Treasurer, in describing his reforms, uses phraseology such as `a watershed in the thinking of the Australian Labor Party'. Whether these admittedly fundamental economic changes constitute a permanent catapulting of Labor deep into the spectrum of right wing politics or merely a temporary aberration during tough economic times remains to be seen. Nevertheless, the hallmarks of the Hawke Administration will no doubt be recorded as fiscal restraint, deregulation and privatisation of public enterprises.

The political rhetoric underpinning these radical changes has been that Labor's great goal of social justice lies in the economic recovery and employment growth that will naturally evolve from a more competitive market. This blind faith in the inherent value of competition is characteristic of the thinking of economic rationalists that dominate both the Thatcher and Hawke Cabinets. I use the words `blind faith' advisedly, because the history of free market economies has not been spontaneous movement to an economic nirvana; rather, it has been characterised by periodic crises associated with the recessionary phase of the business cycle and by general systemic crises.

In those circumstances it was predictable-to all, of course, but the Labor Party faithful-that when macro-economic measures of financial deregulation, tax cuts, high interest rates, massive surpluses and the concomitant cuts to government spending all failed to make any significant impression on the external debt or the underlying high rate of inflation the Government would follow in Mrs Thatcher's footsteps and put privatisation on the top of the economic agenda.

The most interesting argument proffered to justify the recent proposals to sell off the family silver is that the exercise constitutes micro-economic reform. The Treasurer has eloquently argued in his Budget Speech that our new guiding light should be to make all levels of government business more innovative, efficient and competitive to ensure that they are not holding back our industries and are delivering a proper level of services to the community. Following this beacon, we are assured, will see us overcome the deep-rooted structural weaknesses in our economy-created, we are told, by Gough Whitlam and Malcolm Fraser-allow us to build a more balanced, independent economy and, thus, ensure lonely little Australia's survival in an increasingly predatory world economy.

The assumptions that I would like to challenge in analysing these plans for privatisation are whether competition will always provide the economic returns claimed and whether the specific privatisation proposals constitute micro-economic reform in any event.

Before I deal with the actual privatisation measures, I would like to make some general remarks about the problem of meeting the capital needs of government businesses-notably, the questions of the public sector borrowing requirement, Loan Council controls and gearing ratios. Despite the fact that the United Nations and the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development system of national accounts conventions treat assets sales and equity injections as financing transactions which have no effect on the size of the deficit, the Australian Treasury puts them on budget, adopting the irrational approach that ownership, not function, should be the determining factor.

Consequently, we are constantly confronted with the argument that to fund essential capital injections to government business enterprises (GBEs) from the Budget means cutting other expenditure-usually social justice programs. However, the same phoney convention is not applied to government owned financial institutions which are treated in the same way as private business. This placement of GBEs in the public sector means, of course, that their borrowings are treated in the same way as all government borrowings. They become part of the deficit and are subjected to the public sector borrowing requirement, Loan Council controls and global limitations. The subsuming of GBE borrowings within the general government sector deficit brings into play the impact of the fiscal indicator called the public sector borrowing requirement.

In these days when a government's financial reputation seems to be directly related to the size of its surplus, it is predictable that no Treasurer working within these irrational accounting conventions is going to look kindly on several billion dollars worth of GBE borrowings eating up his Budget surplus, but will welcome with open arms asset sales reducing the outlay side of the nation's accounts. However, private financial markets are not fooled by these conventions and frequently go to the trouble of calculating the true deficit figure by discounting the sales of equity.

The problem is accentuated by the Loan Council global controls on government borrowings being applied to GBEs, making it extremely hard for them to obtain capital to pursue development projects. The Treasury has yet to justify rationally how these controls fit within the picture of deregulation and micro-economic reform. One would have thought that the objective of such policies was to allow enterprises freedom to pursue their commercial interests and thereby maximise the efficient allocation of societies' resources. The obvious truth is that if one is about micro-economic reform, the ownership of the business is irrelevant. Allowing all enterprises, be they public or private, to maximise their present value is the only sensible way to achieve a higher level of wealth and income for all Australians. The Loan Council's policy of limiting the potential of GBEs can only produce a less than optimal allocation of resources. The simplest and greatest micro-economic reform of all would be to rid ourselves of these shackles on government businesses.

That brings me to the question of gearing ratios. Recently the Treasurer, in justifying the need for the Commonwealth Bank to pay for the State Bank of Victoria by raising 100 per cent of the purchase price as equity, argued that it was not prudent for the Commonwealth Bank to have a higher gearing ratio than its private competitors. Similar things have been said about Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines Ltd which need to borrow billions of dollars to fund aircraft purchases. Bank managers will say that they see gearing ratios merely as an indicator of the commitment of shareholders to their enterprise. They take the view that loans should not be given to people who have no incentive to avoid failure. However, GBEs are government backed, usually by guarantee but always by moral and political necessity. Just as the State Bank of Victoria could not be allowed to fail, neither can Telecom Australia, Qantas or Australian Airlines.

Accordingly, the point of gearing ratios for GBEs is not a question of prudentiality but of achieving the most efficient and effective structure for their business. Higher ratios exert pressure on management to maximise the performance of assets; lower ratios allow the business to ride out times of crisis. The correct financial gearing is clearly predicated upon the nature of the industry and the economic environment that the GBE is operating within.

Having made these general remarks, I now comment on some of the specific plans for privatisation. Often forgotten in the heated debate about Telecom, Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank are the proposals to sell the Moomba to Sydney gas pipeline and the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. The sale of the HLIC is not likely to obtain more than between $10m and $50m. It is a very successful, highly efficient business that was started by borrowing a mere $300,000 and which has made consistently high profits amounting to $25m over the last five financial years. Its return to the Government will far exceed the value of any debt that might be retired from the proceeds of its sale. So much for the guiding light of micro-economic reform. For some time now, that Corporation has been successfully resisting bids by its private sector competitors to raise premiums on mortgage insurance.

Our housing industry is in the depths of recession, with high interest rates making it very hard for new home buyers to scrape up the deposit, stamp duty, legal fees et cetera that go towards building a home. Affordability is the key factor. An additional premium impost will be just another straw to break the backs of thousands more potential home buyers. It is ironic that the sale of the HLIC will reduce competition in that industry by taking out a lean, mean and highly efficient government player and substituting a private corporation, which will immediately collude with the others to force up premiums.

The sale of the pipeline will be no joy to gas consumers. Inherent in the legislative arrangements are two hikes of 25 per cent in carriage costs on the pipeline. Some 100,000 New South Wales pensioners will find their gas bills increasing substantially as a result. Where are the efficiency gains here? The pipeline is a natural monopoly, the most efficient economic unit. There should and will be no competition. Professor Walker of the University of New South Wales has pointed out that increasing costs are the inevitable consequences of the sale. Privatisation simply will not make the industry more efficient. The argument that is currently being touted, that the Government has to weigh the benefits of continued ownership of public enterprises against the development of essential infrastructure, is fundamentally unsound, because the benefits to fiscal policy of asset sales are merely cosmetic.

As the eminent economist Willem E. Buiter pointed out, nationalising or denationalising becomes relevant only where the total net worth is positively altered by improved efficiencies. If the financial consequences are neutral or negative, we should not be privatising. That is why I cannot understand those within my Party and the Opposition who want to sell off all or part of the Commonwealth Bank. The Budget Papers reveal that the Commonwealth Banking Corporation is expected to pay a dividend of $158m. That figure is likely to change in the light of Cabinet's decision to privatise an initial 30 per cent and eventually 49 per cent of the Corporation.

I have no objection to the purchase of the State Savings Bank of Victoria. It is unthinkable that this Government could have allowed the crisis in confidence that would have flowed from a run on the largest bank in Victoria and the fifth largest bank in the nation. What angers me and the overwhelming majority of Labor's branch members and supporters in Australia is the decision to find the $1.6 billion purchase price by selling 30 per cent of the bank to private interests.

The most annoying feature of the decision was Cabinet's failure to explore options to finance the purchase in a way that would maintain the bank as an entirely public owned enterprise. The statutory capital adequacy requirements would allow the purchase to take place with an additional equity injection of only $400m, the balance being made up in subordinated debt. No-one would suggest that the Commonwealth Bank could not find $400m. The surplus employer reserves in its staff superannuation fund vastly exceed that amount, even after tax.

The Treasurer, though not denying the bank's capacity to meet the capital adequacy requirements, nevertheless takes the view that it is desirable that there be a substantial injection of equity into the bank to allow it to enter into bullish competition with the private banks and to maintain what he described as a prudent gearing ratio. I have pointed out already that the gearing ratios of a government backed enterprise cannot and should not be equated to private enterprises. The test should be the ratio that will best achieve the goals of the government enterprise. Higher gearing, provided it falls within the statutory prudential requirement, is simply not a problem.

There are many sound reasons why the bank should not be partially privatised. The most obvious can be distilled from the current row the Treasurer is having with the banks. There is no doubt that the banks have been conniving for some time to keep interest rates artificially high. As the Treasurer points out, measured in 90-day bank bills, the cost of money has fallen from 18.4 per cent in 1989 to 13.5 per cent now-a fall of almost 5 per cent. However, the banks have reduced their charges for home loans by only three quarters of one per cent. The reason is clear: they have had their fingers burnt to the tune of more than $1 billion by bad debts incurred by the crashes of the empires of our corporate cowboys-Skase, Bond, Elliott and the likes. Instead of making an honest market, they have chosen to rip off consumers to protect shareholders' dividends. A Commonwealth Bank with board obligations, albeit to only 49 per cent of the private shareholders, would be subject to the same temptations to maximise profits collusively by sacrificing true competition and efficiency within the banking industry.

The availability of funds for housing is another telling example. Housing portfolios are the least profitable of bankers' business. Historically the overwhelming majority of loans for housing have come from the Commonwealth Bank and the State Bank of Victoria. The building societies, particularly St George, are the next most important players, followed by a somewhat token performance from the private banks. Privatising half of the two major Australian home lenders is guaranteed to see a substantial reduction in the availability of funds for home lending-a tragedy not only for prospective home owners, but also for the beleaguered building industry.

The Commonwealth Bank was established in 1912 by a Labor government wishing to avoid having to go cap in hand to conservative thinking boards of the private banks to fund Labor projects and implement Labor's financial policies. A 49 per cent private holding in the bank must inevitably again lead to at least 50 per cent of the board's seats being filled by persons with a political viewpoint inimical to Labor and its traditional constituency.

The proposals to create a competitive framework in the telecommunications industry are extremely complex, but fit within the principles I have enunciated already. There is no evidence to support the Cabinet's view that a competitive situation will produce better economic results than a national monopoly. On the contrary, the most efficient telecommunications systems in the world, with the lowest charges, are the monopolies of Scandinavia. The most competitive and efficient telecommunications industry is that recently nationalised by France which replaced a run-down, inefficient private enterprise system. The French now lead the world in research and development, and French exports are making serious inroads into the deregulated American and Japanese markets.

The overwhelming overseas evidence is that the provision of a competitor to government monopolies results in cheaper calls for business but more expensive calls for ordinary consumers. The Government's decision to allow competition, but not a free market, in the sense that prices will be fixed and the competitors rigidly regulated, does nothing for efficiency or micro-economic reform.

On the other side of the coin, Aussat Pty Ltd is a debt ridden space relic that deserves to be sold. Further, there is no doubt that the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations are likely to open up international calls to foreign competitors. Given that side of the equation, proposals to sell Aussat and allow full competition on overseas calls are sensible decisions. Equally sensible and consistent with micro-economic reform are proposals to utilise excess capacity on the local network created by optic fibre cables and allow wholesaling to air time resellers in the niche markets.

One of the delights of being elected to this Parliament is that my alumni includes the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello). The more Labor embraces the policies of Thatcher, the more it erodes the political base of the Liberals. The traditional Labor supporters, alienated by the rejection of the philosophy of Curtin and Chifley, will inexorably turn to the Democrats. The end result of the Costello plan would be Labor dominating the centre and a large portion of the right of the spectrum. The Democrats would represent the left, and his mob would be relegated to the extreme right with M. Penn in France.

However, the honourable member for Higgins can dream all he likes. The current neo-classical economic fixation of the Hawke Government is but a phase. Soon political pragmatism and relentless critical party rank and file will return Labor to the Keynesian policies of government intervention to achieve price level stability, output growth, full employment and a balance of payments equilibrium. The Labor leopard has not changed its spots-Cabinet has merely temporarily lost sight of them.

We all expected, and indeed hoped, that the Government would do the right thing and that we would see these tough decisions being implemented in the Treasurer's post-election Budget. But, unfortunately, the Treasurer got the jitters. He got a little bit wimpish and, as a consequence, this Budget provided no tough options whatsoever. Indeed, it avoided the difficult decisions and led a lot of people throughout this country to be further disappointed in the performance and direction of this Government and led them to question further the economic direction and credibility of our Treasurer.

This is a time which requires tough decisions to be made. He referred to the difficulties of home buyers in affording their homes because of high interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are higher.

—We can apply the same high interest rate problems to people in small businesses who are currently suffering from record high interest rates and a record high level of bankruptcies. As the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) so aptly represents in this House, the farmers of Australia are also suffering from the same high interest rates which are plaguing small businessmen and home buyers. SPEECH.PARA: All of these things are being caused by the Government's deliberate policy of implementing high interest rates. The Treasurer, quite shamefacedly, says, 'We have introduced a high interest rate policy designed to bring the economy into gear, rein it in, so that we can control it properly because it got out of control, it was bubbling over, it was effervescent'-those were the words he used to use. I do not think that any reasonable, well-balanced person would say that we are doing anything else but moving into a recession.

This of course poses a question with regard to the credibility of this Government's economic management. Normally, Australia has had to import its recessions. We have caught recessions as the rest of the world has caught them. In this particular instance Australia has caught its own recession. We are totally self-sufficient in creating recessions these days. That is a great claim that this Government can make; that is its great achievement. Despite relatively high commodity prices and a buoyant world economy over the last six or seven years, Australia's economy has been moving backwards. We are seeing an increase in unemployment and an increase in our balance of payments deficit-a shocking balance of payments deficit which is causing a great deal of concern throughout the community. We are seeing a massive increase in our foreign debt-an alarming increase of some 400 or 500 per cent in our foreign debt since the Labor Government came into power. We are seeing our level of competitiveness falling further and further each and every day, all under the administration of this Labor Government. We are finding that Australia can no longer hold its head up around the world as being one of the major economies; one of the best economies in the world.

Our standard of living has, without any question, fallen. The average Australian now enjoys a standard of living that is considerably less than it was years ago. We are all looking forward to some major changes to try to turn back the tide of this economic recession which is starting to sweep across the land. We are all looking forward to hearing the Government say, 'Right, now we have the chance. Now we know that we have a good reason to make changes. Let's go out and do it. Let's, for example, enter into privatisation which is a good thing, which is something that, despite the fact that we have opposed it, is something which can deliver real benefit to the average Australian'.

These enterprises, by rights, should be in the private sector which traditionally has a better track record of providing more competitive services and better services.

The Government has created the expectation that privatisation would be introduced. Yet the Government has really gone only half way. We have seen the Government talk about tariff reform, but we have seen the Government also hedge away from real tariff reform. In this Budget we thought there might have been an opportunity for the Government to engage in picking up the recommendations of the Garnaut report. Unfortunately, the Government has backed away again. Once again, had the Government picked up the recommendations of the Garnaut report, it would have taken a tough decision. Had the Government picked up those recommendations, in the long term it would have delivered real gains to the average Australian. It would have put the economy on a far sounder footing and it would have indeed created more employment and improved the standard of living of the average Australian.

Once again we have to wait for this Government to go to its political masters and seek their approval for its hoped-for reforms in the telecommunications industries. It begs the question: if this Government wants to make decisions, why is it that it has to go to the national executive of the Labor Party to have those decisions ratified before it can implement them?

In March this year, Australians went to the polls to elect a government. One should have thought that when that Government was elected, it would have gone about the business of governing. We sit here waiting for the national executive of the Labor Party to tell the Government whether it can implement the sorts of things that it proposes to do or whether it cannot.

In the Budget delivered only a few short weeks ago, the Government once again claimed that one of its great justifications for micro-economic reform is what it is doing on the waterfront. When one cuts through the rhetoric and looks at the facts, one finds that the Government's so-called reforms of the waterfront are illusory; indeed, they are almost non-existent.

On 1 June last year, the Government set itself the task of creating a 30 per cent increase in productivity on the Australian waterfront over the next three years. It set aside funds to provide redundancy payments to fulfil those increases in productivity on the Australian waterfront. If one looks through the Budget Papers delivered a few weeks ago, one discovers that the funds set aside last financial year to pay for productivity gains on the Australian waterfront have not been fully taken up.

Indeed, less than 25 per cent of the budgeted funds which were to be paid out for productivity gains on the waterfront have actually been paid out. That tells us that the Australian waterfront and the Government's so-called reforms of it are moving at less than 25 per cent of the pace the Government expected. It could be suggested that the numbers of people who have actually left the waterfront under the Government's so-called reforms are less than the numbers of people who have been employed under the Government's employment programs for new waterfront labour.

Over the past few months we have seen more people actually employed on the waterfront than made redundant. Surely that does not add up to anything like the sort of micro-economic reform that the Government's rhetoric would indicate is actually occurring on the Australian waterfront.

Once again, if one also looks at the Budget Papers and the Shipping Industry Reform Authority and at the expended funds, as opposed to the budgeted funds, for productivity increases in the shipping industry, one finds that the pace of reform in the shipping industry is moving along at about 50 per cent of the pace the Government had anticipated.

The same thing can be said for the towage industry; another area that the Government claims it is reforming. If one looks at the money actually expended compared to the money that was actually budgeted for, one finds that reform within the towage industry is moving along at about 50 per cent of the pace the Government indicated it would move along at. What it tells us is that when we entered the chamber on that fateful Tuesday evening a couple of weeks ago to listen to the Budget, the sorts of reforms that the Government claimed in its rhetoric that it was achieving have not been achieved. Indeed, a further analysis of the Budget Papers reveals that fact.

The pace of micro-economic reform on the Australian waterfront and throughout our Australian shipping industry is absolutely a snail's pace. One should compare the types of reforms that we are having here in Australia to the types of reforms that we find are occurring around the world in places like New Zealand, where a Labor Government with a bit of backbone implemented reforms on the waterfront which have achieved a 100 per cent increase in productivity in 12 months. In April last year in the United Kingdom, the Government implemented reforms on its waterfront which led to a 65 per cent increase in productivity in the 12 month period following the introduction of those reforms. We now see in Italy major reforms of the waterfront currently under way. Indeed, in many other countries throughout the world, one will find governments implementing quite dramatic, sensational and very exciting reforms to their waterfronts, which would leave the Australian Government's expected increases of 30 per cent in productivity over three years in the dust.

What the Government is doing here is pathetic. Whilst this Government may certainly be achieving some productivity gains on the waterfront, the rest of the world is achieving more and at a faster pace. As a consequence, Australia is falling further and further behind in the competitive stakes around the world.

One of the reasons there are so many problems in Australian society today is because we cannot compete well enough. We cannot compete because the Government we have here in Canberra is unable and does not have the courage to make the necessary decisions in order to bring Australia's economy up to the level of efficiencies of the rest of the world. As a consequence, our standard of living falls further and further.

The Budget Papers also reveal that social welfare reform was not engaged in the manner in which many people had expected it would be. We certainly saw the first home owners scheme axed-a scheme which the Government accused the Opposition of being prepared to axe if it got into government. Of course, the Government turned around and did it after the election.

There is very little benefit or incentive for the family in this Budget. There is very little incentive for people to go out there and save money. In this Budget the Government has broken many of the promises it made prior to the election. For example, it wrote to pensioners in February this year and promised them in writing that it would not introduce a $2.50 fee for prescriptions. What did the Government do in the Budget the other night? It introduced a $2.50 fee for prescriptions.

In the build-up to the elections in March this year, the Government wrote to the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association and said, `We are not going to privatise the Commonwealth Bank. It is only those neanderthals in the Opposition who would dare do that sort of economic vandalism'. That was another promise that was broken in the past few weeks when the Government stepped towards making some form of privatisation of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation.

We saw in the Budget a Government that lacks the courage to take the necessary decisions to bring Australia into line with the rest of the world. The Government has failed to give us any hope of economic efficiency.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is sinking like the Titanic.

—As the Leader of the National Party points out, the Government is driving the Australian economy like the Titanic. We are rapidly approaching the rocks and we are about five feet away from hitting them. The Government is engaging in a policy of `steady as she sinks'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to address the problem of homelessness in the electorate of Adelaide and the need to support a peak body to coordinate the delivery of services to homeless people. The electorate of Adelaide contains the central business district which, like most large cities, contains a number of homeless people, probably between 300 and 500. In Adelaide, there are numerous services to house, feed and offer assistance to these people. It is not clear whether the homeless migrate towards the city because that is where they can find food and shelter or whether the services were set up there because of the large number of homeless already there-probably a combination of both.

SPEECH.PARA: Since my election, I have made it my business to visit the various organisations in the city offering succour to the homeless. It has certainly been a very enlightening experience for me. Rarely have I met so many exceptionally dedicated and resourceful people and I would like to thank them fairly individually at this time.

The Adelaide Central Mission coordinates a number of programs for the needy. One suggestion recently put forward by it is home-based community care in the larger homes of South Australians who, like me, have found that since their children have left home they have been left with a number of vacant rooms. There is Sister Janet Mead from the Catholic Day Care Centre for Homeless People who organises meals and a soup run each evening, with which I have been able to assist. There is Saint Luke's Mission where I recently attended, with Commissioner Brian Burdekin, the opening of a new shelter for homeless youth, built with Commonwealth Government assistance. Paul Nicholas of the Wright Court Day Centre offers refuge and comfort for the neediest in the community and some entertainment. Sister Veronica of the Daughters of Charity runs the Hutt Street Centre, which feeds over 1,300 men and women each year. Two weeks ago I had the privilege of helping to serve 120 lunches there.

There is also a number of other organisations like Westcare, which serves very healthy food; Anglican Community Services; Catholic Family Services; Christian Community Care Services; Offenders Aid and Rehabilitation Services; Seventh Day Adventist City Church Welfare Society; St Vincent de Paul Society; of course, the Salvation Army, and the Second Story. These all deserve special mention for their outstanding efforts and assistance to our fellow human beings who are in desperate need. I am continuing to make my way around this sector and unfortunately even six months has not been sufficient to encounter all the very worthy people.

As in other capital cities, some of these charities rely on government grants to remunerate their managers, but most of them are terribly understaffed and could not maintain their services without volunteers. There are two areas which have lacked attention because of these circumstances: first, research on the reasons and direction of homelessness; secondly, the need for a peak organisation to coordinate these multifarious activities.

I was surprised to learn from the representatives of the Department of Community Services and Health at a recent public hearing of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs, which is investigating the funding of peak community services bodies, that there is no national coordinating body for older, itinerant, homeless people. I note here that there are national bodies catering for the specific problems of youth homelessness and for women's shelters. But the group being serviced in the central business district of Adelaide is made up largely of itinerant, unemployed, older men, although there are a few women.

I was also surprised to learn at the public hearing that the funding of peak bodies appears to have been an historic process whereby groups lobby the Government and, according to the interests that prevail on the day, are accepted or otherwise for government funding. This is a submissions-based process and it has resulted in some needs being ignored, I believe, while others are represented by a number of different organisations.

The mature homeless, it seems to me, are presently inadequately represented at the resource coordinating level. A coordinating body could ensure that there was no unnecessary duplication of services by this large number of very worthy bodies, that those services were targeted and geographically dispersed, and that the sector was adequately funded as a whole. It could furthermore undertake research in the State capital cities, in particular, where the problem of homelessness appears to be concentrated.

Brian Burdekin got the ball rolling in this respect with his very extensive and impressive research in 1988. But it is difficult now to provide the adequate well-targeted services that we need when we have not got specific scientific data on what our clients are doing there, whether the problem is growing, what problems they encounter, and how they can be best serviced. I hope our report will address some on these problems. In the meantime, I convey my good wishes to those people presently engaged in serving the interests of homeless people and the many volunteers who have stepped forward into this breach.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of this House to a remarkable piece of theatrical illusion that is being performed. The main players in this scenario are the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley), the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths). The name given to this theatrical farce is micro-economic reform but, like so many theatrical productions, what has unfolded here bears little relation to reality.

SPEECH.PARA: The major performers appear to have adopted Plato's advice when he said, `I wonder if we could contrive some magnificent myth that would in itself carry conviction to the whole community'. The myth that the Government is creating here is that it is serious about micro-economic reform but the words spoken in this House about the Government's complete change of policy direction on privatisation-in itself an endorsement of the principles of privatisation the coalition was putting forward six years ago-are the creation of political illusion designed to convince the Australian community that this Government is serious about economic reform and is genuine in its desire to get this country back on an even keel. On the one hand we have the Prime Minister asserting that selling part of the Commonwealth Bank is okay but selling Telecom Australia is just not on. That is not micro-economic reform; that is political expediency.

Another drama being enacted here is the struggle between the Minister for conservation and the Minister for Resources. If finding the right balance between conservation and development were not such a serious topic, we could be forgiven for thinking we have been watching a comedy rather than a tragedy. It is about time that this Government started practising the principles of sustained development rather than merely mouthing the rhetoric of sustained development. In other words, it should stop the play acting and return to reality.

Let me give just one example of how this question of sustainable development has become distorted beyond reason. In my own region of the central highlands of Victoria a strict code of forest practices applies to all coupes selected for logging. The actual decision-making process from when an area is first selected for potential suitability for logging to when ministerial approval is actually granted takes approximately 12 months. During this period all interested parties, including industry, environment and community groups, take part in this decision-making process. A valuable resource is then harvested but the tragedy is that not all is utilised.

The Victorian Government, like this Government, is fearful of the word `pulp'. It regards it as a dirty word. The amount of waste left on most logging coupes is staggering and this very waste material left to rot on the forest floor in the central highlands area alone could earn the Australian Government millions of dollars in export earnings. On a coupe of around 40 hectares the waste left behind if pulped could bring in around $400,000 or up to $1.2 million in finished paper products. Instead, most of this waste material is burnt, adding to the problem of greenhouse. Where the waste material is left piled metres high on the ground, it makes it difficult for forest workers to replant, frequently resulting in injury, it blocks out the light and it hinders the growth of young trees. This is just a ridiculous waste of resources.

To add to this problem Bowater-Scott Ltd is currently importing eucalypt material for its Myrtleford plant, where similar material is being burned just kilometres away. The collection of residual round wood to replace imports is not the same as utilising native forests for woodchipping.

The opportunity exists now to increase local manufacture, reduce imports and increase State revenues, all without cutting down a single additional tree, simply by using the remains of trees already felled for timber milling. Surely this should be central to the goal of sustainable development. Surely it is about time some common sense was brought into this drama. I urge the Government to include economic as well as ecological consider- ations.

There has been a change of environment Minister but he got to meet the new Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly).

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to thank the editors of the two local newspapers in my electorate who most kindly agreed to sponsor the event in the sense of making sure that there was a lot of publicity for it and who also published the winning entry, which belonged to Daniel Philps, in their respective newspapers. I want to thank in particular the editors of the two news- papers, Brian Hurst, from the Bayside Bulletin and Redlands Times and Mr Allan Watson from the Wynnum Herald. I want to thank them very much for their cooperation and assistance and congratulate them for their concern for the young people of my electorate of Bowman and for the general environment.

As part of his prize, as I said, I brought Daniel to Canberra. Today he had the pleasure of meeting with the Minister for the Environment, who spent some time with him. They went over some of the issues that he brought out in his own essay.

I conducted a survey among my constituents earlier this year well before the election, a survey to which I am very proud to say some 15 per cent responded although I did not have the facilities to send a stamped addressed envelope. Out of that a very big percentage, some 25 per cent, named the environment as No. 1 on their major lists of concerns and said it was the most important issue.

Much of my electorate is bounded by Moreton Bay so the issues of sensible development and the destruction of our sensitive wetlands are particularly important. In his winning essay Daniel discussed the need for development which takes account of the highly sensitive nature of mangrove and seagrass bed ecosystems. He pointed out that canal developments needed to be carefully planned so that any damage to the environment was mini- mised. In my electorate I am not all that happy to say there have been probably too many canal developments, one of which is really a blight on the landscape in what was one of the best areas in Australia.

Daniel highlighted the fact that Redlands still has large tracts of undeveloped land which is a natural habitat for a large range of native animals. He particularly emphasised the need to preserve areas of natural habitat for koalas in our district. Koalas have been plentiful on the Bayside but increasing urban pressures are destroying their natural habitats. A couple of them live in my yard so I have my own home-grown koalas. Daniel also emphasised the need for careful planning as the Brisbane metropolis expands outwards, putting ever increasing pressure on the delicate ecological balance of the Bayside.

Daniel is particularly lucky to be a student of the Redlands Community College. The College is only one of three such secondary schools in Queensland and is one of the best schools of the Bayside district. I have first-hand knowledge of the school because my daughter Zina was one of the first students and my wife conducted an English course there part time. She enjoyed it very much. The principal of the school, Dr David Warner, is an excellent educator and administrator who is regarded very highly in the Redlands area and in the whole of Brisbane.

The school is very heavily community-minded. It gets itself involved in Skillshare programs and all sorts of community activities and is one of those fine schools and fine establishments that I hope will continue as a concept for many years to come. Tomorrow Daniel will go to the Australian National University; he wants to have a look at their law courses. He will also go to the usual places like the Australian National Gallery.

I want to congratulate Daniel for his excellent essay. It was a deserving winner. I am sure with young people like Daniel we will not have much trouble in preserving our environment, which is something our opponents over there always talk about but never do anything about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I applaud some of the decisions made by the Government to reform the welfare sector. It was very courageous of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) to risk the wrath of the loony left by grasping the nettle and making the first tentative steps towards injecting some sort of rationale into welfare spending. For too long the necessity for higher welfare expenditure has been considered by the crusty old adherents to the Labor Party platform as being some self-evident truth, a truth that remains unshakeable in the face of mounting evidence of abuses in the system.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, the shock of making such a radical departure from the secure confines of that happily redundant socialist notion of the welfare state has induced an addled state of consciousness in the Minister responsible. An example of this may be seen in recent changes made to the funding of aged hostel care. These changes are made remarkable only by the lack of planning and forethought that seems to have gone into them. Under new funding arrangements aged hostels receive $2.40 per patient per day for unspecialised care and $19 per patient per day for those who require personalised care. Those subsidies are reserved for those classed as financially disadvantaged.

To be financially disadvantaged one must have assets that are valued at less than 2 times the single pension per year. In other words, one's assets must be worth less than $18,365. If one's assets surpass this amount in value then the hostel at which one resides is not entitled to a subsidy on one's behalf. As honourable members may appreciate, $18,000 is not a substantial sum of money and consequently many hostels are deprived of subsidies for a number of their patients. For smaller hostels this can only have a crippling effect on their overall funding, forcing many to lay off staff and curtail services. Some hostels are being forced to move their patients to nursing homes while others are being confronted with the prospect of closure.

As I stated earlier, in adopting these measures the Government has undoubtedly been motivated by the praiseworthy desire to curtail expenditure in the welfare sector. Indeed, we in the Opposition applaud any move towards rationalising the welfare sector. It is then very sad to note the incompetence and lack of judgment that form the backdrop to the Government's decision to limit the subsidies paid to hostels.

This particular measure seems to me to be anything but rational. As I stated earlier, by limiting the funds made available to the smaller hostels the Government is forcing them to move their patients to nursing homes where the Government pays a subsidy of $55 per patient per day. One does not have to be Albert Einstein to calculate the extra cost to the Government of this measure, not to mention the trauma and upset which the move causes to the patients involved.

To provide a more specific example of the added cost of the measure I shall use the example of Jacaranda Lodge in my electorate where nine residents who were receiving $2.50 per day from the Government have been forced to move to nursing homes because they were not considered to be financially disadvantaged. This has meant that the hostel has lost $8,212.50 in funding per annum-$8,212.50 that was vital in a tight budget for the maintenance of essential staffing and services.

The move to a nursing home has meant that the Government is now paying $55 per patient per day for those nine patients. Projected annually, the Government is now paying $180,675 for those patients alone. That is a substantially larger cost than that originally borne by the Government. If we are going to see these much needed costs applied to the welfare sector, let us at least see them being conceived sensibly and rationally. As far as I can see, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has provided the Minister with an ultimatum to cut the expenditure of his Department. The Minister has responded by leaping in, making cuts hither and thither, with little thought to the cost in both human and financial terms.

If anything, we may derive from this one example the absurd farce that really is the Government's whole commitment to curtailing expenditure. It is ill-conceived and incompetently implemented. Ironically, the cost of the service is more expensive to the taxpayer as a result of the cuts. In the case of the Jacaranda Lodge in my electorate, by saving one stitch the Government has cost the taxpayer nine.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to bring to the House a matter of concern. That concern is the decision made last Friday by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) management to cut local input into ABC regional programs in New South Wales. A few years ago I recall that in Wollongong we had a nightly ABC television program which provided five minutes of local news and was broadcast just before the national news. This was cut a few years back. At that time we were assured that we would get a better news service. We were told that we would get a State-wide news service and there would be segments of local news in that service. I do not know what happened to it but we have no ABC local news service. It is certainly not a State-wide one. There is no local segment in it.

SPEECH.PARA: We are well served in the Illawarra by the local radio station, 2WN. It provides an excellent service. I was very concerned to learn on Friday that the ABC management had made a decision again to cut local input. We are very fortunate that on a Saturday morning we have a two-hour arts and jazz program. This is a very popular program. It is conducted by a woman named Kate Peters. It just so happens that at the very time that this decision by the ABC management to cut this program is being made, Kate Peters is in Italy accepting an international award for her work in radio. The ABC management has now decided to cut this program. One can understand if it were to save huge amounts of money. Spread over the six regional ABC stations in New South Wales, the ABC will save the monumental sum of $9,000 a year.

A survey was carried out before this decision was made to find out what people wanted on the ABC. Eleven per cent of listeners said they wanted more sport while 21 per cent of listeners said they wanted less sport. If there is one thing that the ABC, especially in regional areas, provides a lot of, it is sport. I must not offend my colleague the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) by knocking sport; I would not do that. The ABC does provide a very extensive coverage of sport. The jazz and arts program which can be seen for two hours on a Saturday morning is going to be replaced by a national network sports program called Grandstand.

One could understand a little if there was going to be a local sports program-for instance, details of local sporting teams and interviews with players and officials-but this is going to be a national program. I would suggest that with the exception of Wayne Gardner, the Illawarra Steelers and maybe our basketball team, the Hawks, the Illawarra will not get much of a mention on that national program.

Kate Peters' program was a local program. It was devoted to what was happening locally in the jazz and arts scene. It went for two hours on a Saturday morning. It was a very popular program. It will be cut as part of an ABC cost cutting measure. I appeal to the ABC to stop decimating local radio in New South Wales. I appeal especially to the Managing Director of the ABC, Mr Hill, to think again about this decision and to keep local input. It is very important. As I said before, we were all assured when our local news program was cut that we would get a better service. Our better service today is no service at all. That is what is going to happen in ABC radio. Eventually the regional stations will be replaced with a network program and we will lose that very important local input.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 17 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have hundreds of pensioners been unable to obtain the 1990 influenza vaccine because pharmacies throughout Australia have recently suffered extreme shortages of the vaccine; if so, why.
(2) How is allocation of influenza vaccine determined between pharmaceutical warehouses and the surgical suppliers for doctors' surgeries.
(3) Will he allow negotiation between pharmacy representatives and the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories to determine allocations of influenza vaccine which will meet public demand.
(4) Will influenza vaccine be deleted from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme next year; if so, will pensioners be forced to pay for the vaccine.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An overall shortage of the 1990 influenza vaccine has been experienced even though the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (CSL) produced significantly more vaccine than it did for the previous year and over 60% more vaccine was available for distribution than in 1989.
The shortage has resulted from an unprecedented demand for the vaccine which stemmed from media coverage of the recent Northern Hemisphere influenza experience.
All sections of the community increased their demand for the vaccine but the most substantial increase was noted in the category of those at least risk from influenza.
(2) In common with other pharmaceutical manufacturers, CSL distributes its vaccine to wholesalers and public hospitals. It has no control over the subsequent steps of distribution from wholesalers.
(3) I understand that CSL has already entered into discussion regarding the distribution of the vaccine with representatives of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and the AMA.
(4) There are no plans to remove the influenza vaccine from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme next year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 23 August:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report in the Age of 17 August 1990 that at least five people, including a woman and child, have been killed at the village of Ok Bago on the Papua New Guinea (PNG) side of the border with Irian Jaya as a part of a continuing Indonesian military operation there; if so, has there been any expression of concern from the Australian Government to the Indonesian Government on this matter.

(2) Will Australia publicly lend its support to the protests to Indonesia by the PNG Foreign Minister, Mr Michael Somare, as reported by AFP on 14 August 1990, regarding Indonesian military incursions into PNG territory and infringements of PNG sovereignty.
(3) Did the Australian Ambassador to Indonesia, Mr Philip Flood, discuss these military incursions while on his recent visit to Irian Jaya.

(4) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports of the level of military activity on the border; if so, will Australia convey to the PNG Government, in the strongest terms, its concerns that refugees in the Yapsie area be permitted to stay in PNG at least until the situation in Irian Jaya improves and the safe return of the refugees is completely guaranteed.
(5) Is the Minister able to state the (a) whereabouts and (b) present condition of the OPM leader Melkianus Salosa who was recently forcibly deported to Indonesia by the PNG Government.

(6) Has Salosa been granted any access to independent legal or non-government organisation representatives in a position to monitor his rights in his present situation of detention and alleged intense interrogation.
(7) Is the Minister able to state whether Salosa's forced repatriation was legally well-founded and it complied with Papua New Guinea's obligations as a signatory to the UN Convention on Refugees.

(8) Does the Minister have any information as to the (a) whereabouts, (b) living conditions, and (c) legal status of the seven Melanesian Irian Jayans who sought asylum in the PNG Consulate, Jayapura, on 14 December 1989, and who were subsequently handed over to the Indonesian authorities.
(9) Has the Government sought assurances from Indonesia that the legal and human rights of these political prisoners will be fully respected.
(10) What information does the Minister possess about Indonesia's intentions regarding the eleven alleged OPM activists recently detained in Irian Jaya.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of press reports of recent Indonesian incursions into PNG territory. The Australian government has not commented on these, believing that the management of their joint border is a matter for Indonesia and Papua New Guinea to work out in cooperation with each other.

(2) The Australian government was not asked to associate itself with Sir Michael Somare's protest of 14 August calling on Indonesia to respect the territorial integrity of Papua New Guinea. It does not plan to do so.
(3) The Australian Ambassador discussed developments along the Indonesian-PNG border with Indonesian officials during his recent visit to Irian Jaya.

(4) The latest information available to me is that the UNHCR office in Papua New Guinea, with the cooperation of the PNG government, plans to move refugees from Yapsie to the refugee camp further south at East Awin.
(5-6) According to my most recent information, the questioning of Melky Salosa has been completed. I understand that he is being held in Jayapura.

(7) I have no information to indicate that the deportation of Salosa was not legally well founded. Salosa did not have refugee status. His extradition was sought by the Indonesian government for his alleged involvement in an attack on a transmigration camp in Irian Jaya which resulted in the death of a large number of civilians. Salosa was arrested in Papua New Guinea in December last year for the illegal possession of weapons. Before his deportation he was appearing before a PNG court on a charge of illegal entry. I believe that Papua New Guinea's deportation of Salosa did not contravene its obligations as a signatory to the United Nations Convention on Refugees.

(8) My latest information about the four Irianese who sought asylum in the PNG consulate in Jayapura in December last year is that all four were brought to trial in June on a count of subversion. I understand that all have received sentences of between twelve and eighteen years imprisonment. Staff from the ICRC have had access to the detainees.
(9) The Australian government through the Australian Embassy in Jakarta has continued to monitor the situation of the four Irianese who sought asylum.

(10) I understand that in early August the Indonesian Armed Forces in Jayapura announced the capture of 11 suspected OPM members. They are reportedly being questioned by the security authorities prior to their trial.
